Rwanda Seeks $6.2 Billion Climate Finance by 2030 at COP29.

06:31, 2024-11-15

Rwanda is accelerating its climate action agenda with bold plans to mobilize $6.2 billion in climate finance from 2024 to 2030, aiming to fund critical biodiversity and climate resilience projects across the nation. This ambitious goal was unveiled during the 29th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP29), where Rwanda presented its newly adopted National Climate and Nature Finance Strategy.




The country’s overall climate action plan, which is encapsulated in its Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), has an estimated price tag of $11 billion since it was first introduced in 2020. However, the financing gap to fully implement these plans currently stands at over $6 billion.

Teddy Mugabo, CEO of Rwanda Green Fund, addressed delegates at COP29, outlining the government’s commitment to closing this gap by leveraging innovative climate finance mechanisms and private sector partnerships. Mugabo explained that the new strategy will be rolled out by operationalizing a green taxonomy, enhancing capacity-building efforts, and implementing financial de-risking measures to attract private investment.




“We are focused on creating the financial tools and frameworks necessary to scale up investment in climate and nature-based solutions," said Mugabo. "By 2030, Rwanda aims to secure $6.2 billion to fund climate and biodiversity initiatives, ensuring that our NDCs become a reality for a sustainable future.”

Rwanda’s efforts to address climate change and biodiversity loss are increasingly being recognized as models for developing countries. The country's strategy is centered on ensuring that both domestic and international investors are confident in financing projects aimed at reducing emissions, enhancing climate resilience, and protecting ecosystems.




The new finance mechanisms, which include green bonds, blended finance, and insurance schemes, are designed to encourage greater involvement from the private sector and international climate funds.

Mugabo emphasized that Rwanda’s strategy goes beyond financing, with a strong emphasis on building local expertise and strengthening institutional capacities to implement climate projects effectively. This approach is aligned with Rwanda’s broader vision of integrating climate resilience into national development plans.




The $6.2 billion target is part of Rwanda's broader climate finance goal, which seeks to support the implementation of the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), aimed at reducing carbon emissions and enhancing the country’s resilience to climate impacts. The government has also set ambitious goals to increase green energy production, promote sustainable agriculture, and invest in nature-based solutions, such as forest conservation and ecosystem restoration.

Rwanda’s push for a comprehensive, innovative climate finance strategy comes as the world grapples with the escalating impacts of climate change. The success of the strategy will depend on strong partnerships with both local and international stakeholders, including the private sector, development banks, and multilateral climate funds.




Rwanda's presentation at COP29 exhibits the country’s determination to implement its climate action plans at an accelerated pace, ensuring that it remains on track to meet its 2030 targets while contributing to the global fight against climate change. The $6.2 billion funding goal marks a pivotal moment in Rwanda’s climate action journey and sets the stage for a sustainable future for the nation and the region. As global leaders continue to meet in Baku, Rwanda's strategic approach to climate finance is a call to action for the international community to increase support for climate solutions, particularly in Africa, where the effects of climate change are already being felt most acutely.




Rwanda’s National Climate and Nature Finance Strategy signals a new era of climate action and investment, one that aims to deliver both environmental sustainability and economic growth for the country.

This funding is a key part of a disaster recovery program initiated in response to the devastating heavy rains that occurred on May 2 and 3, 2023, resulting in the deaths of at least 135 individuals and displacing numerous families.




The emergency ministry reports that the allocated funds will facilitate the rehabilitation and reconstruction of a total of 6,218 houses. To date, 2,830 of these homes are currently under construction, 2,052 have been completed, and 1,335 remain to be addressed.

Major General (Rtd) Albert Murasira, the Minister in Charge of Emergency Management, emphasized the government's commitment to providing safe housing for affected families.




“Constructing and rehabilitating homes for families hit by disasters is within the government’s capacity, and it is progressing well,” he stated.

Minister Murasira further explained, “We have constructed houses for those who had plots, and we are now dealing with expropriation for those remaining and ensuring they receive their homes. We have secured the funds, and we aim to complete this program by June next year, ensuring everyone has their house finalized.”




Lambert Dushimimana, the Governor of Western Province, acknowledged the ongoing risks of disasters in the region but highlighted the resilience of the local population. “Even though the region has a high risk of disasters, the population is adapting and finding ways to cope,” he noted.

The World Bank funding not only aims to provide immediate shelter but also seeks to strengthen the resilience of communities against future disasters. As reconstruction efforts continue, the government remains focused on implementing effective disaster management strategies to mitigate risks and enhance community preparedness.




This significant financial support puts MINEMA in an advantaged position of taking crucial steps toward rebuilding lives and restoring hope for families affected by last year’s tragic events.

Caffeine and Heart Health: Striking the Right Balance

04:13, 2024-10-28

Recent years have seen a surge in research focusing on caffeine's effects on cardiovascular health, prompting one critical question: How much caffeine is too much? In a roundup of the latest studies, Medical News Today explores emerging evidence regarding caffeine’s impact on heart health, revealing both potential benefits and risks.

Caffeine, a popular stimulant found in coffee, tea, and cocoa, is consumed daily by millions worldwide.




Many individuals rely on their morning cup to boost alertness and combat fatigue, while others enjoy it throughout the day for various health benefits. Given that approximately one in seven deaths globally is attributed to coronary heart disease, the cardioprotective potential of caffeine has become a compelling area of study. Recent findings highlight a dual narrative surrounding caffeine consumption. On one hand, some studies suggest that moderate caffeine intake may bolster vascular health and lower the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Conversely, excessive caffeine consumption has been linked to an increased risk of stroke, raising questions about safe consumption levels.




The most recent research, published in Rheumatology on October 9, adds to this ongoing discourse. This study found that higher caffeine intake may enhance blood vessel health, particularly in patients with lupus—a condition associated with a heightened risk of cardiovascular issues. This finding is significant, as individuals with lupus face an increased susceptibility to stroke and heart attacks. The implications of these studies are profound. While moderate caffeine intake may offer protective cardiovascular benefits, excessive consumption could pose risks. Health experts are emphasizing the importance of individual responses to caffeine, noting that factors such as genetics, overall diet, and existing health conditions can influence how caffeine affects heart health.




As research continues to unfold, the question remains: How much caffeine is too much? While definitive guidelines are still being established, moderation appears to be key. Most health professionals suggest that up to 400 milligrams of caffeine per day—roughly equivalent to four 8-ounce cups of brewed coffee—can be safe for most adults. As millions of coffee drinkers savor their favorite brews, understanding the delicate balance of caffeine consumption is essential. Ongoing studies promise to shed light on this complex relationship, paving the way for informed choices that can support heart health and overall well-being.



















National Savings Week Campaign Launched to Promote Financial Literacy and Growth.

Rwanda's Economic Growth Resilient Amid Global Challenges, Says IMF.

11:35, 2024-10-24

Rwanda's economic growth continues to demonstrate resilience despite a challenging external environment, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) team following a two-week mission to the country. The visit aimed to discuss policies, priorities, and progress on reforms as part of the fourth review of Rwanda's Policy Coordination Instrument (PCI), Resilience Sustainability Facility (RSF), and the second review of the Standby Credit Facility (SCF) arrangement.

In a statement released at the conclusion of the mission, IMF team leader Mr. Reuben Atoyan projected Rwanda's Real GDP to grow by 8.3% in 2024. This optimistic outlook is driven by robust performances in the services and construction sectors, along with a recovery in food crop production. Additionally, inflation remains stable within the central bank's target range, bolstered by tight monetary policies and favorable food price developments.




Mr. Atoyan noted that the recent 6.6% depreciation of the Rwandan Franc against the US dollar was a necessary step to facilitate essential external adjustments. He highlighted that international reserves were sufficient, standing at 4.5 months of prospective imports by mid-2024, providing a buffer against potential external shocks.

"Despite the challenging environment, macroeconomic policy performance through the end of June 2024 remained aligned with program objectives under the PCI/SCF arrangement. All quantitative targets were met, and reforms aimed at enhancing the transparency of public investments and strengthening the functioning of the foreign exchange market are progressing well," Mr. Atoyan stated.




The IMF team also emphasized the Rwandan Government's strong commitment to implementing climate-related reforms under the RSF arrangement. Initiatives for climate budget tagging, improving the climate resilience of public investments, adopting sustainability disclosure standards, and developing a green taxonomy are on track for completion in the coming weeks.

However, the IMF acknowledged that recurrent shocks in recent years have complicated the Government’s goal of rebuilding policy buffers. Fiscal consolidation has been slower than anticipated, resulting in a continued increase in the public debt-to-GDP ratio.




In response to these challenges, the Government reiterated its commitment to a prudent strategy focused on concessional financing while advancing a medium-term revenue strategy and associated compensatory measures. Efforts to strengthen oversight of state-owned enterprises, address fiscal risks, and improve corporate governance will continue to progress. Looking ahead, following the completion of the review by the IMF Executive Board in mid-December, Rwanda is set to receive US$ 95.9 million under the RSF and US$ 89.0 million under the SCF, further supporting its economic recovery and resilience initiatives.

The revelation highlights the collaborative efforts between Ugandan and Kenyan intelligence agencies in ensuring the safety of high-profile figures.




According to the Africa Confidential blog, the incident unfolded on July 19, 2019, when Ugandan intelligence received a tip-off regarding a plot to kill President Kenyatta using a suicide bomber. Acting swiftly, they alerted their Kenyan counterparts, prompting immediate security measures at the airport.

The plot involved a lone assassin who had managed to infiltrate JKIA as a casual worker just a week prior to the planned attack. Reports indicate that the individual was hired from Atbara, a city in northern Sudan, and was smuggled into Nairobi by operatives based in Kenya.




The assassin was reportedly set to position himself at the Presidential Pavilion, intending to detonate the bomb upon President Kenyatta’s arrival. Sources suggest that the resulting explosion would have had catastrophic consequences, with a lethal radius of four meters, leaving no chance of survival for anyone nearby.

Due to the threat, President Kenyatta’s departure was delayed by four hours while security teams worked to neutralize the situation. This incident underscores the ongoing challenges faced by leaders in the region and the importance of robust intelligence cooperation to prevent potential threats.




The successful intervention not only saved the lives of the Kenyattas but also showcased the effectiveness of regional intelligence collaboration in combating terrorism and ensuring the safety of prominent figures.

Kigali, Rwanda – This November, Rwanda will make history by hosting ACCES (the Music In Africa Conference For Collaborations, Exchange, and Showcases) for the first time. Scheduled for November 14th to 16th, 2024, the event promises to be a landmark occasion for the country’s creative economy, bringing together music professionals, artists, and stakeholders from Africa and beyond to celebrate and advance the continent's dynamic music sector.

Organized by the Music In Africa Foundation (MIAF) in collaboration with the Rwanda Convention Bureau (RCB) and the Ministry of Youth and Arts (MINIYOUTH), ACCES 2024 will offer a vibrant platform for both emerging and established music professionals, as well as fans eager to engage with the music community.




Event Highlights

ACCES 2024 will be structured around three main pillars, bridging the business and creative sides of the music industry:

Conference and Networking: On November 14th and 15th, from 9 AM to 5 PM, the Kigali Convention Center will host a dynamic conference focused on networking and collaboration. Attendees will include local music industry stakeholders alongside representatives from leading global and African music organizations, such as top executives, artists, funders, and promoters.




Showcase Festival: The event will feature a two-day festival showcasing over 20 live acts from across the continent. Performers will include renowned artists like Sir Trill, Heavy K, and Zaki Ibrahim from South Africa, alongside talents from Kenya, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, and beyond. A special showcase dedicated to Rwandan hip-hop will highlight the local scene, featuring the emerging group +250, which includes artists such as Bushali, Ish Kevin, and Angell Mutoni. These performances are set to take place at the Mundi Center on November 15th and 16th, from 6 PM to 1 AM.




Workshops and Capacity Building: ACCES will also offer a curated program of workshops designed to develop critical skills for both aspiring and established music industry professionals.




A key feature of ACCES 2024 will be the MIA Honorary Awards, recognizing a Rwandan music icon for their significant contributions to the country's cultural heritage. This accolade continues a tradition of honoring influential artists from across the continent, with past recipients including Baaba Maal from Senegal and Vusi Mahlasela from South Africa.

Key Details

All happening in November on the 14th & 16th, 2024 at the Kigali Convention Center: Conference, exhibitions, and professional market

Wheras the other events continue at Mundi Center: Live music showcases and networking events (November 15th and 16th, 6 PM - 1 AM)

Registration and Press Accreditation

Tickets and registrations for ACCES are available on a first-come, first-served basis. Media representatives interested in covering the event must apply for press accreditation by the deadline, which is 15 days prior to the event.

About ACCES

ACCES serves as a pan-African trade show designed for music industry players to exchange ideas, discover new talent, and foster business connections. Each year, the event takes place in a different African city, attracting participants from around the globe. The 2024 edition is organized by the Music In Africa Foundation, in partnership with the Rwanda Convention Bureau, the Ministry of Youth and Arts, Siemens Stiftung, and Goethe-Institut.

What next :Deputy President Gachagua Impeached by National Assembly.

03:41, 2024-10-14

In a significant political development, the National Assembly of Kenya voted on October 8 to impeach Deputy President Rigathi Gachagua, confirming all 11 charges brought against him. The decision came during a late-night voting session that saw a substantial majority of lawmakers rallying to support the motion.

National Assembly Speaker Moses Wetang'ula announced that a total of 281 MPs voted in favor of the impeachment, while 44 lawmakers opposed the motion.




"Article 145 (2) of the constitution sets a threshold of at least two-thirds of members of the National Assembly to be considered in support of a special motion for the proposed removal of the Deputy President," Wetang'ula stated.




He confirmed that the vote exceeded the required two-thirds majority.

The matter will now move to the Senate, where the Speaker is expected to convene a seven-day meeting to review the charges against Gachagua. This impeachment marks a historic moment, as Gachagua becomes the first deputy president to be removed under the revised 2010 constitution.




The motion for impeachment was brought forth by Kibwezi West MP Mutuse Mwengi, who accused Gachagua of unlawfully acquiring assets that were inconsistent with his declared salary and violating multiple laws, including the Proceeds of Crime and Anti-Money Laundering Act. Additionally, Gachagua faced allegations of undermining President William Ruto and the Cabinet through public statements that contradicted government policy.

Other serious accusations included potential violations of the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act, with specific sections cited in the motion. The political landscape in Kenya is poised for further developments as the Senate reviews the case against Gachagua, which could have significant implications for the current administration.

Rwanda Launches $10 Million Agricultural Biotechnology Program to Boost Crop Productivity.

03:17, 2024-10-14

Kigali, Rwanda – The Rwanda Agriculture and Animal Resources Development Board (RAB) and the African Agricultural Technology Foundation (AATF) have officially launched a five-year initiative aimed at enhancing crop productivity across the nation. The Rwanda Agricultural Biotechnology Program (Cassava, Maize, Potato – CMP), with a budget of $10 million (approximately Rwf 13 billion), is set to run from October 2024 to October 2029.

The program was unveiled on October 11, 2024, with officials highlighting its potential to provide Rwandan farmers access to high-yielding crop varieties, thus mitigating losses caused by pests and diseases. Minister of Agriculture and Animal Resources, Ildephonse Musafiri, emphasized that the program addresses the urgent challenges faced by Rwandan farmers, including the rise of fall armyworm and brown streak disease, which have significantly impacted maize and cassava production.

“This investment will enable Rwandan farmers to access and plant high-yielding crops, thereby saving the yields lost to pests and diseases," Musafiri stated. He reiterated the government's commitment to embracing innovative agricultural technologies, including biotechnology, as part of Rwanda’s strategy to improve agricultural resilience in the face of climate change and other adversities.

One significant legislative move to support this initiative is the enactment of the Biosafety Act in February 2024. This law ensures that genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are safely managed in Rwanda, creating a robust framework for the introduction of biotechnological advancements.




The CMP program specifically focuses on three key crops: cassava, maize, and potatoes.

Virus-Resistant Cassava: This strain is engineered to combat the Cassava Brown Streak Disease, a major threat to yield and quality.

Late Blight Resistant Potato: Designed to withstand late blight, this potato variant aims to reduce farmers’ reliance on expensive and environmentally harmful chemical sprays.

Drought-Tolerant Maize: This maize variety is engineered to resist stem borers and fall armyworms, providing a safeguard against significant crop losses.

These innovations are expected to significantly enhance the productivity of crops that are vital to the Rwandan diet and economy. Cassava alone is cultivated by nearly 700,000 households, serving as a crucial calorie source in rural diets.




The program builds on years of collaborative research among various partners, including the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center, the national agricultural research organization in Rwanda, and funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which has invested over $9.8 million into similar initiatives. This partnership aims to leverage existing research to expedite the introduction of these improved crop varieties to local farmers.

By fostering local scientific expertise and building the necessary biosafety infrastructure, the CMP program is set to not only introduce innovative crop varieties but also enhance Rwanda's agricultural capabilities.

Rwanda continues to position itself as a leader in agricultural biotechnology within the region, the launch of the CMP program represents a significant step towards improving food security and agricultural resilience. The government’s strategic investment in biotechnology underscores its commitment to innovative agricultural practices that promise to transform the livelihoods of Rwandan farmers and contribute to the nation's economic growth.

Brave Students Awarded Full Educational Support for Protecting Rwanda Flag.

04:22, 2024-10-11

Ruhango District, Rwanda – Six courageous children from Cyobe Primary School in Mbuye Sector have been recognized for their bravery after braving heavy rain and a windstorm to protect the national flag on October 2. The Heads of School Organization (HOSO Rwanda) announced on the evening of October 9 that these students will receive full educational support upon their transition to secondary school.




The incident unfolded when nine pupils, aged between 10 and 13, noticed that the national flag was at risk of being blown away during a fierce storm that even ripped off the school roof sheets. In a display of patriotism, six of the students rushed out from their shelter to safeguard the flag, demonstrating a commitment to their country's symbol. Sister Hellen Nayituriki, the founder of HOSO Rwanda, expressed her admiration for the students' actions.




“Seeing a primary school student trying to prevent the national flag from falling, knowing it would mean the country falling down, brought me to tears,” she said. “These children represent the hope of our nation, and that’s exactly the kind of youth we aim to nurture.”




In recognition of their bravery, the HOSO Rwanda pledged to provide the six students with full educational support, including school fees, until they complete secondary school. Additionally, all nine pupils received scholastic materials and hygiene items to assist them in their current studies.

Seth Bayiringire, vice president of HOSO Rwanda, emphasized the organization’s commitment to the students’ education. “We’ve provided them with school supplies, and six of the pupils will receive full educational support until they complete secondary school,” he stated.




Aaron Mugirwanake, headteacher of Cyobe Primary School, praised HOSO Rwanda for its generous support. “The organization has pledged to provide full educational support until the students complete their secondary school studies,” he said. “In addition, they will support the school’s feeding program for the entire term.”




Mugirwanake noted that this initiative has instilled a sense of civic engagement among students. “This means a lot to the learners, as they now understand the importance of civic engagement, starting with protecting the school’s property. It has motivated them to participate in activities, big or small, related to the country’s protection, and other schools will follow our example.” To further cultivate this spirit, the school plans to organize weekly educational activities focused on civic and cultural initiatives, fostering a deeper understanding of community responsibilities among its students.

President Kagame Begins Historic Visit to Latvia, Inaugurates Genocide Memorial.

06:09, 2024-10-04

Rwandan President Paul Kagame commenced a three-day official visit to Latvia, marking a significant milestone in diplomatic relations between Rwanda and the Baltic state. The visit began with a tour of the Museum of the Occupation of Latvia, a prominent educational institution located in the capital, Riga.




Accompanied by Latvia's President Edgars Rinkēvičs, Kagame participated in a closed-door meeting on Wednesday, followed by a joint press conference. The visit is particularly notable as it includes the inauguration of a genocide memorial at the National Library of Latvia, which symbolizes the country's commitment to preserving the memory of the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda and raising awareness about preventing future genocides.




Philbert Gakwenzire, president of Ibuka—the umbrella organization for genocide survivors' associations—hailed the memorial as a significant step toward international recognition of Rwanda's tragic past. He emphasized the importance of Latvia's initiative in commemorating the victims, stating, "This memorial will serve as a powerful reminder of the horrors of genocide and the need for global solidarity in preventing such atrocities."

This visit marks the first official trip by a Rwandan President to the Baltic States, as well as the first by an African leader to Latvia.

The memorial at the National Library, known as "The Castle of Light," will be the first dedicated to the victims of genocide in the Baltic States and Eastern Europe. Latvia, bordered by Russia and Belarus, is one of the three Baltic states, alongside Estonia and Lithuania. The country operates under a parliamentary representative democratic republic, with Prime Minister Evika Siliņa serving as head of government since September 2023. Edgars Rinkēvičs, who became President in July 2023, previously served as the long-standing foreign minister.




Kagame's visit not only strengthens diplomatic ties but also underscores the growing recognition of Rwanda's history on the global stage. As Latvia enhances its role in international efforts to honor genocide victims, this landmark visit signals a deepening commitment to memory, education, and the prevention of future atrocities.

Meet Salima Mukansanga a Pioneering African female referee who made history at the World Cup

04:38, 2024-10-04

Salima Mukansanga, an international football referee from Rwanda, has made history as the first African woman to officiate at the men’s FIFA World Cup. Born in 1988, Mukansanga has been a FIFA-listed international referee since 2012, marking a remarkable journey that began in her youth.

Initially involved in basketball, Mukansanga's foray into refereeing started when she was deemed too young to join the national under-17 basketball squad. Undeterred, she approached the Rwanda Football Federation to enroll in a refereeing course after completing secondary school, only to face initial rejection. However, her determination led her to self-study the laws of football, eventually earning a place in the course.




While pursuing her passion for officiating, Mukansanga also earned a degree in nursing and midwifery from the University of Gitwe. She began her career by officiating local amateur men’s matches and women's national second division games in Rwanda.

Mukansanga's groundbreaking achievements continued to accumulate when, in 2022, she became the first woman to referee at the African Cup of Nations, leading an all-women officiating team, including Fatiha Jermoumi (Morocco) and Carine Atemzabong (Cameroon). Her experience extends to high-profile tournaments, having officiated at the Olympics, FIFA Women’s World Cup, Africa Women Cup of Nations, and CAF Women's Champions League.




In November 2022, Mukansanga made history again as the first female African referee to officiate in a men’s World Cup match, serving as the fourth official during the match where France defeated Australia 4-1. Her contributions to the sport were recognized when she was listed among the BBC 100 Women in December 2022. Looking ahead, Mukansanga has been appointed to the officiating pool for the 2023 FIFA Women’s World Cup in Australia and New Zealand, further solidifying her role as a trailblazer for women in football.




In a recent interview, Mukansanga reflected on her journey, expressing gratitude for her achievements and the doors she hopes to open for other women in Africa. “It’s an honor and a privilege because it’s never happened before,” she told the BBC. “It means you’re going to be the first one and going to open the door for other women, especially in Africa.”




She also shared insights into the challenges of becoming a referee, stating, “I didn’t know there is a lot to do – laws to follow, a mentality to follow, professionalism inside – but I started to learn step-by-step. It was very difficult. When you are reading the laws of the game, it’s easy to understand but inside the field of play, it needs some time to have a smell for the job.”




Salima Mukansanga's groundbreaking achievements not only highlight her personal dedication and resilience but also serve as an inspiring testament to the potential for women in sports, particularly in regions where opportunities have traditionally been limited. As she continues to break barriers, Mukansanga is poised to inspire a new generation of female referees across Africa and beyond.

Careless Driving and Poor Maneuvering Major Contributors to Traffic Accidents in Rwanda.

04:51, 2024-10-02

Careless driving and improper maneuvering have been identified as leading contributors to traffic accidents in Rwanda, accounting for 50% of the approximately 3,000 reported incidents from January to August this year, according to the Rwanda National Police (RNP).




The alarming statistics were highlighted by RNP spokesperson ACP Boniface Rutikanga, who noted that motorcycles, a popular mode of transport in Rwanda, have significantly contributed to the rising number of accidents. Among the various causes cited, improper overtaking and failure to navigate sharp corners emerged as critical factors in the increase of road incidents.

"Careless driving, particularly on sharp corners and during overtaking, often leads to vehicles veering off lanes or crashing," Rutikanga stated, emphasizing the need for greater caution among drivers.




According to the RNP, 20% of the accidents reported stemmed directly from drivers failing to properly assess corners or attempting risky overtaking maneuvers. The concern over road safety has intensified, with both rural areas and the City of Kigali seeing varying patterns of accidents. Rutikanga pointed out that while fatal accidents are more common in rural regions where drivers exhibit negligence, the City of Kigali has experienced a notable number of minor accidents.




To combat the rise in traffic incidents, the RNP has implemented various measures, including the deployment of Artificial Intelligence (AI) speed enforcement cameras. These efforts have reportedly led to a significant reduction in accidents, particularly those caused by speeding and drunk driving. Despite these initiatives, improper road-user behavior continues to be a challenge. Rwanda's unique topography, coupled with a rapid increase in the number of vehicles on the roads, exacerbates the risk of accidents. Ongoing public safety campaigns, such as "Gerayo Amahoro," aim to target specific road users, including motorcyclists and pedestrians, but the persistent issues highlight the need for ongoing education and awareness.




The RNP is urging all road users to take necessary precautions, especially when approaching sharp corners, overtaking, or driving in conditions with poor visibility. Additionally, passengers are encouraged to hold drivers accountable for their actions, report unprofessional conduct, and advocate for responsible driving to enhance their safety on the roads. As Rwanda continues to work towards improving road safety, collaboration among authorities, drivers, and passengers is essential in reducing traffic accidents and ensuring safer journeys for all.

03:42, 2024-10-02

Monday marked a significant milestone in the East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP) project as Uganda received its first batch of insulated line pipes. This delivery, made by China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co. Ltd (CPP), consists of nine trucks of coated pipes transported from the Nzenga coating plant in Tanzania’s Tabora Region.

The arrival of these pipes at the main camp and pipe yard in Kyotera District signifies the developers' commitment to accelerating the construction of the cross-border pipeline, which will connect oil fields in Uganda's Albertine Basin to the Tanga port in Tanzania.




EACOP Ltd, the project’s developer, indicated that the laying of the pipeline in Uganda is expected to commence soon, as efforts intensify to export the first barrels of crude oil by the end of next year.

"The project remains on track to meet its construction and operational timelines, with a continued focus on safety, environmental sustainability, and local community engagement," EACOP Ltd stated in a release.

Ali Ssekatawa, Director of Legal and Corporate Affairs at the Petroleum Authority of Uganda (PAU), hailed the delivery as a “major landmark” in the construction of the EACOP.




“This is a clear sign of the progress of the project. The government and its partners are committed to ensuring that all developments are completed in the most environmentally responsible and sustainable manner,” he added.

Civil works along the 1,443-kilometer pipeline have already advanced, with ongoing construction at pumping stations, main camps, pipe yards, and storage facilities. To date, the project has received a total of 800 kilometers of line pipes, which are currently undergoing coating and insulation processes at the Nzega Coating Yard.




In a bid to mitigate climate change risks, the EACOP project will utilize renewable energy for all pumping, heating, monitoring, and storage operations. The 296-kilometer section in Uganda is set to be fully carbon neutral, powered entirely by an 80MW renewable energy mix of solar and hydroelectric sources. Plans are also underway to develop similar renewable energy capacities on the Tanzanian side of the project.

With an estimated budget of $5 billion, EACOP is being developed by a consortium that includes Uganda and Tanzania, each holding a 15 percent stake. French supermajor TotalEnergies holds the largest share at 62 percent, while China National Offshore Oil Corporation Uganda Limited owns the remaining 8 percent.




As the project progresses, stakeholders remain focused on balancing economic development with environmental stewardship, ensuring that the pipeline construction benefits both countries while adhering to global sustainability standards.

African Leaders Gather in Beijing for High-Stakes Summit Amidst Shifting Dynamics.

03:53, 2024-09-04

Beijing, China – September 4, 2024

Delegations from across the African continent have converged on Beijing for a pivotal three-day summit, underscoring China’s ambition to reaffirm its role as a key partner in Africa’s development despite a slowdown in lending and rising tensions with Western nations.




In recent days, African leaders have been warmly welcomed in the Chinese capital with elaborate ceremonies featuring honor guards and traditional dance troupes. The event, showcased extensively by Chinese state media, is billed as the largest diplomatic gathering hosted by China in recent years. The summit, which begins on Wednesday, marks the first major gathering of Chinese and African leaders in Beijing since 2018. It arrives at a crucial moment in the relationship between Beijing and Africa—a relationship characterized by significant Chinese investments in infrastructure and growing political influence.




Historically, China's substantial funding has driven the development of highways, railways, and power plants across Africa, positioning China as a major economic and political force on the continent. However, this influx of capital has also faced criticism for contributing to unsustainable debt levels among African nations.

Amidst these concerns and a slowing Chinese economy, Chinese President Xi Jinping and his officials are expected to promote a new strategy centered on what they describe as “small yet beautiful” investments. This approach emphasizes sustainable projects and increased collaboration on green technologies, an area where China is a global leader.




The summit provides Beijing with a high-profile opportunity to advance its vision for future cooperation with Africa, particularly as it navigates increasing friction with Western countries. Xi aims to position China as a champion of the Global South, offering an alternative to Western influence, particularly in light of escalating geopolitical tensions with the United States.




African leaders are expected to use the summit to address several pressing issues. South African President Cyril Ramaphosa has already called for China to address the trade imbalance and improve the structure of trade relations. Many attending the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation are from nations grappling with significant international debt, including substantial Chinese loans.

Leaders will likely scrutinize whether a 2021 pledge by Xi to import $300 billion worth of African products by 2025 will be met and will seek assurances that increased trade will not merely reinforce a pattern of exporting raw materials from Africa in exchange for Chinese manufactured goods.




The backdrop to the summit includes a notable decline in Chinese lending to Africa. Pre-pandemic, China had been a major source of funding for large-scale infrastructure projects. However, lending to African governments and state-linked entities dropped significantly during the pandemic, falling to approximately $1 billion in 2022 from a peak of over $28.8 billion in 2016. Although there was a modest recovery to $4.6 billion in 2023, it remains a fraction of previous levels.

African nations such as Kenya are confronting significant debt challenges. Kenyan President William Ruto, present in Beijing for the summit, is dealing with public backlash over a new finance bill aimed at managing the country’s substantial debt, which includes nearly $6 billion owed to China.




The summit is poised to be a critical juncture for China-Africa relations, with both sides facing important decisions about the future of their partnership. As African leaders pose critical questions and seek concrete assurances, the outcome of this high-profile event will likely have significant implications for both China’s role in Africa and the continent’s economic trajectory.

03:45, 2024-09-04

Kampala, Uganda – September 4, 2024

In a dramatic escalation of political tensions in Uganda, opposition leader Bobi Wine was shot in the leg by security agents during a confrontation in the northern suburb of Bulindo, Wakiso District, just outside the capital, Kampala, on Tuesday. The National Unity Platform (NUP), the political party led by Wine, reported the incident and condemned the attack.




According to NUP, the shooting occurred during a clash between Wine’s supporters and police forces. Photos circulating on social media depict Wine surrounded by followers who were shouting that he had been injured. Supporters can be seen assisting Wine into a waiting vehicle as he appeared to be in significant distress.

The party's statement on X (formerly Twitter) alleged that Ugandan security operatives “have made an attempt on the life of” Bobi Wine, whose real name is Kyagulanyi Ssentamu. The party described his injury as serious, highlighting the dangerous escalation of tensions between the opposition and the authorities.




Kyagulanyi, a former entertainer turned politician, has been a prominent figure in Ugandan politics, especially among the younger population in urban areas. He first gained national prominence in 2017 when he won a seat in the national assembly, and he ran for president in the 2021 elections. Kyagulanyi alleged that the elections were marred by widespread rigging and fraud, which led to President Yoweri Museveni’s continued rule.

The confrontation on Tuesday is notable for being the first time Kyagulanyi has been wounded in such a violent encounter. Historically, clashes between his supporters and police have often turned violent, but this incident marks a new level of aggression.




As of now, there has been no official response from the police or other government authorities regarding the shooting. The lack of immediate comment has fueled further speculation and concern about the state of political freedom and human rights in Uganda.

President Yoweri Museveni, who has been in power since 1986, has faced increasing scrutiny both domestically and internationally. His administration has been criticized for its handling of opposition figures and civil liberties. Despite being a key ally of the United States in regional security matters, Museveni's extended rule and recent constitutional amendments—such as removing the age limit for presidents—have drawn significant criticism.




Uganda has struggled with peaceful transitions of power since gaining independence from Britain in 1962. The ongoing political unrest and violent confrontations reflect deep-seated issues within the country's political landscape.

Kigali Unveils Ambitious Five-Year Strategic Development Plan

03:37, 2024-09-04

Kigali, Rwanda – September 4, 2024

In a significant move towards urban development and environmental sustainability, the city of Kigali has announced its strategic plan for the next five years, marking a transformative phase for Rwanda's capital. The plan, unveiled at the Kigali City Headquarters, promises an array of projects aimed at expanding infrastructure, enhancing green spaces, and improving the quality of life for residents.




Infrastructure Expansion and Road Development

Central to the strategic plan is a comprehensive expansion of Kigali’s road network. The city intends to extend 25 kilometers of existing roads and introduce dedicated bus lanes to streamline public transportation. Additionally, 100 kilometers of new roads will be constructed to ease congestion and facilitate smoother travel throughout the city. These upgrades are designed to align with the Kigali City Master Plan, which envisions a more connected and efficient urban environment.




Swamp Redevelopment for Economic and Recreational Use

One of the most ambitious components of the plan involves the redevelopment of five major swamp areas. These swamps will be transformed into economic and recreational zones, potentially generating income for former inhabitants and the broader community. Kigali’s Mayor, Samuel Dusengiyumva, highlighted the environmental significance of this initiative. “We intend to increase our efforts to make Kigali a green city,” he stated. “These projects will not only make Kigali more sustainable but will also create habitable spaces with water recreational areas that can boost our tourism industry.”




Kinyinya Green Project and Slum Redevelopment

The Kinyinya Green Project is another cornerstone of the plan. This initiative will see the creation of a new eco-village designed to house approximately 250,000 people in its first phase. The development aims to set a benchmark for sustainable urban living. In parallel, a World Bank and French government-funded project will address slum conditions in areas such as Kagugu and Nyamirambo. The Slum Aid Project focuses on the redevelopment and re-planning of these neighborhoods, reflecting Kigali’s commitment to improving living conditions and infrastructure across the city.




Renovation of Nyabugogo Bus Terminal

The renovation of Nyabugogo, Kigali’s main bus terminal, is also a key project in the strategic plan. Vice Mayor Fulgence Dusabimana, in charge of Housing and Infrastructure, emphasized the necessity of updating the terminal. “This project has been long overdue,” he remarked. “The terminal was initially designed for a limited number of buses, but it has now become an international hub serving regional routes.”




Electric Charging Ports and Green Initiatives

As Kigali moves towards lower carbon emissions, the strategic plan includes the installation of electric vehicle charging ports throughout the city and its suburbs. This infrastructure will support the city’s broader goals of sustainability and innovation in transportation.

With these initiatives, Kigali is poised to enhance its infrastructure, foster economic growth, and promote environmental stewardship, setting a forward-thinking example for urban development in Africa.

Volkswagen, Seeking to Cut Costs, Considers German Plant Closures.

05:13, 2024-09-03

Volkswagen warned on Monday that it would consider closing factories in Germany for the first time in its 87-year history and end a decades-old guarantee of job security for workers, as it faces profitability problems amid increasing pressure from Asian competitors.




The company said in a statement that the measures were meant to shore up its namesake brand, but it declined to provide any details.

“In the current situation, even plant closures at vehicle production and component sites can no longer be ruled out without swift countermeasures,” the company said. “The situation is extremely tense and cannot be resolved through simple cost-cutting measures.”




IG Metall, the powerful union that represents German automotive workers, responded by saying it would fight any job cuts. It added that Volkswagen managers had told it that a cost-cutting plan announced last year was not working and that additional savings worth “billions” were needed. Volkswagen declined to confirm that number. Last year, Volkswagen and worker representatives agreed to measures that would save the company 10 billion euros, or $11 billion, by 2026. But those plans, which included job cuts largely based on attrition, are no longer enough, the company said on Monday2 September




“The European automotive industry is in a very demanding and serious situation,” Oliver Blume, chief executive of Volkswagen, said in a statement. “Germany in particular as a manufacturing location is falling further behind in terms of competitiveness. In this environment, we as a company must now act decisively.”




The automaker owns 10 brands, including Audi, Porsche and Lamborghini, but its flagship brand remains core to its identity and that of Germany’s storied history as an automobile nation. But Volkswagen has faced falling sales, amid decreased demand in Europe, especially for its electric vehicles. Volkswagen’s share of the Chinese market, its largest market, has shrunk as fast-moving domestic rivals roll out affordable electric cars. Despite plans by the European Union to introduce tariffs on imports of electric cars from China, those competitors are starting to expand into Europe.




The German economy, Europe’s largest, contracted in the months from April to June, shrinking 0.1 percent from a year earlier. The latest figures dampened hopes that the country might be pulling out of stagnation, which analysts say is driven by high energy and labor costs.




Shutdowns of Volkswagen’s German factories would be a first for the company, which was founded in Wolfsburg in 1937. But closing plants, as well as ending the agreement that provides workers with job guarantees through 2029, will face stiff opposition from union leaders and workers’ representatives, who hold half the seats on the company’s supervisory board. Daniela Cavallo, a union leader and the head of the council representing Volkswagen workers, blamed company management for failing to develop a competent strategy and instead seeking to save by cutting jobs.




“We will fiercely defend ourselves against this,” Ms. Cavallo said in a statement. “There will be no plant closures with us.”

Clashes with unions have cost several chief executives at Volkswagen their jobs. Already the unions are gearing up for wage negotiations that are set to begin this fall. Nearly half of Volkswagen’s 650,000 workers around the globe are in Germany.

“The company — and the VW brand — are in a very dangerous situation,” said Ferdinand Dudenhöffer, director of the Center for Automotive Research in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.

RwandAir Plans Fleet Expansion Amid Record Revenue Growth.

04:19, 2024-09-03

RwandAir has announced an ambitious plan to double its current fleet of 12 aircraft within the next five years, aiming to sustain the significant revenue growth the airline achieved in 2023. The announcement comes as the airline builds on a remarkable 82% increase in total revenues, rising from Rwf341 billion in 2022 to Rwf620.6 billion in 2023.




The news was detailed in the Rwanda Fiscal Risk Statement (FRS) for the financial year 2024/25, which highlights the airline's strategic efforts to mitigate fiscal risks by boosting its revenue streams. This growth trajectory follows a challenging period marked by a revenue dip due to the Covid-19 pandemic, which saw figures fall from Rwf334 billion in 2019 to Rwf271 billion in 2021.

RwandAir CEO Yvonne Manzi Makolo attributed the airline’s resurgence to several key factors: the burgeoning tourism sector in Rwanda, substantial investments in cargo services, and the expansion of the Kigali hub. “Since the pandemic, we have experienced an exceptional level of growth,” Makolo said.




“IATA projections indicate that air travel demand will triple in the next 20 years. We are positioning ourselves to capitalize on this opportunity.”




The airline has played a crucial role in boosting Rwanda’s tourism industry. In 2023, the country welcomed over 1.4 million tourists, nearly three times the number from 2021. Kigali has also emerged as a prominent destination for conferences, ranking second in Africa only after Cape Town. “Our extensive network and successful European and Middle Eastern routes have been pivotal in driving this tourism growth,” Makolo noted.

RwandAir’s cargo operations have also become a significant revenue driver. The airline recently introduced new cargo routes to Dubai and Djibouti and plans to add more as it receives additional aircraft. “Our cargo growth aligns with Rwanda’s strategy to enhance trade and connectivity. We are now able to deliver fresh produce to various international markets and import critical goods,” Makolo explained.




The Kigali hub has evolved into a major regional base, with over 60% of traffic coming from transit passengers. RwandAir has responded by increasing its European flight frequencies, including daily flights from London starting in May 2024. “Our goal is to solidify our position as a major African hub, enhancing connectivity across the continent,” Makolo said. RwandAir’s current fleet includes four Boeing 737-800NGs, two Boeing 737-700NGs, two CRJ900NGs, two Bombardier Q-400NGs, and two Airbus A330s, all in dual-class or triple-class configurations. Looking forward, the airline plans to expand its route network and explore new markets to drive growth across Africa.




“As we continue to grow, we are committed to improving travel, tourism, and trade. Our expanding fleet and network will support this vision, offering more convenient connections for both short- and long-haul journeys,” Makolo concluded.

This strategic expansion underscores RwandAir’s dedication to becoming a leading African airline and a key player in the global aviation market.

Namibia to hunt 723 Wild Animals Amid Severe Drought

04:13, 2024-08-29

Namibia has announced plans to cull 723 wild animals, including 83 elephants, in response to severe drought conditions affecting southern Africa. The cull aims to manage wildlife populations in areas where grazing land and water resources are insufficient and to provide meat to those struggling with food insecurity.




According to a statement from the Environment Ministry issued on Monday, the cull will target both national parks and communal areas. The decision comes as Namibia grapples with one of the worst droughts in decades, having depleted 84 percent of its food reserves last month, as reported by the United Nations. The ministry highlighted that nearly half of Namibia's population is projected to face severe food insecurity in the coming months. With human-wildlife conflicts likely to escalate if left unchecked, the authorities have determined that culling is necessary to mitigate these conflicts. The meat from the culled animals will be distributed through a drought relief program.




In addition to the 83 elephants, the cull will include 30 hippos, 60 buffalo, 50 impalas, 100 blue wildebeests, 300 zebras, and 100 elands. Professional hunters and contracted companies have already culled 157 animals, producing over 56,800 kilograms of meat.




"This action is essential and aligns with our constitutional mandate to utilize our natural resources for the benefit of Namibian citizens," the Environment Ministry stated.

Southern Africa is home to one of the world’s largest elephant populations, with an estimated 200,000 elephants spread across Zimbabwe, Zambia, Botswana, Angola, and Namibia.

New Legislation Aims to Enhance Accountability and Prevent Mismanagement in IBIMINA

03:53, 2024-08-29

The newly enacted ministerial order governing tontines, commonly referred to as ibimina, is expected to usher in a new era of accountability and oversight for these popular community-based financial schemes. The order, which took effect on August 21, 2024, introduces a range of regulations designed to curb financial mismanagement and enhance the security of members' contributions.




The order mandates that all tontines must be registered with the relevant sector administration. Registration can be completed online or through the submission of required documents to the sector administration, with no associated fees. This step aims to bring greater transparency and structure to tontines, which are collective savings and lending schemes where individuals contribute funds and extend loans based on mutually agreed terms.




Jean Paul Ibambe, a lawyer and expert on financial regulations, praised the new legislation as a significant advancement in protecting tontine members' investments. “The promulgation of this Ministerial Order is a positive development for the security of funds contributed by tontine members,” Ibambe stated. He noted that the lack of a legal framework and legal personality for tontines had previously led to numerous issues, including fraudulent activities and the inability to seek legal redress.




The new order allows tontines to acquire legal personality upon registration, granting them the capacity to engage in legal actions, such as suing for default. This development addresses a major gap in the previous system, where members were often left powerless in the face of financial misconduct.

In addition to legal recognition, the regulation permits tontines to establish and adopt their own procedural rules. The decentralization of the registration process further simplifies compliance for tontine members, making it more accessible.

Ibambe highlighted the importance of these changes by recounting a personal experience. “I was once part of a tontine where the leader absconded with funds. We were unable to pursue legal action due to the lack of legal personality. I am confident that this new order will prevent similar scenarios and offer recourse for affected members.”




Under the new legislation, sector administrations are tasked with providing guidance and facilitating compliance for registered tontines. They will also oversee adherence to the tontines’ rules of procedure. Additionally, the Ministry of Finance will oversee the promotion and regulation of tontines through its Department of Financial Sector Development.

The introduction of these regulations marks a significant shift towards greater accountability in community-based financial schemes, aiming to foster trust and stability in tontines across the region.

Kenzo’s appointment marks a significant step for Uganda's creative industry, which has long felt overlooked by the government. The move is seen as an opportunity to bring more attention and support to the sector, potentially leading to substantial growth and development.

Kenzo, known for his international hits and contributions to the Ugandan music scene, is expected to use his influence and experience to advocate for the needs and interests of creatives in Uganda. His leadership in the Musicians Federation has already highlighted his commitment to advancing the industry, and this new role provides a broader platform to enact change.




Following the announcement, Kenzo’s partner, Phiona Nyamutoro, who serves as the Minister of State for Energy and Mineral Development, took to social media to express her pride and support.




"Congratulations on your well-deserved appointment

@eddykenzoofficial, proud of you always. Thank you H.E @KagutaMuseveni," Nyamutoro posted on her X (formerly Twitter) handle on Wednesday night, August 21.




Kenzo’s new position is being celebrated across Uganda’s creative community, with many hoping that his appointment will lead to increased government support and investment in the arts. As he steps into this influential role, the creative industry looks forward to what promises to be a transformative period under his guidance.

Challenges Loom for BRICS+ Reserve Currency as India Cautions on Feasibility

07:44, 2024-08-22

Creating a BRICS+ reserve currency is proving to be a daunting task, with Indian External Affairs Minister, Dr. Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, underscoring the substantial challenges involved. Speaking to journalists in New Delhi, Dr. Jaishankar highlighted the complexity of aligning the diverse fiscal and monetary policies of the bloc's member states, emphasizing that such an initiative would require considerable groundwork and alignment across multiple domains.







Dr. Jaishankar pointed out that, at present, the emphasis within the BRICS+ bloc is more on settling payments using each member's national currency rather than pursuing a new, unified currency. "BRICS members have their particular currencies, so, many of them say, why do I need a third currency to settle between us? Which is completely understandable. Sometimes it's a liquidity issue, sometimes it’s a trust issue," he explained during a briefing to journalists from the Indo-Pacific region.

The idea of a BRICS currency has been floated within the bloc, which consists of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, with the recent addition of Saudi Arabia, Iran, Egypt, Ethiopia, and the United Arab Emirates. However, Dr. Jaishankar was clear about the significant hurdles in establishing such a currency. "For countries to have a common currency, you need enormous alignment of their very fundamental fiscal policies, monetary policies, economic policies… And when you look at BRICS’s standards, I think we’ve to be realistic about the extent of alignment among members."




The diversity of the BRICS+ nations poses a significant challenge to the creation of a unified reserve currency. Each country within the bloc has distinct economic frameworks, priorities, and policies that complicate efforts to achieve the necessary alignment. This sentiment is echoed by experts who question the practicality of a BRICS currency as a viable alternative to the U.S. dollar.

Richard J. Grant, a professor of finance and economics at Cumberland University, Tennessee, and an analyst for the Free Market Foundation, elaborated on these concerns in a recent paper. "Certainly, each of the member countries has an interest in maintaining and spreading the reach of its national currency," Grant observed. He emphasized that each currency within the bloc serves multiple roles—as a domestic unit of account, medium of exchange, policy instrument, and a source of government revenue through seigniorage.

Grant also noted that those advocating for an alternative currency within BRICS+ are, in reality, pushing for broader international acceptance of their national currencies rather than the creation of a wholly new currency.




In the lead-up to the BRICS summit held in South Africa in August 2023, India's Foreign Secretary Vinay Mohan reiterated the bloc’s current approach, stating that discussions have primarily focused on increasing trade in national currencies rather than on establishing a common currency. This approach reflects the practical challenges that lie ahead in developing a BRICS reserve currency.

Key issues complicating the development of a BRICS currency include the availability and liquidity of the currency, the risk of exchange rate fluctuations, the adequacy of banking infrastructure, and the level of international acceptance such a currency would require.




BRICS+ bloc continues to explore its options for economic cooperation and integration, the idea of a reserve currency remains an aspirational goal rather than an imminent reality. The intricate balance of national interests, economic strategies, and practical considerations suggests that the creation of a BRICS+ currency, while theoretically intriguing, is fraught with significant challenges that may take years, if not decades, to overcome. For now, the bloc seems poised to continue its focus on enhancing trade through the use of national currencies, a path that offers a more immediate and manageable means of fostering economic ties within the group.

Rwanda's Meat Production Nears Target as Strategic Investments Pay Off

07:38, 2024-08-22

Rwanda's ambitious target of producing 215,000 tonnes of meat annually, set in the 2018-2024 strategic plan for agriculture transformation, has been nearly achieved. The Rwanda Agriculture and Animal Resources Development Board (RAB) recently announced that the country reached 91% of this goal in 2023, producing 197,778 metric tons of meat during the 2022/23 fiscal year.

This achievement highlights the steady progress Rwanda has made in the agricultural sector, particularly in meat production. Solange Uwituze, the Deputy Director General of RAB, emphasized the significance of this milestone:

“The current data on meat production indicates that during 2022/23 the country has produced 197,778 metric tons of meat, representing 91% of the set target.”




Meat Production Breakdown

The composition of Rwanda's meat production in 2022/23 reveals a diverse livestock sector. Beef dominated the market, accounting for 35% of the total meat produced, followed by chicken at 22% and goat at 19%. Pork contributed 14%, while rabbit and lamb production accounted for six and five percent, respectively. These figures reflect a balanced and varied meat production industry, catering to different consumer preferences.




Economic Impact

The financial impact of Rwanda's growing meat production sector is evident in the country’s export earnings. According to the National Agricultural Export Development Board, meat exports brought in $22.3 million in the 2022/23 fiscal year, a significant increase from $8.8 million in the previous year. This surge in export revenue underscores the sector's growing importance to Rwanda's economy.




Strategic Investments and Challenges

Rwanda's success in meat production can be attributed to several strategic investments made by the government. These include enhancing the availability of vaccines and drugs for animals, increasing the capacity of hatcheries to produce day-old chicks, and establishing pig breeding centers. To support small livestock farmers, the government has also subsidized access to finance, offering loans at an attractive eight percent interest rate.

However, challenges remain. Uwituze pointed out that a limited number of farmers are engaged in professional beef production, which is essential for scaling up the sector. Another significant challenge is the competition between human and animal nutrition for the same raw materials, primarily maize and soya. This competition limits the availability of animal feeds, a crucial component for increasing meat production.




Looking Ahead

To address these challenges, the government is encouraging investment in professional beef farming. This includes training programs aimed at educating farmers on modern techniques such as breed selection, animal husbandry, and sustainable farming practices. Additionally, farmers are being encouraged to form cooperatives to pool resources and share knowledge, which can lead to better production outcomes.

To combat the issue of limited animal feeds, Rwanda is actively working to increase agricultural productivity, particularly in maize and soya production. The government is also exploring alternative feed sources that do not compete with human food, such as crop residues and agro-industrial by-products.




With Rwanda moving towards finalizing the next strategic plan for agriculture, which will include a new target for meat production, the country is well-positioned to build on its successes. The continued focus on innovation, investment, and sustainable practices will be key to achieving and surpassing future goals, ensuring that Rwanda's meat production sector remains a vital part of its economic growth.

A Cry for Equality: The Struggle of Persons with Disabilities in Rwanda's Public Transport System,

07:23, 2024-08-22

In the heart of Rwanda, where the spirit of resilience and community thrives, there is a quiet but powerful plea echoing from those whose voices are often drowned out in the hustle and bustle of daily life. The National Council for Persons with Disabilities (NCPD) has renewed its urgent call for public transport operators to make critical adjustments to their vehicles, ensuring that all passengers, regardless of their physical abilities, can travel with dignity and ease.




For many, boarding a bus is a simple, almost thoughtless action—a routine part of the day. But for people with disabilities, this everyday task can become an insurmountable challenge. Emmanuel Ndayisaba, the Executive Secretary of NCPD, speaks with a deep sense of responsibility: "We assess whether the available vehicles facilitate persons with disabilities, especially those traveling to districts outside Kigali. Priority should be given to assisting persons with disabilities before anyone else."

Ndayisaba’s words resonate strongly within the community of persons with disabilities. They know all too well the reality of what it means to struggle to board a bus, often relying on the kindness of strangers or the strength of fellow passengers. This struggle is most pronounced outside Kigali, where the few accessible buses in the city stand in stark contrast to the difficulties faced in the provinces.

Donatille Kanimba, the Executive Director of the Rwanda National Union of the Blind (RNUB), voices a concern shared by many: "The lack of accessible buses equipped with ramps or lifts exacerbates this problem, making independent travel a daunting task." Kanimba’s words cut to the heart of the matter—independence is something that many take for granted, but for persons with disabilities, it is a hard-won victory that can be easily snatched away by an unforgiving transport system.




The challenges extend beyond physical barriers. For those with visual impairments, the absence of bus conductors who once called out the arrival of buses has created a new layer of difficulty. "Without conductors, visually impaired passengers must rely on bystanders to alert them of an approaching bus. However, this is not always the case, and it leaves many unsure of when to board," Kanimba explains. The uncertainty, the anxiety of missing a bus or being left behind, is a heavy burden to bear.




Agnes Umutoni, a woman with a visual impairment, speaks with a quiet strength about the vulnerability she and others face. "Visually impaired passengers, in particular, are often targeted by pickpockets or would unknowingly receive incorrect change from dishonest conductors." The introduction of Tap and Go cards has been a welcome relief, but it does not solve all the problems. Umutoni also raises the issue of seating arrangements, noting that not all disabilities are visible. "Ensuring that people with disabilities are considered in seating arrangements, even when their disabilities are not immediately apparent, is vital for a truly inclusive public transport system."




David Gatete, a man with a physical disability, reflects on the progress that has been made in making public buildings more accessible. "As they have managed to establish accessible pathways for persons with disabilities in public buildings, similar efforts should be applied to public buses." Gatete’s words are a call to action, a reminder that true inclusion is not achieved with half measures.

The City of Kigali has made strides in ensuring that only transport companies with wheelchair-accessible buses are allowed to operate. Emma Claudine Ntirenganya, the city's director of communications and education, assures that more inclusive buses will be introduced in other regions. But for many, the pace of change is painfully slow. The need for accessible transport is not a matter of convenience—it is a matter of dignity, of human rights.




As the nation looks to the future, there is hope that these calls for action will not go unanswered. The voices of persons with disabilities, like a persistent drumbeat, remind us that until every person can move freely and independently, our work is not yet done. The journey toward equality is long, but it is one that must be traveled together.

Kenyan Aviation workers to hit the road in protest of the Adani deal.

05:08, 2024-08-13

Kenya's main aviation union said it would call a strike from next Monday over a proposed deal with an Indian company to develop the country's biggest airport – industrial action that could cause major disruption in the East African travel hub.

The Kenya Aviation Workers Union, which represents airport workers, said the proposed agreement announced last month with India's Adani Airport Holdings would lead to job losses and bring in non-Kenyan workers.

It called on the government to scrap what it referred to as the "unlawful intended sale of JKIA (Jomo Kenyatta International Airport) Adani Airport Holdings of India" in a seven-day strike notice issued on Monday.

Kenya's government has said the airport is not for sale and that no decision had been made on whether to proceed with what it called a proposed public-private partnership to upgrade the hub.

An Adani Group spokesperson could not immediately be reached for comment.

Any walkout could also cause significant disruption to national carrier Kenya Airways.

Advertisement

"We shall reconsider our intention to engage in industrial action ... only if the Adani Airport Holdings Limited's deal is abandoned in its entirety," Kenya Aviation Workers Union Secretary General Moss Ndiema said in the strike notice.

He repeated a call for the entire board of the Kenya Airports Authority (KAA) to resign.

The KAA confirmed on Monday that it had received a strike notice.

"We are hopeful that a resolution can be reached through negotiation," spokesperson Elijah Miano said.

The authority has said Adani would add a second runway at JKIA and upgrade the passenger terminal.

Kenya Airways CEO Allan Kilavuka did not respond to a request for comment.

The government said in a statement on the Adani proposal last month that JKIA was stretched beyond its capacity of 7.5 million passengers a year and in urgent need of improvements, citing incidents like leaking roofs which it said had caused "international embarrassment".

The statement said modernising JKIA could cost $2 billion, which the government was "constrained to fund due to the current tight fiscal situation".

It said Adani’s offer was currently being reviewed. If a deal is agreed, the government said there would be safeguards to ensure Kenya's national interests are protected.

A nationwide youth-led protest movement that emerged in June over proposed tax hikes has also criticised a perceived lack of transparency over the proposed Adani deal.

Last month police blocked protesters from accessing JKIA, which they had aimed to shut down.




Ethiopia's flag courier Signs Agreement for Africa's Largest Airport, Set for Completion in 2029

04:27, 2024-08-12

Ethiopia has officially signed an agreement for the design of what will become Africa's largest airport upon its completion in 2029. The ambitious project, located near the town of Bishoftu, approximately 45 kilometers southeast of the capital Addis Ababa, is set to revolutionize air travel on the continent.

The new airport will boast four runways and a capacity to handle 100 million passengers annually, with parking facilities for 270 aircraft. This marks a significant expansion from the current Bole Addis Ababa International Airport, which serves as the main hub for Ethiopian Airlines, Africa's largest airline by fleet size and passenger numbers.




Mesfin Tasew, CEO of Ethiopian Airlines, announced the project at a news conference on Friday, highlighting the necessity for a new airport as Bole International nears its maximum capacity of 25 million passengers per year. "It is a five-year project that will be finalized in 2029. It will be the biggest in Africa," Tasew stated. The design contract has been awarded to Sidara, a Dubai-based engineering and consulting firm. Tariq Al Qanni, the company's director of operations, expressed confidence in the project's successful execution, noting that it will set a new benchmark for airport infrastructure in Africa.




The plans for this new airport were first unveiled in 2018, as part of Ethiopia's broader vision to enhance its transportation infrastructure and bolster its position as a key aviation hub. Mesfin disclosed that phase one of the project is expected to cost at least $6 billion, with financing secured through loans and commitments from interested companies.

Ethiopian Airlines continues to experience rapid growth, having carried 17 million passengers during the 2023/2024 financial year. The airline anticipates an increase to 20 million passengers in the current financial year, which began in July. The new airport is expected to play a pivotal role in accommodating this growth and further establishing Ethiopia as a central player in global aviation.




As construction begins, Ethiopia’s new airport is poised to become a symbol of the country's economic progress and a major gateway for international travel in Africa.

Rwanda and Italy Forge Partnership with 50-Million-Euro Climate Financing Agreement

21:47, 2024-07-30

In a significant stride towards bolstering climate resilience and sustainable development, the Governments of Rwanda and Italy have officially signed a 50-million-euro financing agreement. This collaborative initiative, represented respectively by Rwanda's Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning and Italy's Ministry of Environment and Energy Security, is facilitated through the Italian Climate Fund and managed by Cassa Depositi e Prestiti (CDP).




This agreement forms a crucial part of the Italian Mattei Plan’s energy security strategy towards Africa. The primary objective is to support Rwanda’s National Climate Action Plan, which aims to enhance the country’s resilience and adaptive capacity in response to global warming. The financial resources provided will be contingent on the successful implementation of a series of policy and institutional reforms. These reforms are designed to integrate climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies into Rwanda's policy and regulatory frameworks, essential for achieving the national targets for carbon emission reduction.




Yusuf Murangwa, Rwanda's Minister of Finance and Economic Planning, highlighted the importance of this agreement, stating, “Rwanda has placed climate action at the core of its development agenda, as evidenced by our National Determined Contributions (NDCs). To effectively implement the mitigation and adaptation measures outlined in the NDCs, financial, capacity building and technology transfer are essential. Therefore, the agreement we have signed today will significantly contribute to this endeavor, estimated at US$ 11 billion.”

Echoing this sentiment, Gilberto Pichetto, Italy's Minister of Environment and Energy Security, emphasized Italy’s commitment to fostering growth on the African continent through climate initiatives. “Italy, through the Climate Fund, continues its efforts to create the best conditions for growth on the African continent. With Rwanda, we will invest in planning, which is necessary to address the major climate issues affecting that region,” Pichetto stated.




This financing agreement is part of a larger partnership involving a consortium of multilateral and bilateral financing institutions. Notably, it aligns with the framework of the Resilience and Sustainability Facility (RSF) agreement worth approximately USD 319 million, previously signed by the Government of Rwanda with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in 2022. Additionally, other key partners in this broader initiative include the World Bank Group, the European Union (EU), the European Investment Bank (EIB), and various European development financing institutions through the Team Europe Initiative, among others.




The collaboration between Rwanda and Italy marks a significant step forward in addressing climate change impacts and fostering sustainable development. By integrating climate resilience into national policies and leveraging international support, Rwanda is poised to make substantial progress towards its climate goals, benefiting both its environment and its people. This agreement not only underscores the importance of international cooperation in tackling global challenges but also highlights the role of financial support and policy reforms in driving meaningful change.

Kagame gives a deep insight on the reflection of Rwanda's Liberation Struggle..
