President Paul Kagame shared an in-depth recount of Rwanda’s liberation struggle on Tuesday, emphasizing the challenges and resilience required to achieve victory. Speaking at the National Liberation Museum Park in Mulindi, Gicumbi District, Kagame highlighted the significant difficulties faced during the liberation and the unwavering commitment that led to success.




President Kagame, who led the military wing of the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) Inkotanyi, spoke to content creators about the complexities of the struggle that ultimately ended the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi. He emphasized that despite understanding the magnitude of the task, the struggle proved to be even harder than anticipated. “We understood its magnitude and the weight of the work we had, but it turned to be much harder than we thought it would,” Kagame remarked




Kagame recounted the early days of the struggle, noting that the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) soldiers never underestimated the battle ahead. The engagement took place at Mulindi, the site that served as the political and military headquarters for the largest part of the four-year liberation struggle.

An internet image of Kagame (center) and the RPF Inkotanyi combatants




During the interactive session, Kagame shared a personal anecdote about his time at the US-based military college of Fort Leavenworth in 1990. Initially, the late Maj Gen Fred Rwigema had been nominated for the Command and General Staff Course. However, Kagame offered to take the course to avoid disrupting the ongoing preparations for the liberation struggle, which they had started while serving in Uganda’s National Resistance Army (NRA).

Kagame explained that Rwigema was leading efforts to mobilize Rwandans for the liberation struggle after peaceful means had failed. At that time, several senior officers of Rwandan origin in the NRA were set to be dispatched for training in different countries. Kagame had a suspicion that their covert plans to mobilize Rwandans to return home had been discovered by the authorities in their host country.




He suggested Rwigema stay and continue their efforts, while Kagame would find his way back when the struggle began. Tragically, Rwigema died on the second day of the struggle’s launch, prompting Kagame to cut short his training in the US and return to lead the movement.

Rwanda recently marked the 30th anniversary of liberation (Kwibohora 30) on July 4. This annual ceremony celebrates the bravery and selflessness of the men and women of the RPF-Inkotanyi, under President Kagame’s leadership, who liberated Rwanda and halted the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi.

The Hub will catalyze efforts to propel the Continent towards a more globalized way of doing business,” he stated. Timbuktoo represents a bold partnership between UNDP, African governments, and the private sector, positioning itself as the world's largest initiative supporting Africa's innovation ecosystem. It stands as a transformative force and a powerful example of public-private collaboration, poised to reshape the landscape of financial technology and development across Africa.

The launch of the hub signifies a significant milestone in the journey towards a more innovative and financially inclusive continent. By nurturing local talents and fostering cross-border collaborations, the Timbuktoo Fintech Hub is set to play a pivotal role in shaping the future of financial technology in Africa. This initiative reflects UNDP's commitment to harnessing technology for sustainable development.




“Africa is the place where ideas come from to unite the world. Our innovators are finding solutions to the most pressing global problems. Timbuktoo is about changing the way development works and investing in young talents. I invite you all to join and begin to see Africa from the lens of opportunity," mentioned Ms. Ahunna Eziakonwa, UN Assistant Secretary-General and UNDP Regional Director for Africa, during the launch event.

The ceremony brought together key stakeholders—fintech entrepreneurs, investors, regulators, government officials, development partners, and industry experts—to celebrate the hub's potential to transform technological innovations in the financial services landscape for sustainable development in Africa.




Following the launch, the first Pan-African Cohort of Fintech Startups was onboarded, and a Fintech for Development Marketplace was held. The marketplace showcased innovative financial technologies with the potential to drive economic growth and transformation. It also featured networking sessions, policy dialogues, and fireside chats with key ecosystem stakeholders, creating a platform for collaboration and knowledge exchange in the African fintech sector. The launch of this Fintech Hub marks the beginning of a new era for financial technology in Africa, promising to be a cornerstone for future innovations and development across the continent.

Somalia Pays Full EAC Budget Contribution for 2024/25, Ahead of DR Congo.

10:56, 2024-07-07

In a notable development for regional cooperation, Somalia has paid its full budget contribution of $7.8 million for the financial year 2024/25 to the East African Community (EAC). This timely contribution highlights Somalia's commitment to regional integration and contrasts with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DR Congo), which joined the EAC two years ago and has yet to contribute any funds, according to a report by The EastAfrican.

Last month, President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud’s government transferred $7,853,071, just before the EAC budget was presented to the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA). This significant contribution underscores Somalia's dedication to fulfilling its obligations within the regional bloc.

"The joining of Somalia places additional responsibilities and obligations on the EAC Organs and Institutions,” remarked East African Legislative Assembly MP Kennedy Mukulia during his presentation of the Committee General Purposes report. “Whereas the budget of the Community may seem to have increased, it should be noted that this increase is largely attributed to the contribution of $7,853,071 from Somalia.”




As of June 2024, DR Congo owed the EAC $14.7 million, Burundi $11.2 million, and South Sudan $8.6 million in budget contributions. Kenya had paid its full contributions, while other EAC partner states had minimal arrears, with Rwanda owing $920,869, Uganda $200,203, and Tanzania $122,694.

“There is an urgent need for disbursement of the outstanding contributions for FY 2023/2024, as well as arrears, to facilitate the activities of the financial year ending on 30th June 2024,” Mukulia emphasized.

Somalia recently reaffirmed its commitment to integrating into the EAC, demonstrating strong participation in a pivotal regional meeting held last month in Nairobi. This proactive approach by Somalia sets a positive precedent for other member states and reinforces the importance of mutual financial support within the community.




This full payment by Somalia not only strengthens its standing within the EAC but also highlights the need for all member states to meet their financial commitments to ensure the smooth functioning and continued development of the regional bloc.

16:10, 2024-06-11

Recently, Ntare School showcased its state-of-the-art facilities by hosting the national football team at its football stadium for World Cup qualifier training sessions. This comes at a pivotal time as Ntare School Rwanda, located in Nyamata, Bugesera District, begins accepting applications for its first intake, set to commence in September. The school recently opened its doors for a special event, inviting parents and guardians to explore the campus and understand its offerings before the official launch.




During the open house, families toured the campus, while children enjoyed activities such as swimming and other games. This allowed parents to interact and gain insights into the school’s ethos and infrastructure. “We have never had an event where we opened up the campus to parents and children, and families, to visit as potential candidates for our school and also partake in activities like swimming and soccer which we have availed today to incite cheer at our state-of-the-art campus in a natural setting,” said Damien Paul Vassallo, the head of the school. “I have never actually seen young people playing, having fun, and exploring the campus. Today, for the first time, Ntare Louisenlund School felt like a learning community.”

Charles Kamuru, a university lecturer and NSOBA member, emphasized the founders' vision to integrate cultural heritage with academic excellence and robust extracurricular activities. “When the idea of establishing the school was developed, the founders made sure to preserve cultural heritage, academic excellence, and extracurricular activities,” Kamuru explained. He noted that the school is non-denominational and inclusive of all regions, while emphasizing adherence to Rwandan cultural values. “




We have a Rwandan culture that every learner must adhere to. Learners will participate in proper sanitation of the school and we won’t entertain bullying,” Manzi stated. He also mentioned the formation of a debate club aimed at enhancing communication skills, confidence, critical thinking, and teamwork among students. “Learners ought to be competitive. During our time in Ntare School back in Uganda, we were expected to be present for both morning and evening preps, and teachers roll called. If a student missed preps thrice, they were dismissed from school. Students shouldn’t be chased after,” he added.

Vassallo highlighted the school's commitment to mentoring, with teachers engaging up to 10 learners each to discuss their goals, talents, and overall educational development. “We shall also make learning accessible for learners with special needs,” he pointed out. He elaborated on the school’s focus on academic excellence, particularly in STEM and young entrepreneurship, while personalizing education to meet each student’s needs. “Each child’s background, their special learning needs, interests, passions, and goals in life, play a role in contributing to the instructional design. So, we listen, empathize, and then adapt our instructional design to each learner to accommodate that learner’s goals and needs,” Vassallo said. “It’s really about personalizing learning in a very 21st-century way that schools of the 20th and 19th centuries didn’t do, as it was a one-size-fits-all program for students with some variation.”




The successful event at Ntare School marks a significant step in revitalizing Rwanda’s approach to education. As the school prepares to welcome its first cohort of students in September, it symbolizes a commitment to excellence and innovation in education, ensuring that future generations of Rwandans are well-equipped to thrive in a dynamic world.

15:30, 2024-06-11

 In a heartbreaking announcement on Tuesday, President Lazarus Chakwera confirmed the death of Vice President Saulos Chilima and nine other individuals following the disappearance of their military aircraft on Monday morning. The aircraft, a Donier 228 belonging to the Malawi Defense Force, was found destroyed near a hill in the Chikangawa Forest, with no survivors.

"I am deeply saddened and sorry to inform you all that it has turned out to be a terrible tragedy. The search and rescue team found the aircraft near a hill in the Chikangawa Forest. They found it completely destroyed, with no survivors, as all passengers on board were killed on impact," President Chakwera said in a televised address. "Chilima was a good man, a devoted father and husband, a patriotic citizen who served his country with distinction."




The incident began on Monday morning when the military aircraft carrying the Vice President and nine others went missing from airport radars. According to earlier reports by the BBC, a senior military official suggested that the plane might have crashed in the forested region of northern Malawi. The aircraft was operating in adverse weather conditions when it disappeared.

The Vice President was en route to attend the funeral of the country's former Attorney General and Minister of Justice, Ralph Kasambara, who was found dead at a lodge in Lilongwe on Friday. Kasambara's body was buried on Monday at his home village in Nkhata Bay, a short distance from Mzuzu Airport.

The Donier 228 was scheduled to land at Mzuzu Airport at 10:02 a.m. (0802 GMT) on Monday. However, due to bad weather, the aircraft turned back toward Kamuzu International Airport in Lilongwe before it lost contact with radar. A search and rescue operation was promptly launched by security agencies around the Chikangawa Forest area.




Colleen Zamba, Secretary to the President and Cabinet, provided additional details: "The aircraft failed to make its scheduled landing at Mzuzu Airport due to bad weather and was returning to Lilongwe when it went off the radar."

The loss of Vice President Chilima has sent shockwaves throughout Malawi. He was widely respected for his dedication to public service and his contributions to the nation. As President Chakwera noted, "This is a significant loss for our country. Vice President Chilima was a pillar of strength and a leader who always put the interests of Malawi first."




In the aftermath of this tragic event, the country mourns not only the loss of its Vice President but also the nine other individuals who perished in the crash. Their identities are being withheld pending notification of their families.

The government has declared a period of national mourning to honor the lives lost in this devastating accident. As the nation grieves, President Chakwera urged Malawians to come together in solidarity and support for the families affected by this tragedy

Far-Right Gains in EU Elections Send Political Shockwaves Across the Atlantic.

15:15, 2024-06-11

 In a seismic shift that echoes the political upheaval of recent years, far-right candidates have achieved sweeping gains in the European Union elections, embodying a wave of populist nationalism reminiscent of the political climate that led to Brexit and Donald Trump’s 2016 presidential victory. This surge raises significant questions for U.S. President Joe Biden as he prepares for a challenging re-election campaign. The European elections, held this past weekend, saw a dramatic rise in support for far-right parties. These candidates share many of the hallmarks of Trump’s populist approach: a strong anti-immigrant stance, a fervent economic message, and a disdain for traditional governing elites and globalist institutions. This development arrives just as the U.S. enters its own election season, with Trump positioning himself as a key contender.




While U.S. voters are not typically influenced by foreign elections and the electoral processes of the two regions are distinct, the themes driving the recent European electoral successes are strikingly relevant to the American political landscape. President Biden faces a similar array of public sentiments, including concerns over migration, economic hardship due to inflation, and the financial burden of climate change policies. These issues resonate strongly in battleground states critical to the outcome of the upcoming U.S. presidential election. The European results highlight a broader political vulnerability for incumbents in an era of economic discomfort. As Biden heads to the G7 summit in Italy this week, he will meet with several Western leaders who have been politically weakened by recent events. French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz are both dealing with the fallout from a significant rebuke in the European elections, where far-right parties capitalized on voter dissatisfaction. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces low approval ratings, casting doubt on his political future, and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is bracing for a potential electoral wipeout in the next general election after over a decade of Conservative rule.




In a twist of political irony, the most secure leader at the G7 summit may be Italy’s right-wing Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni. Her party’s substantial victory in the European elections positions her as one of the most powerful figures among the Western leaders, underscoring the unpredictable nature of contemporary politics. For Biden, a critical factor in his re-election campaign might be that the upcoming U.S. election is not a straightforward battle between an insurgent outsider and an unpopular incumbent. Trump, despite positioning himself as a challenger, carries the complex legacy of his previous term, including two impeachments and ongoing legal issues. Additionally, the rise of populist nationalism is not a universal trend. Biden’s Democratic Party managed to counteract “Make America Great Again” influences in the 2022 midterm elections. Furthermore, the anticipated victory of the Labour Party in the UK’s general election and Poland’s recent rejection of populist rule offer counterexamples to the far-right’s ascendancy.




As President Biden confronts these multifaceted challenges, the lessons from Europe’s elections underscore the volatile and interconnected nature of global political dynamics. The path to maintaining political stability and addressing voter concerns in an age of economic uncertainty and populist rhetoric remains a complex and ongoing endeavor.

MINECOFIN completes Automation of UMURENGE SACCOs, Paving Way for Advanced Financial Services in Rwanda

15:02, 2024-06-11

The Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (MINECOFIN), in collaboration with the Ministries of Local Government (MINALOC), Information and Communications Technology and Innovation (MINICT), and Trade and Industry (MINICOM), along with key government agencies such as the National Bank of Rwanda (BNR), Rwanda Cooperative Agency (RCA), and Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA), and development partners including the World Bank, Access to Finance Rwanda (AFR), Deutsche Sparkassenstiftung für internationale Kooperation (DSIK), and the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO), marked a significant milestone on Monday, June 10, 2024. The event at Kagano U-SACCO in the Kagano Sector of Nyamasheke District celebrated the completion of the automation phase for all 416 UMURENGE SACCOs.




This achievement marks a pivotal moment in Rwanda's journey towards enhancing financial services and paves the way for the consolidation of these SACCOs into District SACCOs (D-SACCOs), ultimately leading to the establishment of a cooperative bank.

Since their inception in the 1970s, SACCOs have played a vital role in Rwanda's financial landscape. However, a 2008 Finscope study revealed that 52% of the adult population faced financial exclusion. In response, the National Dialogue Meeting in December 2008 recommended the establishment of at least one SACCO in each administrative sector (UMURENGE) to promote economic development and financial inclusion.




Despite the formation of 416 UMURENGE SACCOs starting in 2009, these institutions encountered several operational challenges. Their business operations were largely manual, their scope of business was limited, and they lacked digital financial services for members. To address these challenges, the UMURENGE SACCOs automation and consolidation project, under the leadership of MINECOFIN, aims to professionalize these financial institutions through a three-step process: automation of U-SACCOs, consolidation into D-SACCOs, and the establishment of a cooperative bank to serve U-SACCOs and their members. The automation phase, now completed, involved transitioning U-SACCOs from manual to automated management information systems to enhance efficiency and member service. This transition is a key step in the broader consolidation process, which will merge automated U-SACCOs at the district level to form D-SACCOs. Existing U-SACCOs will become branches of these new entities.

Uganda Martyrs Day: A world's Pilgrimage of Faith and Unity journey

04:39, 2024-06-03

June is a public holiday in Uganda, dedicated to commemorating Uganda Martyrs Day. This annual event honors 22 Catholic and 23 Anglican converts to Christianity who were executed between 31 January 1885 and 27 January 1887 on the orders of Kabaka (King) Mwanga of Buganda.

Pilgrims' Journey from Lira

This year, approximately 820 pilgrims from the Lira Diocese in northern Uganda embarked on a remarkable journey, walking since 18 May 2024. Their destination is the Namugongo Shrine, where they aim to arrive by 31 May in time for the national liturgy on 3 June. The pilgrimage is more than just a physical journey; it is a spiritual and communal experience culminating in a colorful Eucharistic service.

Nebbi Diocese Leads the Liturgy




The Nebbi Catholic Diocese, located in North Western Uganda, will animate this year’s liturgy at the Namugongo Catholic Martyrs Shrine. The theme for this year is “But as for me and My Household, We Shall Serve the Lord,” inspired by Joshua 24:15. This theme underscores the commitment and faith that the martyrs displayed, a sentiment that resonates deeply with the pilgrims.

The Generosity of Strangers




Throughout their journey, the Lira pilgrims have experienced overwhelming generosity from strangers, parishioners, and schools. They sleep at various designated places, such as schools and parishes, and carry provisions to cook for themselves. Fr. Goddie Akio, the principal spokesperson for the pilgrims, shared with Vatican News the heartwarming support they have received. Locals have cheered them on and offered fruits, beverages, and other food items to help rejuvenate their strength on this walk of faith.

Mr. Akio also highlighted the spiritual activities that accompany their journey. Pilgrims participate in daily evening Mass, recite the Chaplet of the Divine Mercy, and fervently pray the rosary, seeking the Blessed Virgin Mary’s intervention. They carry prayer intentions for their diocese, the bishop, priests, and religious members, as well as for friends and relatives who couldn’t join the pilgrimage. Above all, they pray for love, peace, and unity in Uganda.

Ensuring Safety: Police and Military Protection

Road safety and security are major concerns for such a large group of travelers. Fortunately, the Ugandan government has assigned police and military units to escort the pilgrims from various dioceses, including Lira, Nebbi, and Gulu. The Uganda Police Force and the army have been accompanying the Lira pilgrims throughout their trek, ensuring their safety and providing a sense of security.




Catholic teaching in the Catechism recognizes the value of pilgrimages as an opportunity for Catholics to deepen their faith. Pilgrimages are seen as a reminder of the Christian journey towards heaven and are intense periods of prayer and reflection.

As the pilgrims make their way to the Namugongo Shrine, their journey stands as a testament to faith, community, and the enduring spirit of the Uganda Martyrs. The national liturgy on 3 June will not only honor the martyrs but also celebrate the unity and resilience of the Ugandan people.

South Africa's ANC Faces Coalition Dilemma After Historic Election Loss.

04:06, 2024-06-03

South Africa’s ruling African National Congress (ANC) entered "permutation mode" on Friday, grappling with its lowest electoral performance since ascending to power in 1994. Preliminary results revealed the ANC falling below the critical 50 percent threshold, prompting the need to seek coalition partners among its political rivals for the first time in post-apartheid South Africa.

The ANC's diminished performance, predicted by a series of opinion polls, marks a significant shift in the country's political landscape. Now, Nelson Mandela’s party must negotiate alliances, an unprecedented move attracting considerable international media attention. The formation of a coalition government, though legally possible for decades, would be a novel development in South African politics.

This coalition-building process will profoundly impact the nation's future governance and international posture, given the divergent ideologies of the competing political parties. The ANC's main rivals include the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) led by Julius Malema, uMkhonto we Sizwe (MK) of former President Jacob Zuma, and the Democratic Alliance (DA) led by John Steenhuisen.




By Friday, speculation suggested that the ANC might reach out to the DA, which has maintained relatively fewer public conflicts with the ruling party compared to the EFF and MK. However, the DA’s predominantly white membership evokes memories of the pre-ANC era, despite recent efforts to broaden its appeal.

“The ANC needs a partner that can help stabilize governance without deepening existing political rifts,” said Johannesburg-based political analyst Mandla Mzimela. “The DA’s promise to 'Rescue South Africa' and its moderate stance might make it a palatable choice, despite historical tensions.”

The EFF and MK, meanwhile, consist of former ANC members who left the party under contentious circumstances, creating suspicion about their intentions. EFF supporters demonstrated their discontent vividly during the campaign, holding a mock coffin bearing President Cyril Ramaphosa’s face at their "Tshela Thupa" rally.

Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, daughter of former President Zuma, ruled out a coalition between MK and the ANC, citing her father's preference for alliances with "progressive black parties." This exclusion underscores the fractured relationship between Zuma and Ramaphosa, further complicating potential coalitions.




ANC national chairperson Gwede Mantashe stoked controversy by attributing MK's performance to tribalism. “I don’t think we should lock ourselves into Zulu tribalism. Tribalism is a backward form of politics; it has its timeframe and then disappears. If that is the factor, I am not worried,” he remarked.

EFF, originally a breakaway faction of the ANC, presents a more complex option. While sharing some ideological roots with the ANC, their radical positions on land expropriation and nationalization diverge sharply. Despite this, the EFF could still emerge as a coalition partner, given its significant electoral base.

“The ANC faces a challenging decision. Choosing the DA might alienate its core supporters, while aligning with the EFF or MK could introduce instability,” noted Mzimela. “This election result will likely influence regional dynamics, trade agreements, and foreign policy decisions across the Southern African Development Community (SADC).”







The ANC’s declining popularity reflects widespread dissatisfaction with persistent issues like unemployment, which stands at 33 percent, power outages, and rampant crime. Despite its historical achievements, the party has struggled to sustain progress in recent years, leading to voter frustration.

"People want sustainable jobs and basic services, which are absent," said Dominic Maphaka, a scholar from North-West University. "Recounting past successes won't save the ANC; tangible change is needed."

The electoral process itself was marred by protests, power outages, and logistical issues. Voters faced long queues and disruptions, particularly in Eastern Cape and Western Cape. Allegations of IEC property theft and obstructions further complicated the voting day.

Former Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta, leading the African Union Election Observation Mission, expressed confidence in South Africa’s electoral system but acknowledged the challenges. "I trust in the electoral system and believe in the importance of maintaining calm and confidence in the democratic process," he said.

As South Africa navigates this pivotal moment, the ANC’s coalition choice will shape the nation's future. The implications extend beyond national borders, potentially affecting the entire continent’s political and economic landscape.













Rwanda Poised to Develop National Central Bank Digital Currency.

03:34, 2024-06-03

In a bid to modernize its financial system and secure a foothold in the future global economy, Rwanda plans to develop a Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) within the next two years. The National Bank of Rwanda (BNR) announced this initiative, emphasizing the potential benefits of a digital currency, including enhanced financial inclusion and improved international trade capabilities. According to the BNR, the proposed digital currency will provide Rwandans with a safe, cost-free, and convenient alternative to physical cash, thus expanding financial inclusion by integrating more unbanked individuals into the formal economy. As digital currencies gain traction worldwide, Rwanda aims to ensure that its government and private sector can engage in international trade with greater ease.

However, the concept of a CBDC remains largely theoretical for many Rwandans, as it does for people around the world. In an exclusive interview, Soraya Hakuziyaremenye, the Deputy Governor at Rwanda’s Central Bank, shed light on the necessary steps to adopt a national digital currency and the potential benefits for the public.




"Rwanda’s main trading partners, like China, are already testing the digital Yuan, and the European Union plans to adopt a digital currency by 2025," said Hakuziyaremenye. "We needed to understand whether there would be benefits for Rwanda as well to embark on this technological journey."

The BNR recently published a feasibility study on the proposed CBDC. When asked about its relevance and findings, Hakuziyaremenye explained, "The CBDC would be a digital form of cash, similar to how Rwandans currently use banknotes, coins, and electronic payments. With Rwanda positioning itself as an ICT hub and striving to become a cashless economy and an international financial hub, it was crucial to conduct this research."

Hakuziyaremenye highlighted the importance of understanding both the technology behind a CBDC and the potential risks. "We didn't do it alone. We worked with the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of ICT and Innovation to form a task force that examined developments in other countries. This collaboration started in 2022, and it was essential to consult banks, fintech companies, payment service providers, and other government institutions."

The early findings of the study indicate multiple opportunities for a national digital currency in Rwanda. "We identified four key areas: resilience to current payment systems, boosting innovation and competition among payment providers, accelerating our cashless agenda, and improving cross-border payments," said Hakuziyaremenye.




Regarding the next steps and timeline for introducing the CBDC, Hakuziyaremenye emphasized a cautious approach. "Issuing a national digital currency is not something you take lightly. We published the research paper and opened a public consultation process to gather feedback from the general population. Concerns have been raised about data privacy, resilience, and the potential impact on the financial system."

She further explained that Rwanda is mindful of regional developments. "We have close to 86 countries that have started piloting or are at the same level as us in research. Deciding to launch a CBDC requires collaboration with trading partners to ensure cross-border payments are faster and cheaper."

The public consultation process will close in four weeks, followed by a proof of concept to test the technology on a small scale. "This exercise will take roughly six months and will involve testing the technology in other countries, particularly for cross-border payments. Afterward, we will test the digital currency with a sample of individuals and companies to ensure its resilience and mitigate risks," she added. "Given this pace, we expect to have everything in place within the next two years."




Designing the CBDC also presents challenges. "Our preferred option is a retail CBDC, distributed through banks similar to current deposit and account systems. Another option is an indirect CBDC, where people have direct accounts with the central bank, but we don't think this is the right approach as we want banks to continue their role of intermediation," Hakuziyaremenye explained. "Lastly, we are considering a CBDC accessible offline, which is crucial for areas without internet access or during power outages."

As Rwanda advances in its journey toward a national digital currency, it continues to position itself as a leader in technological innovation and financial inclusion, setting the stage for a more connected and efficient economy.

ANC Faces Potential Coalition Government as Early Results Indicate Decline in Support

05:45, 2024-05-31

Initial results from the KwaZulu-Natal province and the national level suggest that the African National Congress (ANC) may lose its majority for the first time since the end of apartheid, prompting discussions of possible coalition agreements. According to reliable sources, preliminary negotiations between the ANC, Democratic Alliance (DA), and Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) were initiated at the provincial level in response to the party's diminishing prospects. These discussions, aimed at ensuring stable governance through a possible tandem agreement between KwaZulu-Natal and the national government, remain in preliminary stages pending a meeting of the ANC National Executive Committee.




By noon on Thursday, the ANC's outlook in KwaZulu-Natal appeared bleak, with the uMkhonto Wesizwe (MK) party narrowly leading. The IFP had 36.8% of the votes, and the DA had 11.4%. By 7:30 PM, the situation worsened for the ANC, which held only 21.27% of the vote, compared to MK’s 43.4%, IFP’s 17.9%, and DA’s 10.3%.

With these percentages, the ANC would require a three-way coalition to govern KwaZulu-Natal, possibly involving a smaller party. However, MK has reportedly ruled out a coalition with the ANC, as per News24. The potential for a coalition involving the IFP remains uncertain, particularly given the presence of former President Jacob Zuma in MK's leadership.

The prospect of a three-way co-governance deal underscores the ANC's potential loss of its historical majority, both provincially and nationally. Since Nelson Mandela led the ANC to victory in South Africa’s first democratic elections in 1994, the party has dominated the political landscape.

Nationally, pollsters on Thursday showed the ANC hovering around 42%, a significant drop from the 57% recorded in the 2019 elections. The DA held around 22%, the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) at 9%, and MK at approximately 10%. If these figures hold, MK will make a notable national debut, surpassing the EFF's 6.35% in 2014.




As of 7:30 PM, with only 30% of voting stations counted, the ANC held 42.31% of the national vote, followed by the DA at 24.6%, MK at 9.3%, and the EFF at 9.1%. The Patriotic Alliance ranked fifth with 3.4%, just ahead of the IFP.

The results, still subject to change as more votes are tallied, have caused concern among political representatives at the Electoral Commission of South Africa (IEC) national results center at Gallagher Estate. Township voting stations, often late in reporting, could still impact the final results.

The ANC's position in KwaZulu-Natal has been precarious, even before MK's emergence. In 2019, the ANC secured 55.47% in the province, down from 65.3% in 2014. The province's significant voting population makes its support crucial for national seat calculations.

At the IEC national results center, the mood among ANC representatives was grim. Gwede Mantashe, ANC National Chairperson, criticized the vote for MK as “tribal,” while another insider described the situation as “shocking.”

IEC Chairperson Mosotho Moepya assured that all procedures were above board, despite concerns about the handling of the three ballots and voting inconsistencies. The IEC expects to declare final results and legislature seat allocations by Sunday, after which the new MPs will be sworn in, and the President will be elected and inaugurated.

Moepya acknowledged the ongoing process, stating, “We are looking at something that is still half-baked — no, it’s still in the oven.”

As the final results approach, the ANC faces the reality of forming coalitions to maintain governance, marking a significant shift in South Africa’s political landscape.

04:57, 2024-05-31

Nairobi, Kenya — Rwanda and the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development (KFAED) signed a financing agreement on Thursday, May 30, to provide $20 million for the rehabilitation of the Muhanga-Nyange road. The concessional loan deal was signed by Rwanda's Finance Minister, Uzziel Ndagijimana, and Waleed Al-Bahar, the Acting Director General of KFAED, on the sidelines of the African Development Bank Annual Meeting in Nairobi, Kenya.




The funding from KFAED will support the completion of the Rubengera-Muhanga road project. This project is divided into three sections: Rubengera-Rambura (15.15 km), funded by the Saudi Fund for Development; Rambura-Nyange (22 km), financed by the Abu Dhabi Fund for Development; and Nyange-Muhanga (24 km), which will be financed by KFAED.

Minister Ndagijimana emphasized the prompt initiation of the project’s procurement process, attributing it to the “flexibility of financiers” that allowed the process to commence even before the official signing ceremony. “We believe the project implementation will be fast-tracked and movement will be enhanced on that road,” Ndagijimana told City Radio.




He expressed gratitude to the Kuwait Fund for its longstanding cooperation and impactful contributions to various projects in Rwanda, particularly in infrastructure. “The Kuwait Fund has been a reliable partner in our development journey, especially in the education, transport, and health sectors,” Ndagijimana said. The minister highlighted the importance of concessional loans in maintaining Rwanda's debt status while balancing budget expenditures. “Accessing concessional loans enables us to keep our debt in check and manage our budget effectively,” he noted.

In addition to the agreement with KFAED, Minister Ndagijimana met with Pasi Hellman, Finland's Vice Minister for International Development, to sign a public sector investment framework agreement. He also held discussions with Abdulhamid Alkhalifa, the President of the OPEC Fund, to explore ways to enhance bilateral cooperation and establish a medium-term country partnership.




The successful signing of the financing agreement with KFAED marks a significant step towards improving Rwanda’s transportation infrastructure, which is crucial for the country’s economic development. The Rubengera-Muhanga road project, once completed, will significantly enhance connectivity and facilitate smoother transportation across the region.

President Paul Kagame to Attend AfDB Annual Meeting Focusing on Structural Reforms for Africa's Socioeconomic Transformation.

12:31, 2024-05-27

Rwanda's President Paul Kagame is set to attend the African Development Bank (AfDB) Annual Meeting from May 27 to 31. The event, themed "Africa’s Transformation, African Development Bank Group, and Reform of the Global Financial Architecture," will focus on structural reforms essential for the socioeconomic transformation of the continent.




This year’s meeting, held in Nairobi, marks the 59th Annual Assembly of the African Development Bank and the 50th meeting of the African Development Fund. The conference will bring together key officials from bilateral and multilateral development agencies, leading academics, and representatives from non-governmental organizations, civil society, and the private sector.

President Kagame is scheduled to speak during a presidential dialogue on May 29, addressing the conference's central theme. Other prominent African leaders expected to attend include President Felix Tshisekedi of the Democratic Republic of Congo, President Emmerson Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe, and President Nana Addo Akufo-Addo of Ghana.




In addition to the African presidents, several high-profile dignitaries will be in attendance. These include finance ministers from various countries, Admassu Tadesse, President and Group Managing Director of the Trade and Development Bank (TDB), Muhammad Al Jasser, President of the Islamic Development Bank, Patrick Verkooijen, CEO of the Global Center on Adaptation, Sidi Ould Tah, Director General of the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa (BADEA), and Alexia Latortue, Assistant Secretary for International Markets and Development at the U.S. Treasury.

Discussions at the meeting will revolve around the necessity of a reconfigured global financial architecture as a catalyst for structural transformation. The AfDB Group’s contribution to Africa’s socioeconomic transformation over its 60 years of existence will also be highlighted.




Despite having 10 of the world's fastest-growing economies and a real GDP growth rate of 4.3 percent annually over the past two decades (compared to the global average of 2.9 percent), Africa remains off track on almost all Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) targets for 2030. Experts estimate the cost of achieving these goals in Africa at about $1.3 trillion annually, which is 42 percent of the continent's $3.1 trillion GDP in 2023.

The conference aims to identify strategies for accelerating Africa’s economic transformation and redefining the current global financial architecture to mobilize the necessary resources. Additionally, the AfDB will launch its flagship African Economic Outlook 2024 report, which will focus on driving Africa’s transformation and reforming the global financial architecture.

The AfDB partners with African governments on numerous projects across various sectors, including infrastructure and healthcare. As of 2023, the bank’s portfolio in Rwanda consists of 26 projects with a total investment of $1.5 billion.

The outcomes of this meeting are expected to play a crucial role in shaping Africa’s economic future and ensuring that the continent can meet its development targets effectively.

Twelve Injured After Qatar Airways Flight Experiences Severe Turbulence

09:04, 2024-05-27

Twelve people were injured on Sunday when a Qatar Airways flight from Doha to Dublin encountered severe turbulence. The incident occurred as the aircraft, flight QR017, was flying over Turkey.

Upon landing in Dublin shortly before 1 PM local time, the flight was met by emergency services, including airport police and the fire and rescue department. According to a statement from Dublin Airport, six passengers and six crew members sustained injuries, with eight individuals taken to hospital for further assessment and treatment.

In a statement to CNN, Qatar Airways confirmed the safe landing of the flight and acknowledged that "a small number of passengers and crew sustained minor injuries in flight and are now receiving medical attention." The airline emphasized that the safety and security of its passengers and crew are its top priority and that the incident is now subject to an internal investigation.

Despite the turbulence, Dublin Airport reported that its operations were unaffected. The return flight to Doha, QR018, is scheduled to proceed, though with a delay.




This incident comes just days after another severe turbulence event involving Singapore Airlines. On Tuesday, flight SQ321 from London to Singapore experienced intense turbulence at 37,000 feet, resulting in 104 injuries and the tragic death of a passenger with a heart condition. The plane sharply dropped and ascended several hundred feet multiple times, leading to a minute of chaos on board.

Experts have linked the increase in severe turbulence incidents to climate change. Paul Williams, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Reading, explained to CNN in 2022 that climate change is likely modifying turbulence patterns. "We ran some computer simulations and found that severe turbulence could double or triple in the coming decades," Williams said. This type of turbulence, known as "clear air turbulence," occurs without visual warning and is difficult to avoid.




The specific nature of the turbulence experienced by the Qatar Airways flight remains unclear. Unlike the Singapore Airlines flight, which entered an area with developing thunderstorms, it is not yet known if similar conditions contributed to the Qatar Airways incident.

As the aviation industry continues to adapt to these evolving challenges, ensuring passenger safety remains paramount. Further investigations and technological advancements will be critical in mitigating the risks associated with turbulence in the future.

Rwandan Community in Ghana Commemorates 1994 Genocide Against the Tutsi

04:43, 2024-05-27

As the Rwandan community in Ghana gathered to commemorate the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi, the Rwandan High Commissioner to Ghana, Aisa Kirabo Kacyira, emphasized the importance of educating current and future generations about the tragedy to prevent similar atrocities.

During the Kwibuka30 event held on Friday, May 24, in Accra, Rwandans, Ghanaian government officials, and members of the diplomatic corps came together to honor the more than one million victims of the genocide. Kacyira extended her gratitude to the countries that supported Rwanda during the genocide and called for renewed efforts to bring perpetrators to justice.

“Thirty years ago, the world abandoned Rwandans to their bitter end as it has been said time and again but what is more heart-breaking is that for the past three decades, the world has continued to abandon Rwandans by not ensuring that justice gets served,” Kacyira said. “Fugitives incriminated in the Genocide against the Tutsi still roam freely. The world can and should do better.”




Kacyira also urged world leaders to combat genocide denial, hate speech, discrimination, and other forms of negation that distort the truth about the Genocide against the Tutsi. “Understanding the truth about genocide as a crime, particularly the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi, requires that education be not a one-off thing,” she said. “We must include modules in schools to teach about this heinous sin, which takes meticulous planning to commit. Only then can we make progress to our global promise of genocide never again.”

Ghana’s Deputy Foreign Minister for Regional Integration, Mavis Nkansah Boadu, expressed her country’s support for Rwanda’s efforts to uphold the values of peace, unity, and humanity, and the memory of the genocide victims. “Let us remember that the fight against genocide and mass atrocities is a collective responsibility,” Boadu stated. “As members of the international community, we must strengthen our resolve to prevent such tragedies, promote human rights, and uphold the dignity of every individual. The lessons of 1994 must continue to guide our actions and our policies, ensuring that such activities never occur again.”




Friday’s event concluded a series of activities organized this year to commemorate the Genocide against the Tutsi. These included a ‘Walk-to-Remember’, a student commemoration of Kwibuka30 at Ashesi University, and a symposium at the Ghana Institute of Management and Public Administration (GIMPA), where delegates deliberated on the need to educate the world about the tragedy and ensure similar atrocities do not happen anywhere in the world.

The Kwibuka30 event in Accra served as a poignant reminder of the importance of remembrance, justice, and education in preventing future genocides and fostering a global commitment to the values of peace and human dignity.

Russia's moves to expand Baltic Sea borders, drawing sharp rebuke from NATO members

04:24, 2024-05-24

In a move that has sparked alarm among Baltic Sea states and NATO members, Russia's Defense Ministry has drafted a government decree to unilaterally revise the borders of Russian territorial waters in the Baltic Sea. The proposed expansion was made without notifying neighboring NATO members Finland and Lithuania.

The Kremlin's response to the surprise and concern expressed by Baltic Sea states only added to the tension. Insisting that there was “nothing political” about the proposed border change, Vladimir Putin’s spokesman Dmitry Peskov simultaneously acknowledged that the “political situation” has “changed significantly” since the borders were originally drawn.




“You see how tensions are escalating, what the level of confrontation is, especially in the Baltic region. This requires our agencies to take corresponding steps to ensure security,” Peskov told reporters. His language echoed Putin’s frequent justification for the invasion of Ukraine, which was framed as a necessary measure for “security” against NATO.

The proposed decree, which was initially published on a government portal on Tuesday, stated, “The state border of the Russian Federation at sea will change.” The decree, if approved, would take effect in January 2025. However, following the backlash from Western leaders, the draft decree was abruptly deleted.




The Defense Ministry argued that the 1985 measurements used to determine current borders were based on outdated charts and thus must be “invalidated.” The adjustments would affect the borders around Russian islands in the eastern part of the Gulf of Finland and around Kaliningrad, though the decree did not specify the exact nature of these adjustments.

The move came as a shock to neighboring countries. Finnish President Alexander Stubb expressed his concern on X (formerly Twitter), stating, “Russia has not been in contact with Finland in the matter,” and assured that “the political leadership is monitoring the situation closely.”

Finnish Foreign Minister Elina Valtonen urged Russia to adhere to international law, specifically the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, and to stop “causing confusion.”




Lithuanian Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis condemned the move as an “obvious escalation against NATO and the EU,” calling for a “firm response.”

Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson also criticized the unilateral decision, stating bluntly, “Russia can’t unilaterally decide on new borders.”

The sudden proposal and its equally sudden withdrawal highlight the volatile nature of regional security in the Baltic area. The incident underscores the increasing tensions between Russia and NATO members, with Western leaders viewing the move as another example of Russia’s aggressive stance towards its neighbors. The situation remains fluid, with NATO and EU leaders likely to discuss coordinated responses to Russia's actions. As the political landscape continues to shift, the need for clear communication and adherence to international law becomes ever more critical in maintaining regional stability.

The vote for the national assembly speaker had initially been scheduled for May 18 but was delayed by Tshisekedi. Despite these disruptions, the election proceeded, reinforcing the political stability needed to move forward.




Vital Kamerhe, 65, has been a significant figure in Congolese politics. He campaigned alongside Tshisekedi in the 2018 presidential election and has previously served as Tshisekedi's chief of staff and as deputy prime minister of the economy. However, his career has not been without controversy; in 2020, he was arrested in a graft probe but has since continued to be a prominent political player.

The Sacred Union, Tshisekedi's coalition, holds a substantial majority in parliament, with at least 90 percent of the 500 seats.

The successful election of Kamerhe as speaker is expected to pave the way for further appointments and the stabilization of governance in the DRC. With Kamerhe's close alignment with President Tshisekedi, the government is poised to advance its agenda more cohesively.




As the DRC navigates these significant political developments, the focus will be on how the new government addresses the myriad challenges facing the nation. The recent attack on Kamerhe's home underscores the volatile security situation, which the new administration will need to prioritize.

Kamerhe's role as speaker will be instrumental in shaping the legislative agenda and supporting President Tshisekedi's efforts to implement reforms and foster stability in the country. With the foundation for a new government now in place, the DRC looks to move forward from a prolonged period of political uncertainty.

China Launches Military Drills Around Taiwan, Citing "Punishment" for "Separatist Acts"

05:07, 2024-05-23

China has initiated two days of military exercises surrounding Taiwan, labeling the move as "punishment" for "separatist acts," just days after Taiwan swore in its new democratically elected leader, Lai Ching-te. The exercises, which began early Thursday, pose a significant challenge for Lai as he navigates the complex and tense relations with China.

China's ruling Communist Party maintains that Taiwan is part of its territory, despite never having controlled the island, and has vowed to take it by force if necessary. The People’s Liberation Army (PLA) launched joint drills involving the army, navy, air force, and rocket force around Taiwan at 7:45 a.m. on Thursday. These exercises are taking place in the Taiwan Strait, and areas north, south, and east of Taiwan, as well as around Taiwan’s outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu, Wuqiu, and Dongyin, just off China’s southeastern coast.




“We stand by with firm will and restraint. We seek no conflicts, but we will not shy away from one. We have the confidence to safeguard our national security,” the PLA’s Eastern Theater Command said in a statement.

Taiwan’s presidential spokeswoman Karen Kuo responded, saying, “It is regrettable to see China threatening Taiwan’s democracy and freedom and regional peace and stability with unilateral military provocations. In the face of external challenges and threats, we will continue to defend democracy and have the confidence and ability to protect national security.”



Rising Tensions

Under the leadership of Xi Jinping, China has increased its assertiveness, intensifying diplomatic, economic, and military pressure on Taiwan, especially as the island strengthens its informal ties with the United States. In August 2022, China conducted extensive war games around Taiwan in response to then US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taipei, demonstrating its military prowess with missiles and simulated blockades.

Chinese warplanes now routinely fly into Taiwan’s air defense identification zone (ADIZ) and cross the Median Line in the Taiwan Strait, a boundary that Beijing does not officially recognize but had largely respected until recent years. Prior to Lai's inauguration, on May 15, Taiwan reported detecting 45 Chinese military aircraft around the island, marking the highest single-day number this year.

Evan A. Feigenbaum, vice president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, described China’s drills as “an intimidation tactic, part of a pattern, not a sign of imminent war.” He noted, “Beijing has a robust coercion kitbag from which it will mix and match, ratchet up and back and up again to signal its range of options to coerce and inflict pain.”




Defense experts observed that the name of China’s latest military exercises, “Joint Sword-2024A,” suggests additional drills could occur later this year. Drew Thompson, a senior research fellow at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy at the National University of Singapore, stated, “It is not a surprise, nor is it a tactical response to President Lai’s speech. These exercises are part of the PLA’s long-term, strategic preparations to fight and win a war over Taiwan.”

PLA Naval Colonel Li Xi, spokesperson for the command, emphasized the exercises as “a strong punishment for the separatist acts of Taiwan independence forces and a serious warning against interference and provocation by external forces.”




Taiwan's Response

Taiwan’s Defense Ministry has condemned China’s drills as “irrational provocations and actions that undermine regional peace and stability.” In a statement Thursday, the ministry confirmed it had dispatched sea, air, and ground forces in response to the exercises.

Lai Ching-te, who succeeded two-term president Tsai Ing-wen, has been labeled by Beijing as a “dangerous separatist” due to his advocacy for Taiwan’s sovereignty and distinct identity. In his inauguration speech, Lai called on China to cease its intimidation of Taiwan, a plea that was promptly denounced by Beijing.

As tensions rise, the world watches closely, aware that the stability of the Taiwan Strait is crucial for regional and global peace.

04:50, 2024-05-23

In a significant move reflecting deepening ties between the United States and Kenya, President Joe Biden is expected to designate Kenya as a major non-NATO ally during Kenyan President William Ruto's three-day state visit this week. As President Biden welcomed President Ruto to the White House for a meeting with business executives, he announced plans to visit Africa in February, following the US presidential election. The two leaders are set to meet again in the Oval Office on Thursday, culminating in a joint news conference and a state dinner.




Senior administration officials indicated that the discussions between Biden and Ruto will cover a broad spectrum of issues, including trade, debt relief, and the geopolitical situations in Haiti, Ukraine, and Sudan. On Wednesday, President Biden highlighted the launch of a new era of technological cooperation between the US and Kenya, focusing on cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, and semiconductors. However, he did not mention the security designation at that time. The US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) is also set to announce $250 million in new investments in Kenya, expanding its portfolio in the country to over $1 billion. According to a US official, this investment reflects both nations' commitment to developing and deploying technology in ways that promote transparency, accountability, and human rights.




"Kenya, like the US, has become an engine for innovation," the official said, referencing Kenya’s $1 billion “Silicon Savannah” technology hub, home to more than 200 startups across various sectors, including clean energy, microelectronics, financial technology, and e-commerce.

Among the businesses participating in the tech dialogue were Alphabet, Baylis Emerging Markets, BasiGo, Teneo, and Gearbox Software. Washington also plans to establish a new semiconductor partnership with Kenya and is working with Congress to make Kenya the first African country to benefit from funding through the US CHIPS and Science Act of 2022.

Biden's designation of Kenya as a major non-NATO ally comes at a pivotal time as Kenya prepares to send forces to Haiti as part of a UN-led mission to address the security crisis in the Caribbean. The designation is granted to close, non-NATO allies with strategic working relationships with the US military.

"The White House had no immediate comment," an administration official stated.




This move follows Biden’s March designation of Qatar as a major non-NATO ally, fulfilling a promise made to the Arab country earlier in the year. Gyude Moore, head of the Africa Initiative at the Center for Global Development, noted Kenya's reliability as a US partner, especially as South Africa pursues a more independent foreign policy.

Cameron Hudson, a fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, remarked, "This move formalizes a shift that has seen Kenya move more squarely into a US orbit in recent years, including greater cooperation on Somalia. It's very significant. No other sub-Saharan African country has it."

As Biden and Ruto navigate these pivotal discussions and collaborations, this state visit marks a historic milestone in US-Kenyan relations, promising to enhance cooperation and strategic alignment between the two nations.

Rwanda's accountability pays off again as IMF approves more funding.

04:27, 2024-05-23

The Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a total funding package of $164.6 million for Rwanda, according to an official statement from the IMF. This decision follows a comprehensive review of Rwanda’s implementation of various IMF-supported macroeconomic policy programs.

The funding includes approximately $76.2 million (SDR 57.5 million) under the Resilience and Sustainability Facility (RSF) and $88.4 million (SDR 66.75 million) under the Standby Credit Facility (SCF). These instruments are designed to assist countries in managing climate shocks and addressing short-term balance of payment needs, respectively.




The IMF praised Rwanda's robust performance under these programs, highlighting successful reforms in social safety nets and spending rationalization. "Progress on the climate agenda under the RSF also remains strong, bolstering Rwanda's resilience to climate shocks," the IMF stated.

Despite facing challenging external conditions and ongoing fiscal consolidation, Rwanda's economy has shown impressive growth. The IMF recommended that Rwanda’s future policy mix should focus on maintaining macroeconomic and financial stability, ensuring fiscal sustainability, and rebuilding economic buffers.




In 2023, Rwanda's economic growth exceeded expectations, reaching 8.2 per cent, driven by strong performance in services, construction, and food crop production recovery following post-flood efforts. Inflation has also been on a steady decline since January 2023, dropping to 4.2 per cent in March, largely due to a slowdown in food prices and core inflation.

The National Bank of Rwanda (BNR) has played a crucial role in stabilizing consumer prices by consistently raising the policy rate to address rising inflationary pressures. However, the current account deficit widened more than anticipated in 2023. Despite this, international reserves remained adequate at about 4.1 months of imports at the end of 2023.

Public debt remains a significant concern for Rwanda. In 2023, public debt reached 73.5 per cent of GDP and is projected to rise to 80 per cent in 2024 before gradually declining to 77.5 per cent in 2025 and 74.6 per cent in 2026. External debt stood at 56.9 per cent of GDP in 2023 and is expected to increase to 65 per cent in 2024 and 67.5 per cent in 2025.




Looking ahead, Rwanda's economy is expected to grow at 6.6 per cent in 2024. The IMF emphasized the importance of maintaining the momentum of reforms and continuing efforts to enhance economic resilience and stability.

Rwanda Revenue Authority continues on to pursue the Gold Gender equality seal.

04:22, 2024-05-23

The Rwanda Revenue Authority (RRA) has reinforced its dedication to fostering a gender-inclusive environment by adopting Gender Equality Seal standards. This commitment was highlighted during a workshop held on May 20 with senior management and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) to discuss Gender Equality in Tax Administration.

Osten Chulu, Senior Economic Advisor at UNDP, emphasized the necessity of addressing gender inequalities across all sectors, including economic, social, political, environmental, and governance domains. Chulu highlighted the Equanomics initiative, through which the UNDP aims to create a tax system and fiscal policies that build a gender-equal economy.




“When we talk about Equanomics, we talk of economic equality, where there is an equal distribution of all national wealth and assets,” said Chulu. “Fiscal policies can play a prominent role in advancing gender equality, which is also a necessary condition to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This calls for gender-responsive tax policies and reforms designed to transform existing economic structures and systems and promote equality between male and female taxpayers.”




Key aspects for enhancing gender equality in Rwanda’s taxation system include equal treatment in taxation, progressive taxation to reduce income inequality, tax credits and deductions, access to financial resources, addressing the gender pay gap, and investing in social programs.

Chulu concluded, “UNDP is working with its partners to extend the implementation of the Gender Equality Seal for Public Institutions, including tax administration. Rwanda is one of only three pilot countries in Africa, alongside Nigeria and Ghana, and one of eight globally, selected to implement the Equanomics program.”




RRA Commissioner General, Pascal Bizimana Ruganintwali, reiterated RRA's commitment to gender equality. “RRA is a law-abiding institution, which makes it easy to give equal opportunities to men and women. Women should get more incentives to be economic actors and contribute to economic development,” he stated. Ruganintwali expressed his gratitude for UNDP's support and emphasized RRA’s goal to be certified after evaluating the implementation of gender standards.

Florien H. Rurihose, Deputy Chief Gender Monitor of the Gender Monitoring Office, commended the integration of gender issues into key economic sectors, including tax administration. He noted the expansion of the Gender Equality Seal program from the private sector to public institutions, resulting in certification for some.




“For institutions that implement the Gender Equality Seal program, they are provided with useful tools that help them enhance accountability to gender equality, improve their working environment, and promote inclusive workplaces. This ultimately leads to sustainable development and is good for the country,” said Rurihose.




The workshop participants underscored the importance of viewing taxes as a means for earners to contribute to national development, rather than as a punishment. They stressed the need to ensure that tax policies support gender equity and encourage women's participation in the economy.

“In that case, we should really ensure that the aspect of gender equity is taken care of in our taxation system, making sure that the participation of women in the economy is growing, getting better, and is of higher quality. Our tax policies should, therefore, be geared to create incentives that can attract women in business to become key actors,” remarked one participant.

To further this cause, UNDP and RRA have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) aimed at fostering a tax system and fiscal policies that actively contribute to creating an environment free from gender-based discrimination

Thousands Mourn President Ebrahim Raisi in Tabriz After Tragic Helicopter Crash

04:56, 2024-05-22

Thousands of Iranians gathered in Tabriz on Tuesday to mourn President Ebrahim Raisi, who was killed in a helicopter crash near the Azerbaijan border over the weekend. The tragic accident also claimed the lives of Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian and seven others.

State TV broadcast live images of the somber event, showing mourners, many dressed in black, beating their chests in grief. A truck covered in white flowers carried the caskets, each draped in the national flag, slowly through the throngs of people. "Everyone has come to bid farewell to the martyred president and his companions regardless of their faction, ethnicity, or language," said Tabriz lawmaker Masoud Pezeshkian.




Despite the large turnout in Tabriz, some insiders observed a stark contrast in public grief compared to past commemorations for other senior figures in the Islamic Republic's 45-year history. While Iran declared five days of mourning for Raisi, the emotional rhetoric that marked the death of Qasem Soleimani, a senior commander of the elite Revolutionary Guards killed by a U.S. missile in 2020, was notably absent. Soleimani’s funeral drew enormous crowds of mourners, weeping with sorrow and rage. Raisi's body was flown from Tabriz, the closest major city to the remote crash site, to Tehran airport before heading to the holy Shi'ite Muslim city of Qom. From there, it will return to the capital to lie at Tehran's Grand Mosalla Mosque before being transferred to his hometown of Mashahd in eastern Iran for burial on Thursday. Mourners carried posters bearing images of Raisi, Amirabdollahian, the Friday prayer leader of Tabriz, and other officials who perished in the crash.




The president's death comes amid a deepening crisis between the clerical leadership and the public over issues ranging from tightening social and political controls to economic hardship. To restore legitimacy following a historic low turnout of around 41% in March's parliamentary election, Iran's rulers need to stir public enthusiasm to ensure high participation in the early presidential election scheduled for June 28.

However, Iranians still bear painful memories of the state's handling of nationwide unrest sparked by the death in custody of a young Iranian-Kurdish woman in 2022. The unrest was quelled by a violent crackdown involving mass detentions and executions. Widespread public anger over worsening living standards and pervasive corruption may also deter many Iranians from voting.

"Millions have lost hope that Iran's ruling clerics can resolve an economic crisis fomented by a combination of U.S. sanctions, mismanagement, and corruption," said a political analyst. Raisi, known for enacting the hardline policies of his mentor, Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, aimed at entrenching clerical power, cracking down on opponents, and adopting a tough stance on foreign policy, was once seen as a leading candidate to succeed Khamenei. However, two sources revealed that Raisi's name had been removed from a list of potential successors about six months ago due to his declining popularity. Raisi's sudden death has introduced "great uncertainty" into the succession, analysts noted, potentially stirring rivalries within the hardliners' camp over who will succeed Khamenei as the country's ultimate authority.

"The uncertainty in the succession process is significant," said an analyst. "It could lead to intense power struggles within the hardline faction, affecting the country's political stability."




As Iran navigates this period of mourning and political uncertainty, the focus remains on how the leadership will address the economic and social challenges facing the nation, and whether they can rally the public around a new presidential candidate in the upcoming election.

Passengers Recount Terror as Severe Turbulence Hits Singapore Airlines Flight, Resulting in One Fatality.

04:23, 2024-05-22

Passengers on Singapore Airlines flight SQ321 faced a harrowing ordeal on Tuesday when severe turbulence struck the Boeing airliner, causing a sudden and dramatic drop. The flight, carrying 229 passengers and crew, was en route from London to Singapore when the turbulence hit, leading to chaos and injuries on board. The plane was cruising at 37,000 feet when it suddenly plunged, climbed several hundred feet, and then repeated the dip and ascent for about 90 seconds. "The flight was perfectly normal," recalled passenger Andrew Davies, who was traveling to New Zealand for business. "I don’t remember any turbulence at all."




Many passengers were having breakfast when the turbulence began. Davies, who was watching a movie at the time, noticed the seat belt sign light up and promptly fastened his belt. "Thank goodness I did because within moments of doing that, all hell broke loose," he told CNN.

"The plane just felt like it dropped. It probably only lasted a few seconds, but I remember vividly seeing shoes and iPads and iPhones and cushions and blankets and cutlery and plates and cups flying through the air and crashing to the ceiling," Davies described. "The gentleman next to me had a cup of coffee, which went straight all over me and up to the ceiling."

Photos from the aftermath show the cabin in disarray, with debris scattered everywhere and ceiling panels hanging loose. Davies, who was seated toward the front of the plane, witnessed the injuries sustained by dozens of passengers, including Geoff Kitchen, a 73-year-old Briton who tragically died during the flight.




"That gentleman was sitting right behind me," Davies said. "Lots of people needed some help but we tended to this gentleman, and I helped carry him, get him out of the seat, and we laid him on the floor so that some medical professionals could administer CPR." Kitchen received CPR for about 20 minutes amidst the chaos. "There was so much screaming," Davies recalled. "I saw one passenger with a big gash in her head and blood pouring down her face, and another elderly passenger in severe shock."

Another passenger, 28-year-old student Dzafran Azmir, described the turbulence as a "very dramatic drop," adding that "everyone seated and not wearing a seatbelt was launched immediately into the ceiling." He noted that the entire event happened so quickly that nobody had time to react, leaving some passengers in the bathrooms and air crew still standing when the turbulence hit. The flight was diverted to Bangkok following the incident. Of the 211 passengers and 18 crew on board, 143 were transported via a relief flight to Singapore, arriving early Wednesday morning, according to Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong in a video message released on Facebook. The remaining 79 passengers and 6 crew members, including those receiving medical care, remained in Bangkok.




The injured passengers included citizens from Australia, Malaysia, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Spain, the United States, and Ireland. Kittipong Kittikachorn, the general manager of Bangkok airport, indicated that preliminary investigations suggest Kitchen suffered from a heart condition, with the autopsy process ongoing. Several passengers had broken arms, but most injuries were cuts and bruises. CEO Goh extended his condolences to Kitchen’s family and expressed sorrow for the traumatic experience endured by the passengers. "The airline is deeply saddened by this incident," he said. "We are very sorry for the traumatic experience that our passengers endured."

Singapore's Ministry of Transport is investigating the incident and is in touch with its Thai counterparts, sending investigators to Bangkok. The US National Transportation Safety Board is also dispatching personnel to Singapore to assist in the investigation, including a representative and four technical advisors.













Kenya's President Ruto Advocates for Democracy and Financial Reform on First State Visit to the US

04:08, 2024-05-22

On Monday, Kenya's President William Ruto embarked on his first-ever State visit to the United States, using the platform to address critical regional and global issues. Landing in Washington, President Ruto spoke about climate change, financial restructuring, and regional security challenges.

In his first engagement, President Ruto emphasized the precarious state of democracy, particularly in Africa, during a session on “Global Democracy Partnership” at the Carter Center in Atlanta. The event was attended by prominent figures including Jason Carter, the Center’s Board Chairman and grandson of former US President Jimmy Carter, Paige Alexander, CEO of the Carter Center, Meredith Evans, Director of the Carter Presidential Library and Museum, US Congresswoman Nikema Williams, and US Ambassador to Kenya Meg Whitman.




“In several countries, we have seen unconstitutional changes of government that have threatened democratic gains. Consequently, this is a crucial time for reflecting on the need to strengthen democracy worldwide,” President Ruto stated.

He pointed out that many countries are facing economic and debt distress exacerbated by climate change and an inequitable international financial system. “We now run the escalating risk of democracy and free market being associated with poverty and suffering, lending credence to the widespread lamentation that democracy is or has been on the retreat in many parts of the world, including Africa,” he added.




Although President Ruto did not specify the countries, Africa has witnessed six coups in the last three years, with military takeovers in Gabon, Sudan, Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso, and Guinea due to economic and security failures.

He argued that the disappointment with traditional democratic systems has fueled a rise in nationalism, intolerance, and violent political contests globally. Ruto highlighted the need for a fair international financial architecture that supports developing nations with concessional development financing, which is crucial for economic resilience, free-market economies, and democratic governance. President Ruto, who has previously highlighted Kenya’s democratic processes, reiterated his experience of being elected through a transparent system that allowed for judicial review of election results. He is set to meet with US Congress members on Wednesday to discuss the impacts of poverty and debt on democracy in Africa.




In Atlanta, he advocated for the need to provide developing countries with fair financial opportunities. “We are making a case for many countries in Africa, including Kenya, seeking a just international financial architecture that will afford developing countries concessionary development financing to support our economies, build resilience against the effects of climate change, drive our belief in a free-market economy and energize our democratic enterprise,” he said. Kenya, grappling with debt inherited from previous administrations, has continued to borrow while increasing taxes. President Ruto recently defended these measures, arguing that proper taxation is essential, even if unpopular.

President Ruto urged the US to assist in addressing credit issues for poor countries, describing it as crucial for the future of democracy. However, Washington remains concerned about conflicts in regions like Sudan, which pose risks to neighboring areas through potential involvement of militia groups and arms smuggling.




The Global Democracy Partnership session at the Carter Center provided a significant platform for President Ruto to highlight the interconnectedness of democracy, economic stability, and global security, stressing the importance of international cooperation to address these challenges.

We have to make sure that the division to the extreme that led to the Genocide, as we had it in 1994, should never happen again. We can't allow it."

The Global Security Forum is an annual conference where leaders from around the world discuss pressing issues of global security and explore strategies to address them. President Kagame’s remarks underscored Rwanda's remarkable progress and the pivotal role of unity in the nation's ongoing development journey.
