FERWABA ADDS RWANDA BASKETBALL CUP TO THEIR CALENDAR IN A BID TO ELEVATE LOCAL TALENTS.

06:00, 2024-04-25

The Rwandan basketball landscape is set for a transformative boost as the local governing body, Ferwaba, announces the addition of the "Rwanda Basketball Cup" to its annual basketball calendar. This ground-breaking tournament, slated to run from April 26 to August 9, is poised to revolutionize the sport in the country, encompassing teams from both the topflight and lower divisions.

Formerly, Rwanda's basketball calendar was dominated by the league and the Genocide Memorial Tournament. However, with the introduction of the Rwanda Basketball Cup, Ferwaba aims to expand opportunities for teams, foster their development, and elevate the overall standard of play in the nation.

In an exclusive interview with Times Sport, Ferwaba Executive Director Fiona Ishimwe shed light on the tournament's purpose, eligibility criteria, structure, and anticipated impact on Rwandan basketball.

"The tournament aims to increase the number of teams playing in the country, fostering their development and raising the overall standard of play," Ishimwe stated, emphasizing the tournament's pivotal role in nurturing talent and promoting competition.

The Rwanda Basketball Cup welcomes teams from both the first and second divisions, across male and female categories. This inaugural edition will feature 21 men's teams and nine women's teams, showcasing the depth and diversity of basketball talent in Rwanda.

To ensure a competitive and fair tournament, the participating teams have been organized into groups. Seventeen men's teams from the first and second divisions have been distributed into four groups, with the top four teams from the 2023 season standings securing direct entry into the quarter-finals. In the women's category, the nine participating teams have been divided into two groups.

Notably, the stakes are high for the tournament's champions. The winner of the Rwanda Cup in the women’s category will represent Rwanda in Zone 5 competitions, while the men's division champion will earn the privilege to compete in the forthcoming East Africa Cup, sanctioned by FIBA.

Furthermore, the victors of both the Rwanda Cup and the league will converge in the prestigious Rwanda Super Cup tournament, held before the commencement of the new season. Adopting a single-game format, this tournament will determine the ultimate winner after a thrilling 40-minute, four-quarter contest, showcasing the best of Rwandan basketball talent.

With the Rwanda Basketball Cup set to become a highlight of the national basketball calendar, fans can anticipate exhilarating matchups, fierce competition, and the emergence of new stars, propelling Rwandan basketball to greater heights on the continental stage.

RWANDA CONSIDERS TO BAN CEMENTED AND TILED TOMBS TO ADDRESS BURRIAL SPACE SCARCITY.

05:52, 2024-04-25

A proposed amendment to Rwandan law aims to ban the construction of burial tombs using cement, tiles, and metallic materials in efforts to tackle delays in land reuse and alleviate cemetery scarcity, according to the Ministry of Local Government (MINALOC).

Joseph Curio Havugimana, Head of Communications at MINALOC, emphasized the need for the amendment, citing concerns that tombs built with non-biodegradable materials can impede the natural decomposition process of bodies, leading to prolonged periods before land can be repurposed for other uses.




"The scarcity of cemeteries in Rwanda has affected a large number of local citizens and non-natives in various ways," stated Havugimana, highlighting the urgency of addressing the issue.

Cement and tiles, commonly used in tomb construction, are known for their durability and resistance to natural degradation processes. This durability poses challenges to timely land reuse, exacerbating cemetery scarcity nationwide. To address this, MINALOC proposes promoting the use of biodegradable materials for burial tombs, facilitating quicker decomposition and allowing for more efficient land reuse. Under the proposed amendment, standard burial plots could be reused after 10 years, while special tombs would have a 20-year reuse period from the last interment.

The existing law distinguishes between ordinary and special tombs, with ordinary tombs excavated into the soil and not fully constructed, while special tombs are fully constructed and placed in reserved areas of public cemeteries.




Additionally, MINALOC acknowledges cremation as another alternative for burial, permitted under current law with proper authorization. However, public cremation facilities are lacking in Rwanda, posing a challenge to wider adoption of this method. Private investment in cremation facilities has been encouraged, but cultural resistance remains a barrier.

Havugimana noted that Rwanda's foreign population, with cultural practices favoring cremation, underscores the need for accessible cineration facilities to accommodate diverse burial customs.

As Rwanda grapples with cemetery scarcity, the proposed law amendment and exploration of alternative burial methods reflect the government's commitment to addressing the issue while respecting cultural diversity and environmental considerations.

BIDEN'S TIK TOK PUTT RAISES EYEBROWS AMIDST LEGISLATION TO BAN THE APP.

04:52, 2024-04-25

When President Joe Biden showcased his putting skills during a campaign stop at a public golf course in Michigan last month, the moment garnered attention on TikTok, the popular social media platform. Forced indoors by a rainstorm, Biden engaged in a friendly putting competition with 13-year-old Hurley “HJ” Coleman IV, with the exchange captured and shared on the app by the Coleman family.

In the video, Biden sinks a putt, followed by Coleman expertly responding with his own successful shot, accompanied by the caption, “I had to sink the rebuttal.” Notably absent were the network television cameras that typically trail the president during public appearances.




However, amidst Biden's engagement with TikTok, he signed legislation on Wednesday that could potentially lead to the banning of the app in the United States. This move has sparked criticism, particularly from avid users of TikTok, which researchers have identified as a primary news source for a significant portion of Americans under the age of 30.

Kahlil Greene, a prominent TikTok user known as the “Gen Z Historian” with over 650,000 followers, expressed concern over what he sees as a contradiction in the Biden administration's stance. “There’s a core hypocrisy to the Biden administration supporting the TikTok ban while at the same time using TikTok for his campaign purposes,” Greene stated.

However, the Biden campaign defends its use of TikTok, asserting that it would be imprudent to disregard any platform where people engage with information about the president. Rob Flaherty, deputy manager of Biden’s reelection campaign, emphasized the necessity of meeting voters where they are in today's fragmented media landscape.




Flaherty noted that the Biden team established relationships with TikTok influencers during the 2020 election and acknowledges the platform's increasing influence as a driver of narratives about the president. The campaign insists that engaging with platforms like TikTok, alongside others such as WhatsApp, Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube, is essential in reaching potential supporters. While opponents of TikTok raise concerns about its Chinese ownership by ByteDance and the potential implications for national security, including data privacy and content manipulation, no concrete evidence has been made public regarding Beijing's influence over the app. Nonetheless, the legislation signed by Biden aims to address these concerns by forcing ByteDance to sell TikTok to a U.S. company within a year or face a national ban.

ByteDance has contested the legality of the law, citing First Amendment concerns, and has vowed to challenge it in court. As debates over TikTok's future in the U.S. continue, Biden's engagement with the platform amid legislative efforts to ban it underscores the complexities surrounding technology, national security, and political strategy in the digital age.

RWANDA'S ZIPLINE DRONE COMPANY CELEBRATES A MILLIONTH DELIVERY.

04:36, 2024-04-25

Zipline, a pioneering drone services delivery company based in Rwanda, has marked a significant achievement in the logistics sector by reaching its one-millionth delivery to customers. The milestone delivery, consisting of two bags of IV fluid transported from a Zipline distribution center in Ghana to a local health facility, underscores the company's commitment to revolutionizing last-mile delivery. Since its inception in Rwanda, Zipline has expanded its operations across four continents, leveraging substantial investments from prominent firms like Sequoia Capital, a16z, and Google Ventures. Keller Rinaudo, the company's chief executive, attributed the milestone to Zipline's unwavering dedication to key markets, particularly healthcare, quick commerce, and food delivery.

President Kagame at the launch of zipline tech in Rwanda




"The three areas where the incentive makes the most sense today are health care, quick commerce, and food," Rinaudo emphasized, highlighting Zipline's strategic partnerships with leading brands and institutions to drive innovation in logistics through autonomous drone technology. Currently, Zipline operates in Rwanda, Ghana, Kenya, Côte d’Ivoire, and Nigeria.

In Rwanda, Zipline's impact on healthcare delivery is profound, with the company responsible for delivering 75 per cent of the country's blood supply outside of Kigali, leading to an 88 per cent reduction in maternal mortality rates due to postpartum hemorrhage. In Kenya, Zipline's collaboration with the Elton John AIDS Foundation has facilitated the efficient delivery of HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment products, empowering individuals to manage their health effectively.

Medical personnel receives the drone delivery




In Nigeria, Zipline's reach extends to over 500 health facilities in Kaduna, more than 350 in Cross River State, and 200 in Bayelsa, demonstrating the company's commitment to addressing healthcare challenges across diverse regions. Across Ghana, Zipline has completed over 540,000 drone delivery flights, transporting essential medical supplies including vaccines, medical products, blood products, and animal health products.

"The achievement of the one millionth delivery milestone underscores dedication to enhancing healthcare outcomes and addressing societal needs across Africa," Rinaudo remarked in a press statement, reflecting on Zipline's mission-driven approach to advancing healthcare access.

As Zipline continues to innovate and expand its reach, the company remains poised to shape the future of healthcare delivery not only on the African continent but also globally. Since commencing operations in 2016, following a groundbreaking partnership with the Rwandan Government, Zipline has been at the forefront of delivering innovation and technology products and services, aligning closely with the country's ambitions of fostering technological advancement and inclusive growth.
















CHINA READYS CREW TO MAN THEIR SPACE STATION AS THEY EYE MEN ON THE MOON BY 2030.

04:22, 2024-04-25

China's space agency is gearing up to send a fresh crew to its burgeoning space station on Thursday, marking another milestone in its ambitious space exploration agenda that eyes lunar missions by 2030. The upcoming Shenzhou-18 mission underscores China's rapid progress in space exploration, despite being excluded from the International Space Station (ISS).

The three-member crew, comprising Commander Ye Guangfu and astronauts Li Cong and Li Guangsu, is poised to relieve the current team at China's Tiangong space station. This mission follows China's independent development of its space station, forged in response to exclusion from the ISS,

largely attributed to geopolitical tensions, notably with the United States.







According to Lin Xiqiang, deputy director of the China Manned Space Agency (CMSA), the Shenzhou-18 crew will engage in a diverse array of tasks during their approximate six-month stint aboard the space station. These include scientific experiments, installation of space debris protection equipment, payload experiments, and efforts to promote science education.

Lin emphasized China's commitment to international collaboration in space endeavors, expressing intentions to welcome foreign astronauts and even space tourists aboard China's space station. "We definitely expect to see astronauts of different identities on China's space station," he stated during a press conference. The lift-off for the Shenzhou-18 mission is scheduled for 1259 GMT from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, situated on the fringes of the Gobi Desert in China's northwest.

China's foray into space exploration began with its first manned mission in 2003, positioning it as the third nation, after the former Soviet Union and the U.S., to independently launch humans into space. While the U.S. space program maintains a considerable advantage in spending, supply chains, and capabilities, China has made notable strides in recent years, including lunar sample returns and rover missions to the far side of the moon.




Meanwhile, the U.S. is reviving its lunar ambitions, aiming to land astronauts on the moon by the end of 2025. Leveraging partnerships with private sector entities like SpaceX and Blue Origin, the U.S. seeks to reclaim its status as the sole country to have put astronauts on the lunar surface.

Currently, only four countries — the U.S., Russia, China, and India — have achieved the feat of landing spacecraft on the moon, underscoring the exclusivity and complexity of lunar exploration endeavors. As China looks to expand its presence in space and beyond, the global stage braces for heightened competition and collaboration in the final frontier.

HAMAS SIGNALS WILLINGNESS TO TRUCE AND POLITICAL TRANSITION WITH THE UNIFICATION OF THE INDEPENDENT PALASTINIAN STATE.

03:49, 2024-04-25

In a surprising turn of events, a top Hamas political official has indicated the Islamic militant group's openness to a truce lasting five years or more with Israel. Khalil al-Hayya, speaking in an interview with The Associated Press on Wednesday, suggested that Hamas would be willing to lay down its weapons and transition into a political party if an independent Palestinian state is established along pre-1967 borders.




"The suggestion that Hamas would disarm appeared to be a significant concession by the militant group officially committed to Israel’s destruction," al-Hayya remarked during the interview.




The remarks from al-Hayya come amidst a deadlock in months of cease-fire negotiations. However, the feasibility of such a scenario remains uncertain, given Israel's steadfast opposition to the creation of a Palestinian state on territories captured in the 1967 Middle East war.

"We want to join the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and form a unified government for Gaza and the West Bank," al-Hayya emphasized, highlighting Hamas's aspirations for political integration.

In the event of certain conditions being met, al-Hayya asserted that Hamas's military wing would dissolve, mirroring the transition of other liberation movements into political entities with national armies upon achieving independence.




"All the experiences of people who fought against occupiers... when they became independent and obtained their rights and their state, what have these forces done? They have turned into political parties," al-Hayya reflected on the potential transition.

While Hamas's position on the prospect of a Palestinian state alongside Israel has evolved over time, with occasional moderation in its public stance, the group's official political program continues to reject any alternative to the full liberation of Palestine.




"While we entertain the idea of a truce and political transition, our ultimate goal remains the full liberation of Palestine," al-Hayya concluded, reaffirming Hamas's long-standing objectives amidst the ongoing diplomatic efforts.

As diplomatic efforts continue to navigate these challenges, the possibility of a lasting peace in the region hangs in the balance, with Hamas's latest overture offering a glimmer of hope amidst the protracted stalemate.

UK ASYLUM SEEKERS AWAIT A 12 WEEKS PROCESSING AFTER UK PARLIAMENT APPROVES THE RWANDA BILL.

03:56, 2024-04-24

After two years of legal battles and political debates, the UK Parliament has finally approved the government's Rwanda bill, marking a significant step towards the implementation of the UK-Rwanda migration deal. However, despite the bill's passage, the engines on the planes bound for Kigali will remain silent for now.

Technically, a flight could take off as soon as 12 days after receiving royal assent, which formally turns the bill into law. However, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak indicated that the practical timeline for the first flight is expected to be later than that, estimating a timeframe of 10 to 12 weeks, likely placing the inaugural flight in late June or early July.




"We acknowledge that the timeline is later than we initially aimed for," stated Prime Minister Sunak on Monday. "But we have consistently emphasized that the processing of asylum seekers will require time."




The approval of the government bill by the United Kingdom’s upper house of parliament on Tuesday, April 23, represents a pivotal milestone for the UK-Rwanda migration deal. The agreement, forged in December in Kigali by Minister of Foreign Affairs Dr. Vincent Biruta and UK Home Secretary James Cleverly, aims to revive the Migration and Economic Development Partnership (MEDP), which was deemed unlawful by the UK Supreme Court in November of the same year.

Under the terms of the deal, individuals who arrive in the UK illegally via small boats will be transferred to Rwanda, where they will have the opportunity to claim asylum.




Despite the approval of the bill, there had been hesitancy in the House of Lords regarding the agreement, with demands for additional safeguards to be incorporated.

With the bill's passage through Parliament, attention now turns to the operationalization of the UK-Rwanda migration deal, which is anticipated to occur in the coming weeks. As both nations navigate the complexities of migration policy and international cooperation, the fate of asylum seekers awaiting processing hangs in the balance, contingent upon the successful implementation of this landmark agreement.
















RWANDA RECORDS A REMARKABLE DECREASE IN MALARIA INFECTIONS, AHEAD OF THE WORLD MALARIA DAY.

03:45, 2024-04-24

As Rwanda gears up to commemorate World Malaria Day on April 25, the nation has reason to celebrate significant strides in the fight against malaria. According to the Rwanda Biomedical Center (RBC), the country has witnessed a remarkable 60% reduction in malaria-related deaths, accompanied by an impressive 88% decrease in malaria cases as of 2023.




Dr. Aimable Mbituyumuremyi, Division Manager of the Malaria, Neglected Tropical Diseases, and Other Parasitic Diseases Division at RBC, highlighted the substantial progress achieved. "In 2016, the country grappled with approximately five million malaria cases," he stated. "However, concerted intervention efforts have slashed these numbers to a mere 600,000 cases by 2023, marking an 88% reduction."

Dr. Mbituyumuremyi further elaborated on the tangible impact of these interventions, noting a staggering 90% reduction in severe malaria cases, from 18,000 in 2016 to just 1,300 in 2023. Moreover, malaria-related fatalities plummeted from over 600 in 2016 to a mere 51 in 2023, representing a remarkable 91% decrease.

One pivotal factor contributing to this success story is the expanded role of community health workers in managing malaria cases. In 2016, these frontline healthcare providers handled only 18% of cases, whereas they now oversee a staggering 60% of malaria cases across the nation.




Emphasis on the indispensable role played by community health workers in timely diagnosis, treatment, and management of malaria cases, revealing that there are now two dedicated workers per village tasked with this critical responsibility can never be downplayed .

Rwanda's approach to malaria control has been multi-faceted, incorporating evidence-based strategies such as information dissemination, distribution of Long-lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs), Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS), and early diagnosis coupled with effective management of malaria cases. Dr. Mbituyumuremyi underscored the effectiveness of extensive IRS campaigns across 12 districts, coupled with LLIN distribution efforts spanning 18 districts, which collectively contributed to a 71% reduction in malaria cases between 2016 and 2021.




Innovative measures have also been adopted to combat malaria, including the introduction of larviciding using drones in 2020. Additionally, an integrated vector management approach has been embraced, involving training for communities and local leaders to identify and mitigate mosquito breeding sites, further bolstering malaria prevention efforts. Despite encountering challenges such as mosquito resistance to insecticides and pesticides, Rwanda remains steadfast in its commitment to malaria elimination by 2030. Aligning with the World Health Organization's global technical strategy for malaria 2016–2030, Rwanda aims to reduce malaria incidence and mortality rates by at least 90% by 2030, alongside the ambitious goal of eliminating malaria in at least 35 countries by the same year.




With Rwanda hosting the 8th Multilateral Initiative on Malaria (MIM) Society Conference from April 21-27, under the theme "Grassroots Mobilization to End Malaria: Invest, Innovate, and Integrate," the nation reaffirms its dedication to fostering global collaboration in malaria research and control. Through concerted efforts and collective action, Rwanda is poised to realize its vision of a malaria-free future, safeguarding the health and well-being of its citizens and communities.

06:12, 2024-04-22

Airbnb is broadening its horizons by extending hosting opportunities to renters, not just homeowners, on its short-term rental platform. The move reflects Airbnb's dedication to inclusivity and economic empowerment, aiming to provide opportunities for renters amidst regulatory challenges in various jurisdictions. Theo Yedinsky, Airbnb's Vice President of Public Policy, emphasized the company's mission to support both landlords and renters in listing their homes on the platform.




"A lot of the early laws that were made limited short-term rental to homeownership," Yedinsky stated, highlighting Airbnb's efforts to challenge existing regulations that restrict renters' participation in short-term rentals.

Yedinsky underscored Airbnb's origins, tracing back to 2007 when co-founders Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia struggled to pay rent in San Francisco and welcomed guests on air mattresses during a design conference to make ends meet. This grassroots beginning informs Airbnb's commitment to democratizing access to its platform for both homeowners and renters alike.




Airbnb recently achieved a significant victory in Virginia, where Governor Glenn Youngkin signed a bill into law requiring localities to issue short-term rental permits to tenants with permission from property owners. This legislative milestone represents a step towards empowering renters to engage in the sharing economy.

The initiative to include renters as hosts on Airbnb comes at a time when homeownership is increasingly out of reach for many Americans, particularly younger generations, amid soaring mortgage rates and living expenses. Yedinsky highlighted the opportunity for disenfranchised and lower-income communities to benefit from Airbnb's platform, providing a pathway to supplemental income.




However, renters seeking to host on Airbnb must obtain permission from their landlords, and regulatory challenges persist in major cities like New York, where restrictions on short-term rentals are tightening.

Rahul Bhaskar, a tech consultant in San Francisco, exemplifies the potential for renters to participate in short-term rentals. Despite renting his two-bedroom apartment, Bhaskar obtained permission from his building management to host on Airbnb, benefiting from the platform's initiatives to support renters in earning additional income.

As Airbnb expands opportunities for renters to host, the company navigates regulatory landscapes and advocates for policies that foster inclusivity and economic empowerment in the sharing economy.

CONTROVERSY ERUPTS OVER UNPUNISHED DOPING CASES INVOLVING CHINESE SWIMMERS.

05:10, 2024-04-22

Revelations of positive doping tests for nearly two dozen Chinese swimmers, which went unpunished, have ignited a heated dispute between the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) and the CEO of the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency (USADA), Travis Tygart, triggering a flurry of accusations and legal threats. The controversy stems from WADA's acknowledgment that it cleared 23 Chinese swimmers who had tested positive for a banned heart medication to compete at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. WADA attributed its decision to contamination of the samples and defended its process, asserting that it acted in good faith and in accordance with due process.




However, Tygart swiftly condemned WADA's handling of the matter, alleging that the organization and Chinese anti-doping authorities had "swept positive tests under the carpet" by failing to adhere to global anti-doping rules. He emphasized the seriousness of the case, particularly regarding the use of trimetazidine (TMZ), a medication known for its performance-enhancing effects and its potential to incur severe penalties under anti-doping regulations.

Tygart highlighted USADA's distinct approach to contamination cases, emphasizing that previous instances did not involve TMZ and underlining the agency's commitment to upholding anti-doping standards. Unlike WADA's handling of the Chinese swimmers' cases, Tygart emphasized that USADA had consistently followed protocol, including provisional suspensions and public disclosure of violations.

The disagreement between WADA and Tygart underscores longstanding tensions between the two entities, rooted in diverging opinions on how to address doping scandals and enforce anti-doping regulations.




Tygart's criticism of WADA's leniency towards Russia following the Sochi Olympics doping scandal in 2014 has fueled ongoing friction between the organizations.

WADA responded to Tygart's accusations by labeling them as "outrageous" and "completely false," dismissing them as politically motivated and asserting that similar contamination cases involving U.S. athletes had been accepted by USADA in the past. The organization emphasized the challenges of conducting investigations in China amid COVID-19-related restrictions and defended its decision not to appeal the case based on legal advice.

The clash between WADA and USADA underscores the complexities and controversies surrounding anti-doping efforts in international sports, raising questions about transparency, accountability, and the enforcement of anti-doping regulations on a global scale. As the dispute unfolds, it underscores the imperative for greater cooperation and transparency in combating doping in sports worldwide.

04:07, 2024-04-22

''BELGIUM ORDERED RWANDA'S QUEEN GICANDA TO LEAVE, WEEKS BEFORE SHE WAS KILLED'', SAYS MINISTER BIZIMANA.

03:40, 2024-04-22

As Rwanda progresses through the solemn 100 days of commemorating the Genocide against the Tutsi, disturbing revelations have emerged shedding light on hidden facts surrounding this tragic chapter in history. Shockingly, it has been disclosed that Belgium ordered Queen Rosalie Gicanda, the last Queen of Rwanda, to depart its territory in 1994, mere weeks before the Genocide against the Tutsi unfolded, despite her critical need for medical attention.




During the commemoration of Gicanda, held on Saturday, April 20, Jean Damascene Bizimana, the Minister of National Unity and Civic Education, unveiled this unsettling truth. Queen Gicanda, the consort of King Mutara III Rudahigwa, met a tragic end at the hands of the genocide perpetrators when she was 66 years old.

Bizimana highlighted that despite Belgium possessing knowledge of the genocidal plans brewing within Rwanda, they instructed Queen Gicanda, who was receiving medical treatment in Nivelle, to leave their territory, even though her visa was still valid. The Minister emphasized that this directive came in February 1994, a crucial period when the preparations for genocide were alarmingly evident.

"Before the Genocide began, Queen Rosalie Gicanda was in Belgium for medical treatment. Her visa was still valid, and Belgium had sufficient information about the preparation of the Genocide," Bizimana asserted.




The Minister referenced a letter dated February 3, 1994, purportedly from the mayor of Nivelle, Maurice Dehu, informing Queen Gicanda of Belgium's decision. The letter mandated her departure from Belgian soil by February 12, 1994, under threat of prosecution and deportation if she disobeyed. Furthermore, Bizimana revealed that despite pleas from medical authorities highlighting the critical nature of Gicanda's treatment, Belgian authorities remained resolute in their stance. Although an extension was informally granted until March 1994, it was not confirmed in writing, leaving Gicanda in a precarious position.

Tragically, Queen Gicanda, resigned to her fate, expressed her intention to return to Rwanda, indicating her compliance with Belgium's demands. "That is the wish of God. I will go back home to see my mother," she said, displaying her unwavering resolve amidst adversity.




Minister Bizimana underscored Belgium's complicity in Gicanda's murder, pointing to documented evidence of their awareness of the impending genocide. He referenced a damning 1997 assessment by the Belgian Senate, which outlined Belgium's knowledge of Rwanda's genocidal plans as early as January 1994.

In a chilling revelation, Bizimana noted that on January 15, 1994, the Belgian Ambassador to Rwanda had alerted his government about the impending genocide. Subsequent reports by Belgian intelligence officers and UN forces in Rwanda further corroborated Belgium's awareness of the looming catastrophe.




Captain Ildephonse Nizeyimana, the individual responsible for ordering Queen Gicanda's execution, faced justice in 2012 when he was convicted of genocide crimes by the UN International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, receiving a 35-year prison sentence.

The commemoration of Queen Rosalie Gicanda serves as a poignant reminder not only of the profound loss suffered by Rwanda but also of the international community's failure to prevent a genocide foretold. As Rwanda mourns the victims of this dark chapter, it stands as a beacon of resilience and remembrance, ensuring that such atrocities are never forgotten nor repeated.

To his supporters, his administration was hailed for its decisive action and unwavering commitment to fiscal discipline. However, his detractors lamented what they perceived as a decline in political and civic freedoms, coupled with Tanzania's increasing isolation on the global stage during his presidency. International observers raised concerns about human rights violations and restrictions on media freedom.




Since assuming office following Magufuli's passing, President Samia Suluhu Hassan has embarked on a path of reform, seeking to address some of the challenges and criticisms that characterized her predecessor's administration. President Suluhu has emphasized the importance of dialogue and inclusivity, signaling a departure from the more confrontational style of governance seen under Magufuli.

While honoring the achievements of Magufuli's tenure, President Suluhu's administration has pledged to uphold democratic principles and promote transparency and accountability. Initiatives aimed at fostering dialogue with opposition parties and civil society organizations have been met with cautious optimism.




As Tanzania navigates this period of transition, the nation continues to grapple with the complexities of balancing the legacy of a transformative leader with the imperative of embracing reform and progress. The commemoration of Magufuli's legacy serves as a reminder of the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead on Tanzania's path towards development and democratic consolidation.

IBUKA RE ECHOS THE NEED FOR INFORMATION ABOUT THE STILL MISSING BODIES OF THE 1994 GENOCIDE VICTIMS.

EVENING WORKOUTS ARE LINKED TO IMPROVED HEALTH FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH OBESITY.

05:10, 2024-04-16

A groundbreaking study conducted by researchers at the University of Sydney in Australia, published in the journal Diabetes Care, reveals that engaging in the majority of daily physical activity during the evening may offer significant health benefits for individuals with obesity. The study comes at a critical time as global rates of obesity continue to rise exponentially. With projections indicating that the number of individuals classified as obese could reach 4 billion by 2050, understanding effective strategies for managing obesity-related health risks is paramount.




According to Angelo Sabag, lead author of the study and a researcher at the Charles Perkins Centre, University of Sydney, obesity poses a significant risk factor for a multitude of chronic illnesses, including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and various types of cancers. To investigate the potential impact of timing on physical activity and health outcomes, Sabag and his team analyzed data from the U.K. Biobank, encompassing nearly 30,000 individuals over the age of 40, all of whom were classified as having obesity. Additionally, approximately 3,000 participants had type 2 diabetes.

Utilizing wearable device data tracking participants' physical activity levels throughout the day for over eight years, researchers were able to discern patterns and correlations between timing of physical activity and health outcomes.




The study yielded compelling results: individuals who engaged in the majority of their aerobic moderate to vigorous physical activity between 6 p.m. and midnight exhibited the lowest risk of premature death and death from cardiovascular disease.




"These findings underscore the importance of considering timing when incorporating physical activity into daily routines, particularly for individuals with obesity," Sabag emphasized.

The implications of this research extend beyond individuals with obesity, offering valuable insights into the optimization of physical activity regimens for overall health and longevity.

As the global health community grapples with the obesity epidemic and its associated health challenges, studies such as this provide valuable guidance for developing targeted interventions and strategies aimed at mitigating the impact of obesity-related conditions.




Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms driving the observed associations between evening physical activity and improved health outcomes. Nonetheless, these findings offer promising avenues for enhancing public health initiatives and promoting healthier lifestyles worldwide.

Despite the launch of more than 300 Iranian munitions, the majority of which were believed to have been launched from inside Iran's territory during a five-hour attack, only "a small number" of ballistic missiles managed to reach Israel.




The military disclosed that around 170 drones, over 30 cruise missiles, and more than 120 ballistic missiles were launched at Israel by Iran overnight Saturday. US officials revealed that over 70 drones and three ballistic missiles were intercepted by US Navy ships and military aircraft. At least three ballistic missiles were shot down using the Aegis missile defense system aboard two guided-missiles destroyers in the eastern Mediterranean.




Additionally, US warplanes intercepted Iranian ordnance. Although the location of these US jets' operation was not disclosed, there are US Navy aircraft carriers and land-based aircraft well within range of the region. President Biden affirmed the US's preparedness to assist Israel in defending against Iranian attacks. He stated, "Thanks to these deployments and the extraordinary skill of our servicemembers, we helped Israel take down nearly all of the incoming drones and missiles."




Britain expressed readiness to intervene using Royal Air Force aircraft in the region, stating that UK jets would intercept any airborne attacks within range of existing missions, as required.

An Israeli military spokesperson also acknowledged France's involvement in blocking the Iranian attacks, stating, "We are working closely with the US, UK, and France who acted tonight. The successful interception of the Iranian missiles underscores the effectiveness of the collaborative efforts between Israel and its allies in countering external threats and safeguarding regional stability.

REMEBERING THE LIVES OF THOSE DROWNED IN LAKE MUHAZI IN 1994.

06:25, 2024-04-15

On Sunday, the 14th of April, mourners from the Eastern province districts of Rwamagana and Nyagatare gathered at Lake Muhazi to honor the memory of those who tragically lost their lives to its waters during the dark days of the Genocide against the Tutsi. With solemn hearts and a shared commitment to remembrance, they laid wreaths and flowers upon the lake's surface, paying homage to the victims whose lives were cut short by unimaginable violence and cruelty. As the horrors of the Genocide against the Tutsi continued to unfold in April 1994, the district of Rwamagana became a scene of unspeakable tragedy. In the face of relentless attacks by Interahamwe militias, Tutsi refugees sought shelter at the Muhazi Commune offices, hoping to find safety within its walls. It was there, amidst the chaos and desperation, that a courageous few dared to resist the tide of hatred and violence.




On the fateful day of April 15-16, as the Interahamwe launched a brutal assault on the commune offices, a small group of Tutsi individuals, armed with just two guns they had accessed from the offices, valiantly fought back. Led by a brave government Tutsi soldier named Kanamugire, they stood their ground against overwhelming odds, determined to protect their fellow refugees and defy their oppressors. Despite their heroic efforts, the attackers eventually overwhelmed them, forcing the survivors to flee for their lives. With no other refuge in sight, they made their way to Lake Muhazi, seeking sanctuary across its waters where the Inknotanyi were believed to be. But their journey to safety was fraught with danger and despair, as they approached the shores of Lake Muhazi, they were intercepted by government soldiers who engaged them in a fierce battle. Outnumbered and outgunned, they fought with all their might, but their ammunition soon ran dry. With no means of defense remaining, they were left vulnerable to the merciless onslaught of their pursuers.




In the final moments of their struggle, as they sought to escape the clutches of their tormentors, tragedy struck once more. The Interahamwe, relentless in their pursuit of destruction, caught up with them at Kavumu and callously drowned them into the depths of Lake Muhazi, condemning them to a watery grave.




''Today, as we gather to remember the victims of Lake Muhazi, we pay tribute to their courage, resilience, and unwavering spirit in the face of unimaginable adversity. Theirs is a story of defiance in the face of despair, of solidarity amidst chaos founded on sectarianism, and of hope in the darkest of times.'' said one of the mourners.

The of honor their memory, let us also reaffirm our commitment to never forget the atrocities of the past and to stand united against the forces of hatred and intolerance.'' Mukandori added

May the souls of those lost to the waters of Lake Muhazi rest in peace, and may their legacy inspire us to build a future rooted in peace, justice, and reconciliation.

ISRAEL ADMITS AND DISCHARGES SOLIDIERS IN THE ATTACK ON AID WORKERS.

12:00, 2024-04-05

In a tragic incident that has sparked global condemnation, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have admitted to mistakenly killing seven aid workers from the World Central Kitchen (WCK) in Gaza on Monday 1 March. The shocking revelation has raised serious questions about the IDF's tactics and accountability in the volatile region.

"The IDF deeply regrets the loss of life in this tragic incident. Our thoughts are with the families of the victims and the World Central Kitchen organization," stated an IDF spokesperson.




The IDF's publication of a report into the killings on Friday, March 5, admitted that the incident violated its own protocols and should never have occurred. However, the WCK has swiftly called for further independent investigations, expressing a lack of trust in the IDF's ability to impartially investigate its own actions in Gaza.

"The IDF's acknowledgment of their mistake is only the first step towards justice. We demand a thorough and independent investigation into this egregious error," declared a spokesperson for the World Central Kitchen.




The IDF has been engaged in efforts to track down and eliminate Hamas militants in Gaza for nearly six months, accusing the group of embedding itself within civilian populations. According to the IDF, its forces identified a gunman in an aid truck on Monday and subsequently identified an additional gunman.

"We deeply regret the tragic loss of life and offer our sincere condolences to the families of the victims. This incident highlights the challenges of operating in a complex and volatile environment like Gaza," explained an IDF official.




An IDF spokesperson revealed to CNN that the unit responsible for the attack mistook "something slung over one of the passenger’s shoulders as a weapon," which later turned out to be a bag. Furthermore, it was confirmed that some of the aid workers who survived the initial strike fled to other vehicles, only to be targeted again.

"The IDF's actions demonstrate a reckless disregard for the safety of humanitarian workers. We demand accountability for this grave error," emphasized a representative from the WCK.

The IDF explained that surveillance drones were unable to discern the WCK logo on the vehicles during the nighttime operation, prompting consideration of measures such as distributing thermal stickers for aid vehicles to prevent similar incidents in the future.

"In light of this tragic incident, we are reviewing our procedures to ensure that such mistakes do not happen again. We remain committed to the safety and security of all individuals in the region," affirmed an IDF spokesperson.




In response to the grave errors, the IDF has dismissed two senior officers over the strikes, including the brigade fire support commander and the brigade chief of staff. The brigade commander and the 162nd Division commander have also faced disciplinary action.

"While we welcome the dismissal of the officers involved, it is imperative that broader systemic changes are implemented to prevent future tragedies," urged the WCK in a statement.

As the international community reacts with outrage to this devastating loss of innocent lives, calls for greater accountability and adherence to humanitarian principles echo across diplomatic corridors. The incident serves as a grim reminder of the urgent need for a peaceful resolution to the conflict in Gaza and underscores the importance of ensuring the safety of humanitarian workers operating in conflict zones worldwide.

In a solemn gesture of solidarity and remembrance, the United States announced a distinguished delegation of government officials to attend the 30th Commemoration (Kwibuka@30) of the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda. Accompanying President Clinton will be a cadre of esteemed officials, including US Ambassador to Rwanda Eric Kneedler, Assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of African Affairs Mary Catherine Phee, Special Assistant to the President and Senior Director for Legislative Affairs Casey Redmon, and Assistant Administrator of the Bureau for Africa, U.S. Agency for International Development Monde Muyangwa. Their presence signifies the enduring partnership between the United States and Rwanda in advancing peace, stability, and prosperity in the region.




The commemoration, slated to begin on April 7th, marks the start of a week-long period of mourning and reflection, coinciding with the 100 days of Kwibuka—the duration of the genocide that claimed over one million lives. Global leaders, including heads of state, will converge to honor the victims and survivors, reaffirming their commitment to the theme of this year's commemoration: Remember, Unite, Renew.

Central to the event is a poignant "Walk to Remember," symbolizing the collective vow to never forget the atrocities of the past while forging a path towards unity, reconciliation, and renewal. Amidst solemn remembrance, the occasion also serves as an opportunity to celebrate Rwanda's remarkable achievements over the past three decades, including strides in national unity, economic growth, and development.




The significance of this year's commemoration is underscored by the persistent threat of genocide denial and hate speech, particularly in the volatile eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Tutsi communities in the area continue to face persecution and violence, with the involvement of militia groups like the FDLR, linked to the genocide in Rwanda. This ongoing crisis has elicited grave concerns within the region and the broader international community. Against this backdrop, the United Nations has reiterated the importance of vigilance and action in preventing further atrocities. The violence in eastern DRC serves as a stark reminder of the dangers posed by hate speech and incitement, especially in regions scarred by a history of genocide. As the world gathers to commemorate Kwibuka30, it is a solemn reminder of the collective responsibility to remember, unite, and renew our commitment to preventing such atrocities from ever happening again.

The 30th commemoration also coincides with a significant milestone in the global recognition of the genocide against the Tutsi. In September 2023, four memorials were added to the UNESCO World Heritage List, marking a historic victory in the fight against genocide denial and revisionism. This acknowledgment underscores the importance of preserving the memory of the victims and safeguarding against the distortion of historical truth.




As global leaders and dignitaries gather in Rwanda to pay tribute to the lives lost and reaffirm their commitment to prevention, the 30th Commemoration of the genocide against the Tutsi serves as a poignant reminder of the enduring legacy of resilience, hope, and unity in the face of unspeakable tragedy.

UN REPORT HIGHLIGHTS URGENT NEED FOR ACTION TO COMBAT FOOD WASTE

03:58, 2024-04-05

In a stark revelation, the UN Environment food index report, initiated in 2022, has unveiled a staggering truth: more than 1.3 billion tons of food are lost annually, from farm to fork, imposing severe strains on vital resources like water. The report paints a troubling picture of inefficiencies and negligence across various stages of food production and consumption, exacerbating global hunger and environmental degradation. A significant portion of this colossal food loss occurs during production and processing stages, with over 500 million tons wasted due to factors such as crop pests, suboptimal harvesting techniques, and inadequate irrigation. Postharvest handling and storage, as well as consumer habits, contribute equally to this crisis, squandering approximately 350 million tons each. Shockingly, these three stages alone constitute nearly three-quarters of all food waste.




However, the report also underscores the immense potential for waste reduction at every stage of the food supply chain. Evidence gathered from waste management entities, particularly in urban centers like Rwanda, highlights that a substantial portion of discarded food remains perfectly edible. Approximately 35% of wasted food is needlessly thrown away by supermarkets, shops, and households, exacerbating the already dire situation. The United Nations has set ambitious Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to halve global food waste at retail and consumer levels per capita by 2030, alongside reducing food loss in production and supply chains. While commendable, this target faces significant challenges. Even if achieved, it might not be sufficient to counteract the rise in total global food waste, given the projected increase in the world population to 8.6 billion by 2030—an additional 800 million people compared to 2020.




This demographic surge intensifies the urgency of addressing food waste. Over 2 billion more individuals are expected to inhabit the planet by 2050, necessitating a 60% increase in food production to sustain them. Alternatively, curbing food waste presents a more immediate and viable solution. Astonishingly, the food lost or wasted in the United States and Europe alone could potentially feed all 800 million people suffering from hunger and undernourishment worldwide. As we confront the reality of a burgeoning global population, the imperative to tackle food waste becomes paramount. Every morsel discarded represents not just a squandered resource, but a missed opportunity to alleviate hunger, mitigate environmental degradation, and promote sustainability. It is incumbent upon governments, businesses, and individuals to heed the warning sounded by the UN report and take decisive action towards a more equitable and sustainable food system. Failure to do so imperils the very future of our planet and its inhabitants.




Food waste and climate change

As though it is not a problem enough every part of the food supply chain releases greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. Energy is used to grow, store, process, transport, and cook the food. In addition, discarded food ending up at landfills also contribute. In addition, meat production (especially beef!) releases huge amounts of methane gas because of farting cows. Methane is a very powerful greenhouse gas with a 84 times higher global warming potential than CO2 (over a 20 years period).

The global food system accounts for up to 30% of greenhouse gas emissions. And food waste is part of this. The carbon footprint of food waste is estimated to be 3.3 billion tons of CO2 equivalents released into the atmosphere a year.

EV GIANT TESLA GIVEN A RUN FOR THEIR MONEY AS BYD RAISES LEVEL.

05:17, 2024-04-04

Founded by metallurgy graduate Wang Chuanfu in 1995, BYD started as a small Chinese company specializing in the production of rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries at a lower cost compared to Japanese competitors.

Fast forward nearly 30 years, and the Shenzhen-based company has evolved into the foremost manufacturer of electric vehicles (EVs) globally, surpassing even the American giant Tesla (TSLA) in pure-play electric car sales during the final quarter of 2023.

Despite this milestone, the competition between the two companies remains fierce, with Tesla reclaiming its leading position in the first quarter of 2024.

According to car news, the most valuable car makers;

Tesla stock was priced at $17 a share when it listed in June 2010. Nearly 14 years later, the company’s shares trade above $166, giving it a market capitalization of about $560 billion, making it the most valuable car company in the world. It’s also among the biggest companies globally by market value.

As for BYD, its $81 billion market cap places it among the top 10 automakers in the world, according to Murthy Grandhi, business fundamentals analyst at Global Data, a data and analytics company in London.




Still, it trails far behind Tesla and other car makers like Toyota (TM) and Stellantis (STLA), a conglomerate created from the 2021 merger of French PSA Group and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles. The group sells cars under 14 brands, including Chrysler, Citroën, Jeep, Maserati and Peugeot.

But BYD has already surpassed BMW and Ford (F) and is catching up to Mercedes-Benz and Ferrari (RACE),







In 2023, Tesla sold around 230,000 more cars than BYD. But the gap has been narrowing from 400,000 in 2022 and 600,000 in 2021.

And in the last quarter of 2023, BYD hit a major milestone: selling more battery electric vehicles (BEVs) than Musk’s company did globally, due in part to a slowdown for Tesla in one of its biggest markets, China, and to a general deceleration in demand for EVs.

However, the Chinese company stumbled in early 2024. It sold only 300,114 BEVs in the first quarter, down from the 525,409 it sold in the final three months of last year.

That drop was big enough for Tesla, which sold 386,810 BEVs in the same period, to retake its former position despite posting plunging sales.

UNDERSTANDING AUTISM AND BREAKING MYTHS TO FOSTER AWARENESS, THIS AUTSIM AWARENESS MONTH.

04:52, 2024-04-04

April marks Autism Awareness Month, a time dedicated to increasing understanding, acceptance, and support for individuals on the autism spectrum. As we embark on this month-long campaign, it's essential to dispel myths, promote accurate information, and advocate for inclusivity. Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a developmental condition characterized by differences in social communication and interaction, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviors. It affects individuals in various ways, ranging from mild to severe, and no two individuals with autism are exactly alike. According to the Center for Disease Control's (CDC) Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring (ADDM) Network, the prevalence of ASD has risen nearly 123% from 2018 to 2022. Based on 2018 data, the ADDM reported that 1 in 150 children was diagnosed with ASD. Now, based on 2022 data, 1 in 68 children is identified as having ASD.

While the numbers show that ASD diagnoses are on the rise, it's difficult to pinpoint why. This rise could be due to increased risk factors, including parents' ages, nutritional factors, political instabilities which have increased access to medical care hard. or it could also be that we have more awareness and better tools to recognize ASD in children.




However here are some of the symptoms;




Parents should pay close attention to their child's developmental milestones. Developmental milestones are skills or tasks that children perform at certain ages to ensure they are developing normally. For example, a three-month old child should make cooing sounds and turn towards the sound of someone's voice. If a child isn't meeting these developmental checkpoints, parents should discuss their concerns with their child's doctor. Certain behaviors, especially those involved with communication (such as not saying their first word by 16 months or not using two-word phrases by 24 months) tend to be alert flags that call for further evaluation.




According to DR Sbarina Kitaka a renown East African pediatrician, doctors might start screening for autism and other development disorders as early as nine months, but signs of autism generally become clearer as a child gets older. Parents can screen their children between 18 and 30 months for ASD with the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers-Revised (M-CHAT-R).

The M-CHAT-R has parents answer 20 questions about their child's behavior, such as whether a child responds to his or her name, makes eye contact, smiles back, and plays pretend. If a parent mostly answers 'no' to these questions, their child could be a risk for ASD.




However not all hope is lost in as much as there is no cure for autism, but identifying someone as being on the autism spectrum doesn't have to prevent him or her from leading a normal life. Early intervention can help children with social difficulties learn tools and behaviors that play to their strengths and allow them to function comfortably.

Important to note is , a non-verbal autistic child might communicate better with pictures, symbols, or gestures instead of words. Other intervention strategies could include modeling, play therapy, or computer instruction. Early intervention is different for every child due to their needs, but by starting early, children will develop the necessary tools to set them up for success as they get older.

Now take these autism facts that you just learned and share them with someone else to boost their knowledge and awareness, too!

Scheduled from April 5th to April 7th, Azoulay's visit holds significant importance in honoring the memory of the victims and fostering remembrance among younger generations.

On Saturday, April 6th, Azoulay will visit the Murambi Genocide Memorial in Nyamagabe District, where she will engage with survivors, site management, and local youth. The memorial, a former technical school turned into a site of tragedy, stands as a testament to the brutality of the genocide, preserving the memory of over 50,000 victims.




Reflecting on UNESCO's commitment to educating future generations about violent histories, Azoulay's visit coincides with the recent inscription of four Rwandan memorial sites, including Murambi, on UNESCO's esteemed World Heritage List. This recognition underscores the global significance of these sites in promoting remembrance and national reconciliation.




"In transmitting this history and paying homage to the victims, we aim to prevent such atrocities from recurring," Azoulay emphasized during her previous visit to the Kigali Genocide Memorial, where over 250,000 victims are interred. She reiterated the crucial role played by memorials across Rwanda in this collective endeavor.

Azoulay's itinerary extends beyond Murambi, as she is expected to participate in the official inauguration of the commemoration week in Kigali on Sunday, April 7th. Furthermore, UNESCO will host a ceremony at its Paris headquarters on the same day, honoring the victims at the initiative of Rwanda's permanent delegation.

During her stay, Azoulay will present the official certificate of inscription of the genocide memorials to the Government of Rwanda, reaffirming UNESCO's solidarity in preserving the memory of the genocide and promoting reconciliation.




The commemoration of the 30th Genocide Memorial serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of remembrance, education, and international solidarity in confronting the horrors of the past and building a more peaceful future. Through initiatives like UNESCO's engagement and the preservation of sites like Murambi, Rwanda continues its journey towards healing and reconciliation.

As Rwanda prepares to mark the 30th commemoration of the Genocide against the Tutsi, President Paul Kagame sheds light on the tumultuous events of 1994, recounting his pivotal role in the liberation struggle during a broadcast on Royal FM and Radio 10.

Speaking candidly, President Kagame reminisced about the challenges faced in the aftermath of the death of Maj. Gen. Fred Gisa Rwigyema, a key figure in the liberation movement, near the Kagitumba border. He stated,

"I was already on my way to join the struggle, albeit delayed due to prior commitments and military course. However, the loss of our leader necessitated my immediate return."




Addressing inquiries regarding the Arusha peace process, President Kagame emphasized the RPF's willingness to engage in dialogue, lamenting the former government's reluctance to embrace true freedom for Rwandans. He cited chilling remarks from Col. Bagosora, signaling a grim determination to unleash havoc upon the nation, as a stark reminder of the urgency of their cause. President Kagame elaborated,

"We were open to talks, but the government at the time was not ready to agree to the total freedom of Rwandans. Col. Bagosora's statement about returning to Rwanda to reign in an apocalypse instilled fear in many, but we were resolute in our determination to continue the fight."




President Kagame elucidated on the resilience of the RPF, highlighting the transformation of the struggle from an RPF endeavor to a nationwide movement. "It ceased to be just our war; it became the people's war. Rwandans, both at home and abroad, rallied behind the cause, providing crucial support and sustenance," he affirmed. "The struggle was no longer confined to the RPF; it became a collective effort of Rwandans from all walks of life. The solidarity and determination of our people fueled our resolve to press on despite the hardships."




Touching on recent political discourse, President Kagame defended the sovereignty of African nations, asserting that external intervention in domestic affairs is unwarranted. He underscored the African people's discernment in determining their leaders, dismissing notions of foreign superiority in governance. "Africans possess the wisdom to hold their leaders to account. Democracy is not a monopoly of the West," President Kagame asserted. "It is imperative that we as Africans assert our independence and chart our own course towards progress and prosperity."




In a moment of introspection, President Kagame affirmed his commitment to democratic principles, expressing readiness to heed the will of the people. "No leader, including myself, should cling to power if they fail to serve their nation effectively. Accountability is paramount," he affirmed. "Leadership is a sacred trust, and it is incumbent upon us to honor that trust by delivering tangible results and upholding the welfare of our citizens."

As Rwanda prepares to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Genocide against the Tutsi, President Kagame's reflections serve as a poignant reminder of the nation's journey from tragedy to triumph, reaffirming Rwanda's resilience and determination to forge a brighter future.

LESSONS FROM TRAGEDY: REFLECTING ON RWANDA'S JOURNEY 30 YEARS AFTER GENOCIDE.

05:22, 2024-04-01

As Rwanda marks the 30th anniversary of the Genocide against the Tutsi, known as Kwibuka, the nation stands as a beacon of resilience, reconciliation, and hope. From the ashes of tragedy, Rwanda has emerged as a testament to the indomitable spirit of its people and the transformative power of unity and forgiveness. As the world observes this solemn occasion, it is imperative to reflect on the lessons that both modern-day Rwanda and the global community can glean from the dark chapters of history.




1. Never Again, Always Remember: At the heart of Kwibuka lies the imperative to remember the victims and honor their memory. Rwanda's commitment to preserving the legacy of the genocide serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of acknowledging and confronting the past. By bearing witness to the atrocities and ensuring that the stories of survivors are heard, Rwanda underscores the necessity of collective remembrance in preventing future atrocities.




2. Embracing Unity in Diversity: One of the most profound lessons from Rwanda's journey is the transformative power of unity in the face of division. In the aftermath of the genocide, Rwanda has embarked on a path of reconciliation and nation-building, transcending ethnic divisions to forge a shared identity grounded in unity and inclusivity. By embracing diversity and fostering a culture of dialogue and understanding, Rwanda has charted a course towards healing and sustainable peace.




3. Justice and Accountability: Rwanda's commitment to justice and accountability led to the establishment of home based solutions like GACACA, that if taken on in the world would solve the backlog of cases rotting in courts of law which stands as a cornerstone of the nation's recovery and reconciliation efforts. Through national and international mechanisms, perpetrators of genocide have been held accountable for their crimes, demonstrating that impunity will not be tolerated. By upholding the principles of justice and the rule of law, Rwanda sends a clear message that reconciliation is inseparable from accountability.




4. Investing in ideology Education and Healing: Education plays a pivotal role in Rwanda's journey towards healing and reconciliation especially with the introduction of initiatices such as ''Ndi Umunya Rwanda'', which would see the unity doctrine passed on to the youngsters. Through such educational programs, memorial sites, and community initiatives, Rwanda is fostering a culture of remembrance and dialogue, ensuring that future generations understand the importance of peace, tolerance, and human rights. By investing in education and healing, Rwanda is laying the groundwork for a more just and compassionate society.




5. Global Solidarity and Prevention: As away to contribute globally to the ''Never Again'', The initiative is not limited to Rwanda but rather to the entire world which would is prone to genocidal ideology. Kwibuka serves as a call to action for the global community to stand in solidarity with survivors and victims of genocide everywhere. By amplifying the voices of survivors, supporting genocide prevention efforts, and promoting peacebuilding initiatives, the world can honor Rwanda's resilience and commitment to never again allowing such atrocities to occur.




As Rwanda commemorates the 30th anniversary of the Genocide against the Tutsi, the lessons learned from its tragic history serve as a guiding light for both the nation and the world. By remembering the past, embracing unity, seeking justice, investing in education, and fostering global solidarity, Rwanda offers a powerful testament to the resilience of the human spirit and the enduring quest for peace and reconciliation.

"There are discussions on the possibility of France cooperating with us, including on nuclear energy, nuclear fuel," stated Maria Luisa Escorel de Moraes, the European head of Brazilian diplomacy, acknowledging the sensitive nature of the matter.

Despite efforts to advance the project, significant delays have been encountered, primarily attributed to budget constraints. The launch of the nuclear submarine is now projected between 2036 and 2037, according to the Brazilian navy.

Previously attributing the incident to a group of university students who allegedly spread news about the glitch through social media channels, Abie Sano reiterated the bank's stance on holding those responsible accountable for their actions.

The software malfunction, which occurred during a routine system update, was promptly addressed by Ethiopia's central bank earlier this month. Assurances were provided that there was no imminent risk to customers or the overall stability of the financial system.




The swift recovery of the majority of the lost funds stands as a testament to the efficiency and resilience of the State-owned Commercial Bank of Ethiopia, as it continues to uphold its reputation as a cornerstone of the nation's financial infrastructure.

A historic occasion was witnessed, as the timbuktoo Africa Innovation Foundation is officially incorporated in Kigali, Rwanda. Representing a bold collaboration between the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), African governments, and the private sector, timbuktoo aims to become the world's largest initiative supporting the innovation ecosystem in Africa.

At the heart of timbuktoo's mission is the establishment of university innovation pods (UniPods) in 13 African cities, serving as hubs for research and development. These UniPods provide aspiring innovators with the space and resources to translate their ideas into viable products and profitable ventures. Notably, the UniPod at the University of Rwanda exemplifies this vision, offering a platform for innovation and entrepreneurship to flourish.




In addition to UniPods, timbuktoo has dedicated a mantle to creating thematic hubs across the continent, focusing on areas such as FinTech, EdTech, AgriTech, and GreenTech. These hubs are to serve as centers of excellence, providing comprehensive support for ecosystem and venture building. In 2024, as three hubs are set to launch, beginning with a FinTech in Lagos, HealthTech in Kigali, and AgriTech in Accra.

Crucially, timbuktoo will provide early-stage risk capital to empower Africa's youth in their entrepreneurial endeavors. This support will be facilitated through a fund based in the Kigali International Financial Centre, leveraging Rwanda's status as a leading financial hub in Africa. The journey of timbuktoo began with its global launch at the 54th World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where it garnered support from leaders including President Paul Kagame of Rwanda and President Nana Akufo-Addo of Ghana. Professor Yemi Osinbajo, former Vice President of Nigeria, assumes the role of Guardian of the Foundation, ensuring its alignment with its mission and goals. His commitment to driving change in Africa underscores the transformative potential of timbuktoo. Ms. Ahunna Eziakonwa, UNDP's Assistant Secretary General and Director of the Bureau for Africa, expressed solidarity and support for timbuktoo's mission. UNDP remains committed to providing development services to the Foundation and empowering Africa's youth to lead the startup revolution.

Rwanda's Minister of ICT and Innovation, Ms. Paula Ingabire, welcomed the establishment of timbuktoo, emphasizing the importance of fostering a vibrant pan-African innovation ecosystem. Today's milestone in Kigali marks the beginning of a new era of opportunity and progress for Africa.

TRAGEDY STRIKES: BALTMORE'S FRANCIS SCOTT KEY BRIDGE COLLAPSE CLAIMS LIVES.

06:15, 2024-03-27

In a devastating turn of events early Tuesday morning, the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, Maryland, collapsed following a collision with a cargo ship, leaving six individuals missing and presumed dead. As the search and rescue efforts transition into recovery operations, the grim reality of the situation begins to unfold.

Halted Search Amid Dangerous Conditions

Overnight, search and recovery operations were suspended due to hazardous conditions, including precarious sections of the collapsed steel bridge and dangling shipping containers from the cargo ship. Despite the challenges, divers are set to resume their efforts Wednesday in hopes of locating the missing individuals. Maryland Governor Wes Moore reiterated the commitment to employing every available resource to bring closure to the affected families.




Hazmat Threat Looms

The US Coast Guard is now faced with the daunting task of assessing the potential hazmat threat posed by damaged shipping containers onboard the crashed vessel. Teams are meticulously inspecting the ship's manifest to identify any materials that may pose health risks, intensifying the complexities of the recovery operation.




Investigation Underway

The National Transportation Safety Board has taken charge of the investigation, aiming to gather crucial evidence to understand the circumstances leading to the tragic incident. While initial reports suggest no foul play, authorities remain vigilant in their pursuit of answers.

Heartbreaking Details Emerge

As the identities of the missing individuals slowly emerge, stories of loss and anguish begin to surface. Among those unaccounted for is Miguel Luna, a construction worker from El Salvador, described as a devoted husband and father who has called Maryland home for nearly two decades. Additionally, two Guatemalans and an undisclosed number of individuals from Mexico remain missing, compounding the international scope of the tragedy.

Ship Malfunction Preceded Collision

Preliminary findings indicate a sudden blackout of engine and electrical power on the cargo ship just moments before the collision. While emergency measures were initiated, the timing proved catastrophic, resulting in the tragic collision with the bridge.




Long Road to Recovery

As the nation grapples with the aftermath of the collapse, attention turns to the daunting task of rebuilding the Key Bridge. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg acknowledges the substantial time and resources required for restoration, emphasizing the need for federal support in the endeavor.

Impact on Supply Chains

The closure of the vital shipping port in Baltimore reverberates across supply chains, with significant disruptions expected. As efforts to clear the channel and reopen the port commence, the extent of the economic repercussions remains uncertain.

The collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge stands as a poignant reminder of the fragility of infrastructure and the profound human toll of such tragedies. As communities mourn the loss of lives and grapple with the aftermath, solidarity and support become paramount in the journey toward healing and recovery.

PARLIAMENT TASKS MINUBUMWE WITH ADDRESSING CHALLENGES FACED BY GENOCIDE SURVIVORS.

04:27, 2024-03-21

As Rwanda is set for the 30th Genocide memorial, a significant development aimed at bolstering support for vulnerable survivors of the Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda, Parliamentarians have directed the Ministry of National Unity and Civic Engagement (MINUBUMWE) to tackle pressing issues including medical care, education, shelter, and poverty alleviation. The directive comes following the presentation of a comprehensive report by the Commission of Unity of Rwandans, Human Rights, and Combating Genocide. The report, which unveiled its findings on Wednesday, March 20, shed light on the current conditions of vulnerable Genocide survivors across the country. Conducted during a ten-day trip from October 9 to 18, 2023, the assessment aimed to monitor the well-being of survivors and evaluate the adequacy of support services available to them.




MP Veneranda Nyirahirwa, chairperson of the commission, emphasized the significance of the tour, which sought to closely examine the lives of vulnerable survivors and gauge the effectiveness of existing support mechanisms. While acknowledging the strides made in assisting survivors over the past 29 years, Nyirahirwa underscored the urgent need for improvement in critical areas identified by the survivors themselves. Among the challenges highlighted in the report are barriers to accessing essential healthcare services, delays in obtaining identification numbers, mental health concerns, insufficient financial assistance, and shortages of adequate housing. Furthermore, the commission noted deficiencies in preserving evidence and testimonies of the Genocide, as well as in maintaining historical monuments—a crucial aspect of ensuring the accurate recording of Rwanda's history.




In response to these pressing issues, Jean Damascene Bizimana, the Minister of National Unity and Civic Engagement, outlined ongoing efforts to address them. These initiatives include housing projects aimed at providing secure accommodation for survivors, as well as enhancements to history education programs to ensure comprehensive coverage of Rwanda's past, particularly regarding the Genocide against the Tutsi. Despite the existence of unity and reconciliation clubs in secondary schools, Nyirahirwa emphasized the need for further improvements, citing inadequate teaching materials on Rwanda's history. Efforts to bolster these educational resources are crucial in fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of Rwanda's history among the younger generation.




However, challenges persist, including budgetary constraints and coordination issues among various institutions tasked with supporting survivors. Addressing these systemic obstacles will require concerted efforts from all stakeholders to ensure the effective implementation of support programs and initiatives. With the six-month deadline set for implementing measures to address the challenges faced by vulnerable survivors, there is a renewed sense of urgency to prioritize their well-being and ensure that their needs are met adequately. The commitment demonstrated by Parliamentarians and government officials signals a collective determination to uphold the rights and dignity of Genocide survivors, reaffirming Rwanda's ongoing journey towards reconciliation, healing, and unity.
