''TRUMP IS NOT IMMUNE FROM CRIMINAL PROSECUTION'' SAYS THE APPEALS COURT.

16:00, 2024-02-06

In a unanimous ruling on Tuesday 6 Feb, a federal appeals court asserted that former President Donald Trump is not immune from criminal prosecution for his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. The three-judge appeals panel firmly rejected Trump’s contention that he could not be charged due to his status as president at the time of the alleged crimes.




“We cannot accept that the office of the Presidency places its former occupants above the law for all time thereafter,” the panel stated in the ruling from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

“For the purpose of this criminal case, former President Trump has become citizen Trump, with all of the defenses of any other criminal defendant,” the panel clarified in a 57-page opinion. “But any executive immunity that may have protected him while he served as President no longer shields him against this prosecution.”




The decision marks another significant legal setback for Trump, who is currently the leading contender for the Republican presidential nomination.

"It's a critical ruling reaffirming the fundamental principle that no one is above the law," said a legal expert familiar with the case. It is anticipated that Trump will swiftly petition the Supreme Court to overturn the ruling or request a rehearing of the case by the full judicial lineup of the appeals court.




"President Trump respectfully disagrees with the DC Circuit’s decision and will appeal it in order to safeguard the Presidency and the Constitution," said Trump campaign spokesman Steven Cheung.

Trump's immunity claim pertains to the criminal election interference case being prosecuted by Department of Justice special counsel Jack Smith in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C. Smith has charged Trump with four counts related to attempts to overturn his electoral defeat by President Joe Biden in 2020, culminating in the January 6, 2021, Capitol riot where a mob of Trump supporters disrupted a joint session of Congress.




Trump, who has pleaded not guilty, faces charges tied to his encouragement of the Capitol riot and his efforts to pressure then-Vice President Mike Pence to reject Electoral College results.

"We firmly believe that Mr. Trump's actions were within the boundaries of the law and his constitutional authority," said one of Trump's attorneys. Trump's legal team argued three points to the appeals panel in claiming presidential immunity from the charges, all of which were rejected by the panel as inadequate defenses.

The ruling has profound implications for the prosecution of former presidents and underscores the principles of accountability and rule of law in the United States.

A RAY OF HOPE SHINES ; Mutuelle de Santé SET TO COVER CANCER, KIDNEY AND PHYSIO TREATMENTS IN 2025.

15:54, 2024-02-06

In a significant move towards enhancing healthcare accessibility and inclusivity, the Rwandan government has unveiled plans to integrate specialized medical services into its community-based health insurance scheme (CBHI), popularly known as Mutuelle de Santé. This initiative, slated to commence in 2025, aims to address longstanding issues of inadequate access to critical medical services, particularly for vulnerable populations such as people with disabilities and the elderly.




The decision to expand the scope of services covered by Mutuelle de Santé comes in response to concerns raised in the report of the National Commission for Human Rights for the fiscal year 2022/2023. Among the highlighted issues were the insufficient access to specialized medical care and the exclusion of certain treatments from the insurance coverage.

Health Minister Sabin Nsanzimana emphasized the government's commitment to inclusivity in healthcare, stating,

"For us as the Ministry of Health, we wish to include all possible services in the Mutuelle de Santé health package." However, limited resources have historically constrained the breadth of coverage. To address this challenge, a collaborative effort between the Ministry of Health and the Rwanda Social Security Board (RSSB) has been initiated to bolster the capacity of the fund.




One of the key areas earmarked for inclusion in the expanded coverage is specialized medical services such as cancer treatment and kidney transplants. These services, which were previously inaccessible to many due to financial constraints, will now become accessible to a broader segment of the population under the CBHI scheme. Additionally, assistive devices, including prostheses, are slated to be covered, ensuring that individuals requiring such devices can access them without financial burden.

Louise Kanyonga, Deputy Chief Executive Officer of RSSB, underscored the success of the CBHI scheme, noting that it covered over 90% of Rwandans in the previous year. Despite this achievement, sustaining the scheme's financial viability remains a pressing concern. Kanyonga cautioned that without adequate financing mechanisms, the scheme could revert to a deficit state, jeopardizing the gains made in healthcare coverage.




The infusion of additional resources into Mutuelle de Santé has been instrumental in bridging the gap between liabilities and assets, thereby enabling the scheme to operate with a surplus. This surplus has facilitated the expansion of service coverage and the provision of essential health services to members. However, sustaining this positive trajectory necessitates a concerted effort to enhance financing mechanisms and ensure the long-term sustainability of the scheme.

In 2023 alone, Mutuelle de Santé collected Rwf85 billion in contributions, with Rwf75 billion disbursed in benefits to cover healthcare services for scheme members. The tangible impact of these investments is reflected in improved access to healthcare services and better health outcomes for Rwandans across the country.




Looking ahead, the government's commitment to inclusive healthcare through the integration of specialized medical services into the CBHI scheme heralds a new era of healthcare accessibility and equity in Rwanda. By addressing the needs of marginalized populations and bolstering the financial sustainability of the scheme, Rwanda reaffirms its dedication to advancing universal health coverage and ensuring the well-being of all its citizens.

STILL UNCOVERING THE TRAGEDY: 700 MORE 1994 GENOCIDE REMAINS DISCOVERED IN HUYE.

13:50, 2024-02-05

In a somber turn of events, the search for the remains of victims of the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Huye District has intensified, revealing a heart-wrenching total of 714 bodies under houses. Ibuka, the umbrella organization for Genocide survivors, shared this distressing update, shedding light on the ongoing efforts to bring closure to the families affected.




Theodate Siboyintore, Ibuka’s representative in Huye District, provided insights into the escalating numbers during an interview with The New Times. The search, which commenced in October 2023, initially uncovered 313 bodies on the property of Jean Baptiste Hishamunda and Seraphine Dusabemariya, a father and daughter duo. However, as of February 4, the count has surged to a staggering 714. An additional 401 remains were discovered in the neighboring plot owned by Mediatrice Uwimana.




The disturbing revelation has not only brought to light the extent of the tragedy but has also led to legal actions. The Rwanda Investigation Bureau (RIB) reported the arrest and remand of Uwimana and five others for concealing information about the victims' remains. The individuals currently remanded include 86-year-old Hishamunda, Dusabemariya (61), Petero Habimana (89), Mariani Musasangohe (50), and Marie Josee Uwabega (53), while Sifa Nyirakiromba (68) was granted bail in the same case.




The discovery unfolded in October 2023 when workers, constructing a fence around Hishamunda's compound in Ngoma sector, stumbled upon six bodies. Subsequent exhumation efforts, including the demolition of the main residential house, revealed additional victims. The area, formerly inhabited by soldiers of the genocidal regime, included Hishamunda's son, currently serving a prison sentence for genocide crimes. Despite his guilty plea, crucial information regarding the victims' remains was withheld.




Dusabemariya, who inherited the land from Hishamunda, initiated landscaping work that ultimately led to the discovery of the remains. Notably, Dusabemariya, Musangangohe, and Uwabega are children of Hishamunda, while Habimana and Uwimana are Dusabemariya's neighbors. The unfolding tragedy exposes the deep scars left by the genocide, emphasizing the importance of continued efforts to unveil the truth and seek justice for the victims. It should be remembered that since the wake of the 1994 Genocide against Tutsi to date information on such mass graves was acquired from eyewitnesses and some perpetrators who confessed their wrong doing and indicated their whereabouts. Initially the government of Rwanda had proposed a new technology that would help to discover the remaining mass graves but would still rely on sourced information of which with holding it is a crime punishable by law.

NAMIBIA EMBRACES NEW LEADERSHIHP IN MBUMBA AS THEY STILL MOURN FALLEN GEINGOB.

13:07, 2024-02-05

In a swift and solemn transition, Namibia found itself with a new leader, Nangolo Mbumba, just hours after the passing of its president, Hage Geingob. President Geingob, aged 82, succumbed to his battle with cancer on Sunday while undergoing medical treatment in the capital, Windhoek.

A prominent figure in Namibia's struggle for independence, Geingob had disclosed his cancer diagnosis to the public a month ago. Describing the departed president as a "liberation icon," Vice-President Nangolo Mbumba paid tribute to Geingob's leadership and credited him as the chief architect of the nation's constitution.




Mbumba wasted no time assuming the presidency, taking the oath of office in a hastily arranged ceremony at the state house just 15 hours after Geingob's death. During the ceremony, Mbumba assured the nation, stating, "I am not going to be around for the elections, so don't panic," hinting at the upcoming elections later this year.




Reflecting on Geingob's legacy, Mbumba acknowledged the stability and calmness in the nation, crediting it to the late president's leadership. "I take on this heavy mantle cognizant of the weight of responsibility," Mbumba added.

Geingob's death came after a recent trip to the United States for a "two-day novel treatment for cancerous cells." Although the exact cause of death was not disclosed, his deteriorating health had been a matter of public concern.

Namibian radio has become a platform for people to share fond memories of Geingob, remembering him as a visionary and a jovial personality who could effortlessly share a joke. Leaders worldwide have expressed their condolences, with South African President Cyril Ramaphosa describing Geingob as "a towering veteran of Namibia's liberation from colonialism and apartheid."




Hage Geingob, a long-serving member of the Swapo party, played a crucial role in leading the movement against apartheid South Africa. His towering presence, deep gravelly voice, and commitment to freedom made him a respected figure not only in Namibia but across the globe.

After 27 years in exile, where he lived in Botswana, the US, and the UK, Geingob returned to Namibia in 1989, a year before the country gained independence. As Namibia mourns the loss of its leader, the nation is left with the task of continuing the journey toward building an inclusive society, a goal President Geingob had passionately advocated for throughout his political career.

12:40, 2024-02-05

In a momentous development for the residents of Kigali City's Mageragere sector in the Nyarugenge district, the Business Development Fund (BDF) has resumed operations, bringing renewed hope and opportunities for the community. The announcement came on January 27, 2024, following the completion of the "Umuganda rusange" in Mageragere, where the BDF reopened its offices and extended health insurance (Mutuel de sante) to 947 individuals facing challenges in covering their medical expenses.




Muhayimana Paul, a resident of Mageragere, expressed gratitude to the BDF for providing health insurance to those who were previously unable to afford it. He remarked, "We thank BDF for covering the costs of health insurance for the remaining members of our community who were unable to pay for themselves. We're glad and grateful to the Rwandan government and the BDF for coming back here to aid people."




The absence of the BDF had posed challenges for the region, according to Mukamana, another resident. She mentioned the setbacks faced due to the lack of development support but expressed hope for positive change with the BDF's return, particularly in empowering youth to access financing. She stated, "I'm hoping that the BDF would work with our local leaders to encourage our youth to apply for bank loans. Thus, I believe that youth development is just getting started as long as BDF is back here."

Hategekimana Silas, the executive secretary of the Mageragere sector, highlighted the importance of BDF's presence, especially since 74% of residents are engaged in agriculture and animal husbandry. He said, "We are happy to have BDF join us in our mission to support our residents' growth and success. The government's effort to end poverty among its residents is essential to their growth, the provision of services, and their general well-being."




BDF CEO Vincent Munyeshyaka, in his speech, reaffirmed the organization's goals and target audience. He stated, "Our primary goal is to assist those who own small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in obtaining financing." Munyeshyaka expressed appreciation for the collaborative relationships with national banks and Saccos, emphasizing the support BDF provides in obtaining collateral for loans.

The Business Development Fund (BDF) Ltd, established in 2011 by the Government of Rwanda and the Development Bank of Rwanda (BRD), aims to support Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in accessing finance and advisory services. The reopening of BDF's operations in Mageragere signifies a positive step towards economic empowerment, community development, and improved well-being for the residents.

"IN MEMORIAM: HONORING RWANDA'S UNKNOWN SOLDIER – A SYMBOL OF SACRIFICE AND UNITY"

08:32, 2024-02-05

At the heart of the National Heroes’ Mausoleum in Remera, Kigali, stands a towering tribute to the unsung heroes of Rwanda – the tomb of the Unknown Soldier. This solemn memorial represents the thousands of fallen soldiers who gave their all in the fight for freedom and liberation, leaving an indelible mark on the nation's history.

The Unknown Soldier holds a unique place among Rwanda's national heroes, classified into three categories – Imanzi, Imena, and Ingenzi – by the Chancellery for Heroes, National Orders, and Decorations of Honour (CHENO). Maj Gen Fred Rwigema and the Unknown Soldier stand as Imanzi, supreme heroes recognized for their outstanding achievements through supreme sacrifice.




Nicolas Rwaka, the Director of Research at CHENO, explains that the Unknown Soldier embodies the core values of integrity, patriotism, sacrifice, and proven courage or bravery. These values serve as a beacon, preserving the spirit of a nation that emerged from one of its darkest chapters. Preserving the memory of the Unknown Soldier is paramount, according to Rwaka, as it honors the sacrifices made by fallen soldiers. The monument becomes a source of inspiration for future generations, a reminder of the resilience and determination that shaped Rwanda's destiny.

For the youth, the Unknown Soldier holds a profound significance. Galina Isimbi, a university student, sees the monument as a reminder of sacrifice and the ultimate price paid for Rwanda's freedom. She emphasizes that the absence of a specific name signifies the equal value of each sacrifice and the universality of the cause.




Manzi Keith, an 18-year-old student, believes that the Unknown Soldier serves as an inspiration for the younger generation to stand against injustice. He sees the sacrifices made by these unnamed heroes as a driving force behind the desire for a better and more prosperous Rwanda.

Motorcyclist Patrick Hagumagatsi, passing by the mausoleum daily, is reminded of the bravery and determination required to protect his country. It instills in him a sense of duty to contribute to Rwanda's well-being and progress.

Flora Umugwaneza, a procurement officer, perceives the Unknown Soldier as a symbol of unity and resilience. The monument brings people together, transcending backgrounds, as they pay homage to those who fought for their freedom. Umugwaneza emphasizes that the Unknown Soldier reminds them of the shared history that unites Rwanda as one nation.




In the face of the Genocide against the Tutsi in 1994, Rwanda has emerged as a nation transformed, guided by the values instilled by heroes like the Unknown Soldier. These values continue to resonate within the hearts of the younger generation, witnessing the nation's remarkable journey of recovery and renewal.

Russian President Vladimir Putin seems to revel in the face of adversity as he proudly boasts about Russia's ability to withstand international sanctions and maintain economic resilience. Contrary to expectations, Russia has adeptly navigated the extensive sanctions imposed by Western nations. The adaptability displayed by Russia on the economic front raises questions about the efficacy of the sanctions strategy employed by the West.




While the immediate economic outlook for Russia seems robust, the longer-term horizon appears clouded with uncertainty. As the second anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine approaches, questions arise about the sustainability of Russia's economic resilience and the potential consequences of prolonged isolation. The reliance on oil and diamond exports, coupled with restricted access to advanced military technology, raises concerns about the long-term viability of Putin's strategy.




Putin's defiance and Russia's economic resilience have global implications. The ability of a nation to withstand international sanctions challenges the conventional wisdom that such measures can swiftly cripple a country's economy. This poses a dilemma for Western powers as they grapple with the effectiveness of their approach and consider the broader geopolitical ramifications of a resilient Russia.




Vladimir Putin's boasting over Russia's resistance to international sanctions presents a complex narrative. While the short-term gains are evident, the long-term outlook remains uncertain. As the world watches the geopolitical chess game unfold, the resilience of the Russian economy raises important questions about the effectiveness of sanctions as a tool of diplomatic leverage and the evolving dynamics of global power.

BELGIUM AND RWANDA STRENGTHEN BILATERAL TIES: NEW 5 YEAR COORPERATION AGREEMENT UNVEILED

07:55, 2024-01-31

On January 30, 2024, the Government of Rwanda, represented by Dr. Uzziel Ndagijimana, the Minister of Finance and Economic Planning (MINECOFIN), and the Kingdom of Belgium, represented by Heidy Rombouts, Director General of Development Cooperation at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Development Cooperation, signed a groundbreaking bilateral cooperation agreement for the period 2024-2029. The signing ceremony, held at the MINECOFIN offices, marked a significant milestone in the enduring partnership between the two nations, setting the stage for collaborative efforts in key sectors vital for Rwanda's socio-economic advancement.




This being valued at EUR 95 million (approximately Frw 131 billion), the new cooperation program strategically allocates resources across crucial sectors, emphasizing continuity and impact. The sectors include agriculture, urbanization, health, and public finance management. The program is an evolution of the ongoing cooperation program (2019-2024), with both nations demonstrating their joint commitment to addressing global challenges and fostering sustainable growth.




The implementation of the program is expected to begin July 2024 and will be a joint effort, involving MINECOFIN, technical ministries and agencies, and Enabel, the Belgian development agency. This collaborative approach ensures effective utilization of resources and maximizes the impact of the program. The initiative is part of a broader Team Europe approach, aligning with the development goals of other EU partners.




While speaking at the event, minister Ndagijimana highlighted the significance of the new program, emphasizing its crucial role in sectors such as agriculture, health, urbanization, and public finance management. He described the agreement as a "crucial stride forward" that reaffirms both nations' dedication to achieving tangible progress across diverse sectors of engagement.




"The latest program represents a crucial stride forward, reaffirming our dedication to vital sectors such as agriculture, health, urbanization, and public finance management—a cornerstone for Rwanda's socio-economic advancement. This agreement underscores the sustained collaboration between our two nations, a partnership that has consistently delivered tangible progress across diverse sectors of our engagement," said Minister Ndagijimana.




In addition, director Heidy Rombouts expressed pride in renewing Belgium's commitment to sustainable development in collaboration with Rwanda. She commended Rwanda's ambitious agenda, particularly in healthcare, food systems transformation, and the development of climate-smart cities.




"With this new program, Belgium and Rwanda renew their longstanding joint commitment to sustainable development. I am proud to stand here as a partner to Rwanda’s ambitious agenda on the access to healthcare, the transformation towards sustainable food systems, and the development of climate-smart inclusive cities," said Director Rombouts.

The program's allocation reflects a strategic focus on key sectors which are:




Health (€30 million): Emphasis on health system strengthening and improving quality healthcare for all, with a particular focus on sexual and reproductive health and the fight against gender-based violence, 




Agriculture (€25.5 million): Directly addressing the challenge of increasing access to and consumption of quality food for the growing population through the development of sustainable, resilient, and inclusive agricultural value chains.




Urbanization (€25.5 million): Supporting the development of sustainable and attractive satellite cities to enhance living conditions, especially for vulnerable populations, contributing to a socio-economic and environmental ecosystem that is inclusive and climate-proof.




The signing of the new bilateral cooperation agreement marks a significant chapter in the enduring partnership between Rwanda and Belgium. With a strategic focus on key sectors, both nations reaffirm their commitment to sustainable development, setting the stage for collaborative efforts that aim to address pressing global challenges and foster socio-economic advancement in Rwanda. This partnership exemplifies the potential of international cooperation in creating positive and lasting impacts on communities worldwide.

" REMEMBERING THE POST, SHAPING THE FUTURE: A REFLECTION ON THE HOLOCAUST REMEBRANCE DAY EVENT IN KIGALI "

08:12, 2024-01-29

January 25, marked a solemn yet significant day at the Kigali Genocide Memorial, where the Jewish community in Rwanda, along with the Israeli Embassy, the Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany, and the United Nations Office in Kigali, gathered to commemorate Holocaust Remembrance Day. The event not only paid tribute to the 6 million Jews brutally murdered by the National Socialist Party [The Nazis] under Adolf Hitler but also drew poignant parallels to the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda.




In a world still grappling with the shadows of the past, the annual event seeks to rekindle the flame of #NeverAgain, alerting the globe to the persistent specters of anti-Semitism, genocidal denial, and their evolution into modern-day terrorism. Dignitaries from various nations, the United Nations, and the AEGIS Trust Board, along with members of the Jewish community, attended, emphasizing the universal importance of remembering and learning from history.

Israeli Ambassador H.E Einat Weiss, speaking passionately at the event, said, "Full-fledged violence was carried out in front of the international community where some people seemed less important than others, other lives were more valuable than others, acts that should never happen ever again." She echoed the sentiment that such acts must never happen again, urging collective vigilance against discrimination and violence.




The historical significance of the Holocaust, marked by events like Kristallnacht in 1938, propelled actions such as Britain's Kinder transport program, which rescued 10,000 children, mostly Jewish. The invasion of Poland in 1939 and the establishment of ghettos demonstrated the horrifying conditions faced by Jewish communities, foreshadowing the Wannsee Conference's sinister plan for mass deportations and extermination.




Ambassador Heike Uta Dettmann, representing Germany in Rwanda, emphasized the importance of remembrance coupled with drawing lessons from the past. She said, "Remembrance is important. But without drawing lessons learned from our past, remembrance will remain simply that: the past. Germany acknowledges this historical responsibility. 'Never again' must actively be shaped every day."




The event's context intertwined with the ongoing Middle East conflict, particularly the October 7th attack by Hamas militants. The Ambassador of Germany linked these events, highlighting the global importance of actively shaping a future free from violence, discrimination, and genocide.

Also speaking at the event the UN resident Coordinator said that, ''As we reflect on this emotionally charged event, let us heed the lessons of history, working together to build a world where the atrocities of the past remain memories, and the call of #NeverAgain becomes a shared commitment for generations to come.''

RWANDA'S REMARKABLE TOURISM RESURGENCE :DOUBLING RWANDAIR FLEET SPARKS TOURISM BOOM

15:11, 2024-01-23

In a testament to resilience and strategic recovery efforts, Rwanda has not only weathered the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic but has emerged stronger, with a burgeoning tourism sector. Prime Minister Edouard Ngirente, speaking during the National Dialogue-Umushyikirano on January 23, 2024, highlighted the remarkable surge in tourist arrivals, attributing much of the success to the expansion efforts of RwandAir.




Efforts invested in recovering from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic included a significant milestone – the doubling of RwandAir's fleet. Prime Minister Ngirente expressed pride in the strategic decision to expand the national carrier, stating that the move played a pivotal role in revitalizing the tourism sector.




The impact of doubling the RwandAir fleet was immediately evident, with a nearly tripled influx of tourists within a span of just two years. In 2021, the number of tourists to Rwanda stood at 521,000. Fast forward to 2023, and that figure had skyrocketed to an impressive 1.4 million. This surge underscores not only the successful recovery from the challenges posed by the pandemic but also the resilience of Rwanda's tourism industry.




Following the tumultuous period of the COVID-19 pandemic, RwandAir demonstrated agility and strategic foresight. The airline resumed flights and, crucially, expanded its route network to include popular destinations such as Paris, London, Doha, and others. These new routes not only catered to the growing demand for travel but also showcased Rwanda as an attractive and accessible destination.




RwandAir's commitment to recovery wasn't limited to passenger flights. Recognizing the evolving needs of global trade, the airline also launched cargo services. This move played a significant role in the overall tourism resurgence, showcasing Rwanda's versatility and adaptability in responding to dynamic market demands.

“RwandAir resumed flights after Covid-19 pandemic and opened new routes to different destinations including Paris, London, Doha, and others. RwandAir also launched services to transport cargo. This played a big role in increasing visitors coming to Rwanda, after Covid-19 pandemic, from 521,000 in 2021 to 1.4 million tourists as of September last year [2023]. This was a drastic increase within 18 months,” Ngirente said




Prime Minister Ngirente affirmed the government's commitment to further invest in RwandAir, recognizing its pivotal role in boosting tourism and contributing to the national economy. By enhancing the national flag carrier's service provision, the government aims to continue positioning Rwanda as a premier destination for both leisure and business travelers.




“In partnership with the private sector, the government will continue to increase infrastructure to boost tourism and facilitate hosting of Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions (MICE) events in the efficient way you [President Kagame] have requested of us,” he added.

As revealed by Frank Murangwa, Director of Destination Marketing at Rwanda Convention Bureau, in 2023, Rwanda generated a record $91 million from 157 summits and events that attracted over 67,000 delegates.

The impressive feat not only underscores the sector’s post-pandemic recovery but also positions it as a pivotal force propelling Rwanda towards sustained economic development.

RWANDA INSPECTORATE CALLS FOR SUSTAINABLE MEAT PACKAGING TO ENHANCE SAFETY AND QUALITY

07:27, 2024-01-23

Amidst a move towards promoting sustainability and ensuring the safety and quality of meat products, the Rwanda Inspectorate, Competition and Consumer Protection Authority (RICA) has issued a directive urging the discontinuation of the use of paper bags and non-biodegradable sacks for packaging meat across the country. This initiative aligns with the 2010 Ministerial Order on the transport and trade of meat, specifically targeting the enhancement of hygiene standards in the meat packaging industry.




The call for a shift in meat packaging practices is grounded in the 2010 Ministerial Order, which sets stringent guidelines for the transport and trade of meat. Article 9 of the order explicitly prohibits the use of dirty or previously used non-washable materials for meat packing, a category that includes paper bags. The directive highlights the importance of maintaining hygiene throughout the entire meat supply chain, from production to consumption.

Gaspard Simbarikure, Veterinary Hygiene and Quarantine Specialist at RICA, emphasized that packaging meat in paper bags is not only environmentally unsustainable but is also illegal as per existing regulations. Simbarikure further stressed the need for consumers to explore alternatives such as reusable materials like dishes and other food containers.




The decision to discourage the use of paper bags and non-biodegradable sacks for meat packaging is rooted in environmental awareness and responsibility. Traditional packaging materials, especially those that are not biodegradable, contribute significantly to environmental degradation. By advocating for sustainable alternatives, RICA aims to reduce the environmental impact associated with the meat industry.




As part of the initiative, RICA is encouraging consumers to play an active role in supporting sustainable packaging practices. Simbarikure suggests opting for reusable materials, such as dishes and other food containers, as an eco-friendly alternative to single-use and non-biodegradable options. This shift in consumer behavior not only aligns with RICA's directive but also contributes to the broader global movement towards reducing plastic waste and promoting environmentally conscious choices.




RICA acknowledges the importance of public awareness and education in ensuring the success of this initiative. By informing consumers about the environmental and legal implications of using non-compliant packaging materials, RICA aims to foster a sense of responsibility among citizens. Educational campaigns will be crucial in dispelling misconceptions and encouraging a more sustainable approach to meat packaging.




As Rwanda takes a bold step towards aligning its meat packaging practices with environmentally friendly and legally compliant standards, it sets a precedent for responsible and sustainable consumption. The collaboration between regulatory authorities, businesses, and consumers is pivotal in creating a positive impact on both the quality of meat products and the overall well-being of the environment. Through these concerted efforts, Rwanda is poised to become a model for sustainable practices in the meat industry, showcasing the benefits of harmonizing economic activities with ecological responsibility.

SCHWARZENEGGER'S AIRPORT DETENTION: LUXURY WATCH AND CHARITABLE INTENTIONS

07:00, 2024-01-23

In a surprising turn of events, legendary actor and former California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger found himself detained by customs officers at Munich airport. The reason? His failure to declare a luxury watch, a custom piece by Swiss watchmaker Audemars Piguet. The incident unfolded as authorities could not locate any supporting documents for the prized timepiece, leading to a three-hour ordeal for the 76-year-old icon.




Schwarzenegger, known for his larger-than-life persona, was sporting a specially customized Audemars Piguet watch as he traveled. The watch, tailored to his taste, added a touch of sophistication to his ensemble. However, what was meant to be a smooth journey took an unexpected turn at the Munich airport.




Customs officers, upon discovering the unreported luxury watch, detained Schwarzenegger for three hours. The actor had not filled out the necessary declaration form for carrying high-value items, prompting an investigation by the authorities. The absence of proper documentation raised concerns, leading to the initiation of a procedure that would unfold in the following hours.




Upon being questioned about the watch, Schwarzenegger revealed that he was en route to Austria for a noble cause. The 76-year-old icon was heading to Kitzbuhel for a charity auction. The auction aimed to raise funds for The Schwarzenegger Climate Initiative, a foundation supporting climate projects globally.




As the customs officers delved into the matter, Schwarzenegger attempted to pay the necessary taxes for the watch. However, complications arose when the airport's credit card machine malfunctioned, hindering the payment process. In an effort to resolve the issue, the actor was escorted to an ATM, only to find that the withdrawal limit was insufficient.




After several hours of attempts, a functioning credit card machine was finally brought in by the customs officers. The ordeal highlighted the bureaucratic challenges faced by even high-profile individuals in adhering to customs procedures.




The actor clarified that the luxury watch was intended for the charity auction in Austria. Once auctioned, the proceeds would be directed towards The Schwarzenegger Climate Initiative, where he assured that proper documentation and reporting would be undertaken once the watch found its new owner through the auction.




Despite the charitable intentions behind carrying the watch, a shadow of suspicion looms as a criminal procedure investigation for possible tax evasion is underway. The customs spokesperson confirmed that authorities are diligently examining the circumstances surrounding the incident.




Arnold Schwarzenegger's detention at Munich airport sheds light on the complexities and challenges individuals face when transporting valuable items. Despite facing hurdles, the actor's commitment to charitable causes remains evident, as the luxury watch was destined for a noble purpose. As the investigation unfolds, the incident serves as a reminder of the importance of adhering to customs procedures, even for those in the spotlight.

THE HOUSE OF COMMONS PASSES THE RWANDA -UK ASSAYLUM BILL ; WHAT NEXT ?

14:30, 2024-01-18

In a significant move aimed at reshaping the UK's approach to asylum seekers, the House of Commons approved a new migration bill on Wednesday, January 17, declaring Rwanda as a safe country for those seeking refuge. The bill, presented by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, addresses concerns raised by the UK Supreme Court regarding the potential risk faced by asylum seekers sent to Rwanda.




The impetus for this legislation stems from the UK Supreme Court's ruling, which highlighted the risks associated with sending asylum seekers from the UK to Rwanda, potentially leading them to be returned to their countries of origin. Despite facing opposition from some Members of Parliament within Sunak's own Conservative Party, the bill successfully passed the third reading in the Commons, securing a majority of 44 for the government, with 320 votes in favor and 276 against.

The next hurdle for the legislation is the House of Lords, where further debates and discussions will shape the final outcome. Prime Minister Sunak emphasizes that the proposed migration partnership with Rwanda plays a pivotal role in addressing concerns related to illegal migrants arriving in the UK, particularly through the English Channel.




The urgency of this legislative move is underscored by the rising number of individuals crossing the English Channel on small boats. In 2022, this figure exceeded 45,700, with many being lured by criminal gangs with promises of job opportunities, as reported by the UK government.

On December 5, 2023, the UK and Rwandan governments solidified their commitment to this migration partnership by signing a new treaty. The treaty, signed in Kigali by UK Home Secretary James Cleverly and Rwanda's Foreign Minister Vincent Biruta, seeks to reinforce the provisions of the initial partnership established in April 2022. One notable aspect of the treaty is the creation of an appeals tribunal in Rwanda, providing asylum seekers sent from the UK the opportunity to appeal if their asylum claims are rejected.




This move reflects a concerted effort by both nations to establish a fair and secure process for asylum seekers, addressing concerns raised by the judiciary and laying the groundwork for a comprehensive migration partnership that aligns with international standards of human rights and asylum protection. As the bill progresses to the House of Lords, further deliberations will shape the final contours of this groundbreaking legislation.

During this visit, discussions focused on de-escalating tensions between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DR Congo) and addressing the underlying issues contributing to the security situation in eastern DR Congo, where the government coalition is combating the M23 rebels.

The FDLR, formed by remnants of the Interahamwe militia and the former Rwandan army involved in the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi, continues to be a source of tension between the two nations.




Incidents along the Rwanda-DR Congo border have escalated, with Congolese warplanes violating Rwandan airspace multiple times between November 2022 and January 2023. These provocations included rocket shells landing on Rwandan territory, resulting in civilian injuries.

The most recent incident occurred on Tuesday, January 16, when three armed Congolese soldiers crossed into Rwanda. Two were apprehended, while one was fatally shot after opening fire on Rwandan soldiers, underscoring the volatility of the situation along the border.




President Kagame's meeting with Secretary Blinken signifies a commitment to diplomatic channels in addressing regional conflicts. TANNZANIA LIFTS BAN ON KENYA AIRWAYS: A DIPLOMATIC RESOLUTIONS IN THE SKIES

14:37, 2024-01-16

In a swift turn of events, the Tanzanian Civil Aviation Authority has rescinded its decision to suspend Kenya Airways from its airspace, signaling a diplomatic breakthrough just hours after the suspension was announced as part of a tit-for-tat exchange.

The suspension, initially slated to take effect from January 22, has been withdrawn following Kenya's response to Tanzania's demands. In a statement released by Hamza Johari, the Director General of the Tanzania Civil Aviation Authority, it was revealed that Kenya has granted the Fifth Freedom Traffic Right to Air Tanzania Company Limited for all-cargo services, aligning with the requests of the United Republic of Tanzania. This change is effective from January 16, 2024.




“This is to inform the public that the aeronautical authorities of the Republic of Kenya have granted the Fifth Freedom Traffic Right to Air Tanzania Company Limited for all-cargo service as per the request of the United Republic of Tanzania," the statement reads.

Tanzania had initially blocked Kenya Airways from flying to Dar es Salaam, citing a reciprocity dispute after Kenya declined a request for all-cargo flight operations by Air Tanzania Company Limited.




In response to Kenya's compliance, Mr. Johari stated, "Following this development, the aeronautical authorities of the United Republic of Tanzania hereby withdraw its decision of January 15, 2024, and therefore approval for Kenya Airways to operate Third and Fourth Freedom Traffic Rights between Nairobi and Dar es Salaam is hereby restored with immediate effect.”

The diplomatic tension prompted swift action, with Kenya and Tanzania committing to resolving the dispute. Prime Cabinet Secretary and CS for Foreign Affairs, Musalia Mudavadi, and Tanzania’s Minister for Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation, January Makamba, affirmed their commitment to working together to settle the matter amicably within the next three days.




Mudavadi stated, "We have jointly agreed that our respective Civil Aviation Authorities will work together to have the matter resolved amicably within the next three days. There should, therefore, be no cause for alarm."

Makamba echoed the sentiment, saying, “I spoke to my Kenyan colleague Musalia Mudavadi. We agree that restrictions of air travel between our countries and from any of our countries to a third country shouldn’t stand. With relevant authorities, we’ve resolved to settle this issue, per existing agreements, within 3 days.”

This rapid resolution showcases the diplomatic agility of both nations, emphasizing their commitment to maintaining cordial relations and adhering to established agreements.

14:43, 2024-01-15

In a significant move towards fostering gender equality in the workplaces, the Rwanda Revenue Authority (RRA)enrolled in the Gender Equality Seal (GES) programme which was launched on 15 Jan , an initiative established by the United Nations in 2018. This initiative aims to bridge gender gaps in both private and public sectors, with a particular focus on promoting equality in workspaces. Rwanda Revenue's commitment to gender equality in tax administration is underscored by its dedication to extensive research and being the first African country to produce a sex-disaggregated data.




In a conversation with Innocente MURASI, the Commissioner for Strategy and Risk Analysis at RRA, she expressed the organization's ambitious goals. "We are ambitiously working to not just be a world tax administration, which pushes us to set this one straight, despite being a new entrant," she stated. This commitment reflects Rwanda Revenue Authority's determination to be a trailblazer in the global effort towards gender equality.




Commissioner MURASI further highlighted the potential impact of this initiative on achieving tax collection targets in the near future, by actively participating in the GES programme, RRA aims to enhance its effectiveness not only in promoting gender equality but also in meeting its financial objectives.

Technical Assistance from UNDP and Gender Monitoring Office:

The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) and the Gender Monitoring Office will provide technical assistance to RRA through the GES programme. The program was officially launched with the formation of a committee chaired by MUKASE Josiane, who is currently Ag. Director in charge of People Management in the HR department at Rwanda Revenue. This collaboration seeks to mainstream gender equality principles in tax administration, contributing to a more inclusive fiscal sector.




While at the launch, KIRENGA Clement, the National Coordinator for Inclusion at UNDP, emphasized the synergy created by the Gender Equality Seal. ''The program sets a standard recognized by the UNDP world over, awarding private and public sector entities based on their efforts towards gender equality and mainstreaming.'' Clement stated.

This aligns with the broader goal of creating a more inclusive fiscal sector in Rwanda. He added




This should be remembered that Gender Equality Seal (GES), with its varying levels of recognition from bronze to platinum, offers distinct advantages to national authorities like Rwanda Revenue. Berni Smith, the Strategic Advisor to the Commissioner General of Rwanda Revenue and a tax lawyer, highlighted the uniqueness of this commitment. She stated, "The commitment and dedication of the team at Rwanda Revenue Authority, coupled with the partnership with UNDP, make them gender equality leaders among revenue authorities not only on the continent but worldwide."




Rwanda Revenue Authority's enrollment in the Gender Equality Seal programme represents a pivotal step towards fostering an inclusive workplace and bridging gender gaps in the tax administration sector. This commitment not only positions RRA as a leader in the global push for gender equality but also underlines its dedication to achieving excellence in tax collection through an inclusive and diverse workforce.

The closure follows an attack by the RED-Tabara group near the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) on December 22, resulting in the tragic loss of 20 lives, including women and children.

The tensions have escalated to the point where Burundi's Interior Minister, Martin Niteretse, declared the closure of the border during a press briefing on Thursday 11,January..




"We have closed our borders (with Rwanda), anyone who tries to go there will not get through. The decision has been made," announced Interior Minister Martin Niteretse. He went on to state that the decision was prompted by the perceived support from Rwanda to the RED-Tabara group, accusing Rwanda of harboring criminals that pose a threat to Burundians.




This comes shortly after President Ndayishimiye expressed his disappointment in the relationship with Rwandan President Paul Kagame, stating, "After having noted that we had a bad neighbor, Paul Kagame... we stopped all relations with him until he returns to better feelings." The Burundian government insists that Rwanda shelters criminals responsible for harming Burundians.




For some time now Burundi-Rwanda relations have been historically tumultuous, with occasional periods of improvement. While ties showed signs of betterment after Ndayishimiye assumed power in 2020 and reopening of the borders in 2022, recent events surrounding Burundi's alleged involvement in the DRC have strained relations once again.




Rwanda on the other hand, continues to deny any involvement with the RED-Tabara group. In a rebuttal, Rwandan authorities referenced an incident in 2019 when the Rwandan Defence Forces (RDF) repatriated suspected rebels to Burundi for prosecution.

These latest developments underscore the fragility of diplomatic relations between the two East African nations and raise concerns about the potential impact on regional stability, tras border businesses and the movement of persons. The international community will be closely watching the situation unfold as efforts to de-escalate tensions and seek diplomatic solutions are anticipated.

"ANOTHER SUCCESSFUL JUSTICE INVANTION ; RWANDA'S PLEA BARGAINING EMPTIES 5000 CASE BACKLOG''

07:45, 2024-01-10

In a remarkable turn of events, Rwanda has achieved significant success in its justice system with over 5,000 cases closed through plea bargains within just over a year since the introduction of this innovative legal procedure. Judicial data reveals that from August to December 2023 alone, more than 4,000 cases were successfully resolved through plea bargains. This article explores the impact of plea bargaining in Rwanda, its evolution since its introduction in October 2022, and the potential implications for the country's legal landscape.




The Concept of Plea Bargaining:

Plea bargaining, introduced as a new operational procedure in Rwanda in October 2022, involves negotiations between the prosecution and defense. Under this process, the defendant agrees to plead guilty to specific charges in exchange for a more lenient sentence or other possibilities, such as the dismissal of charges. Initially applied in cases of assault and theft, the procedure was designed for a five-year pilot phase in five intermediate courts. However, due to its success, officials at the judiciary decided to implement it nationwide.

Rapid Expansion and Impressive Statistics:

The statistics speak for themselves, showcasing the rapid expansion of plea bargaining in Rwanda. Over 1,500 cases were closed during the earlier stages of the year and the latter part of 2022, and an astonishing 4,000 cases were resolved from August to December 2023. The last quarter of 2023 witnessed a substantial number of cases closed through plea bargains, with October recording 960 cases, November 1,166, and December 795. These numbers underline the efficiency and effectiveness of this new legal procedure.




Optimism for the Future:

Harrison Mutabazi, the judiciary’s spokesperson, expressed optimism about the early performance of the plea bargaining system, foreseeing improved future outcomes. The success of plea bargaining is not just in the sheer number of cases closed but also in its potential to transform the judicial process in Rwanda.

PROS of Plea Bargaining:

Plea bargaining offers several advantages that contribute to its success in Rwanda. Firstly, it facilitates the obtaining of crucial information from suspects, aiding in the fight against organized crime. Moreover, it expedites justice delivery, reducing court backlogs and prison overcrowding by minimizing the number of cases that reach courts or prisons. This streamlined approach not only benefits the legal system but also ensures a more efficient and timely resolution for both victims and defendants.




Rwanda's experience with plea bargaining serves as a testament to the potential benefits of innovative legal procedures in the pursuit of justice. With more cases closed within just over a year, the success of plea bargaining not only highlights its effectiveness in resolving cases but also suggests a positive transformation in the country's legal landscape. As Rwanda continues to refine and expand this approach, it sets a noteworthy example for other jurisdictions considering similar reforms in the justice systems

SUPREME COURT UPHOLDS CONTROVERSIAL POWERS FOR RWANDA INVESTIGATION BUREAU IN LANDMARK RULING

12:25, 2024-01-03

In a groundbreaking decision, the Supreme Court of Rwanda has ruled in favor of allowing the Rwanda Investigation Bureau (RIB) to conduct searches on persons, buildings, and premises without the need for court warrants, provided investigators believe there are reasonable grounds for suspecting criminal activity.

The ruling comes in response to a petition filed by city lawyer Edward Murangwa, who challenged the constitutionality of certain provisions within the 2017 law that established RIB and outlined its mission, powers, organization, and functioning.




Central to Murangwa's argument was his opposition to the 10th article of the law, which grants investigators the authority to "search any person or property, enter premises without a warrant" if there are reasonable grounds to suspect a criminal act is being committed or is about to be committed, or if there are reasonable grounds to believe the premises house a criminal suspect or an object used in committing a crime.

Murangwa contended that such provisions contravene several articles of the constitution, including the 13th one, which emphasizes the sanctity and inviolability of an individual, asserting that the state is obligated to respect, protect, and defend the person.




The Supreme Court's decision marks a significant development in the ongoing debate over the balance between law enforcement powers and individual rights. Proponents argue that granting RIB expanded search powers without warrants is crucial for effective crime prevention and investigation, especially in cases where immediate action is deemed necessary.




On the other hand, critics, including Murangwa, express concerns about potential violations of constitutional rights, raising questions about the delicate balance between ensuring national security and safeguarding individual liberties. The court's ruling, therefore, not only settles a legal dispute but also sets a precedent that will likely shape the landscape of law enforcement practices and civil liberties in Rwanda. The decision is poised to spark further discussions on the fine line between security measures and the protection of individual rights in the pursuit of justice.

Eyewitness accounts reveal instances of physical assault by the police against some of the demonstrators.




The conflicting narratives surrounding the events make it challenging to ascertain the accuracy of the claims made by both parties. The situation calls for an independent investigation to determine the facts surrounding the alleged use of live ammunition and the reported police brutality during the protest.




The unfolding events have raised concerns among the international community, with calls for a peaceful resolution to the political crisis in the Democratic Republic of Congo. JUSTICE FINALLY SERVED; THE BUTCHER OF TUMBA, SOSTHENE MUNYEMAN SENT TO PRISON FOR 24 YEARS.

14:59, 2023-12-20

The Cour d’assises de Paris has rendered a historic verdict, sentencing Sosthène Munyemana, infamously known as the 'Butcher of Tumba,' to 24 years in prison for his role in the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi. The ruling marks a significant milestone in the pursuit of justice for the atrocities committed during one of the darkest chapters in human history.

A trained medical doctor, Munyemana was implicated in heinous acts during the genocide while working as a lecturer in the faculty of medicine at the University of Rwanda. Additionally, he served as a gynecologist at the University Hospital in Butare (CHUB). His active involvement in the genocide led to his notorious moniker, the 'Butcher of Tumba.'




The French court's sentencing comes after a protracted legal process. Munyemana, aged 68, has resided in France for over two decades, despite an outstanding indictment for the genocide crimes he was accused of committing. The trial commenced on November 14, spanning over a month of hearings before the court delivered its sentence on Tuesday.

Immediately following the verdict, Munyemana was placed under arrest, despite having a 10-day window to appeal the sentence, as per reports from the European country. The ruling is a testament to the persistence of international efforts to hold individuals accountable for their roles in the genocide.




The trial, which delved into the intricate details of Munyemana's actions during the genocide, brought to light the magnitude of the crimes committed against the Tutsi population. The sentencing reaffirms the international community's commitment to pursuing justice and ensuring that those responsible for genocide are held accountable, regardless of the passage of time.

As Sosthène Munyemana begins his prison term, survivors of the genocide and advocates for justice find solace in the recognition of the atrocities and a step towards closure for the victims and their families. The verdict sends a powerful message that impunity for such heinous crimes will not be tolerated, even after decades have passed.

The gravity of the situation forced a temporary adjournment of the parliamentary session, as bewildered lawmakers found themselves evacuated to the outside world, away from the unfolding turmoil within.

The breach, a disconcerting reality, left the nation grappling with the vulnerabilities of its security apparatus.

Opposition lawmakers voiced their apprehensions, their words cutting through the air like a mournful lament. Mallikarjun Kharge, the leader of India's main opposition Congress party, expressed the gravity of the situation, stating, "The issue is very serious. The Presidential Order, issued on December 11, 2023, provides clarity on the timeline for both the election of the President of the Republic of Rwanda and specified Members of Parliament (Deputies).




According to the Presidential Order, the elections for the President of the Republic and the 53 Deputies will take place on July 14 and 15, 2024. This announcement was promptly published in the Official Gazette on the same date, marking a crucial step in the electoral preparations.

The order specifies that the 53 Deputies (Members of Parliament) will be elected from a final list of candidates proposed by political organizations or independent candidates. This inclusive approach ensures a diverse representation in the parliamentary body, reflecting the pluralistic nature of the democratic process.




A key highlight of this Order is the synchronization of the election dates for both the President and the Deputies. The decision to hold these elections concurrently on July 15, 2024, is aimed at streamlining the electoral process and fostering a unified expression of the public's will.

"Throughout the country, the polling date for the President of the Republic and 53 Deputies elected from a final list of names of candidates proposed by political organisations or for independent candidates is Monday, 15 July 2024," states the Presidential Order.

This synchronized approach not only maximizes efficiency but also emphasizes the interconnected roles of the head of state and parliamentary representatives in shaping the nation's future. RWANDA AND UNITED KINGDOM FORGE AWAY FORWARD ON THE ASYLUM SEEKERS' PARTNERSHIP.

10:02, 2023-12-06

Rwanda and the United Kingdom on Tuesday, December 5, announced a new migration treaty that is set to re-emphasize, in a binding manner, already existing commitments that address concerns previously raised about the protection of asylum seekers.




Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dr. Vincent Biruta alongside visiting UK Home Secretary James Cleverly presided over the signing ceremony in Kigali.




Under the treaty, a new appeals tribunal, is set to be established under Rwandan law and overseen by two co-presidents

One of the presidents is expected to be Rwandan and another is drawn from another Commonwealth country.




Also, to be introduced is a panel of judges from various nationalities, who will hear appeals in the event an applicant’s asylum claim is turned down.

This comes after a contradicting ruling by the British court, that based it on the assumptions of human rights violations and the fear that Rwanda would repatriate asylum seekers to their home countries which would pose threats.

This did not receive a calm reaction from both governments that felt it was all a PR haux and were still forging ways for this partnership to work




“This partnership reflects Rwanda's commitment to protecting vulnerable people and our country's track record in welcoming and hosting refugees and migrants from around the world,” Minister Biruta said at a press conference after signing

Biruta went on to assert that Rwanda and the UK, understand that there is a critical need to find innovative ways to address the suffering of migrants making dangerous, desperate journeys under the exploitation of criminal human smugglers.

There is also a need to tackle the underlying causes driving people from their homelands, he pointed out.

“In other words, the boats will not be completely stopped unless we reverse the lack of opportunity and insecurity in countries around the world.”

The new scheme announced Tuesday, Biruta said, will reinforce the mutually beneficial framework for cooperation between both countries.

ITALY JAMS TO THE GERMAN REQUEST OF RETURNING HITLER'S BOUGHT STATUE.

14:48, 2023-12-05

Italy’s culture minister is refuses a request by the German State Antiquities Collection in Munich to return an ancient Roman statue that embodied Hitler’s Aryan aesthetic, calling it a national treasure.




The Discobolus Palombara is a 2nd-century Roman copy of a long-lost Greek bronze original. Hitler had bought the Roman copy from its private Italian owner in 1938 under pressure from Italian dictator Benito Mussolini and against the wishes of the education minister and cultural officials. The statue, unearthed at a Roman villa in 1781, was returned to Italy in 1948 as part of works illegally obtained by the Nazis.




The dispute arose when the director of the National Roman Museum requested the statue’s 17th-century marble base be returned from the Antikensammlungen state antiquities collection. The German museum instead asked for the return of the Discobolus Palombara, saying it had been illegally transported to Italy in 1948, the Corriere della Sera newspaper reported Friday.

ADRESSING PESTE DES PETITS RUMINANTS (PPR) OUTBREAK: FAO's COLLABORATIVE RESPONSE ACROSS BORDERS.

12:47, 2023-12-05

In a pivotal moment for regional collaboration, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) in partnership with the Ministry of Agriculture swiftly responded to the outbreak of Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR) reported by the Rwanda Veterinary Services on August 14, 2023 in the parts of Kayonza, Ndego,Ruhuha and Bugesra. This marked the first occurrence of PPR in the region, demanding immediate attention and coordinated efforts. Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is a severe viral disease of domestic and wild small ruminants. PPR affects primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, inducing high rates of morbidity and mortality.

Recognizing the urgency of the situation, the FAO forged a strategic partnership with the Ministry of Agriculture in Rwanda, as well as authorities in Burundi and Tanzania. This collaboration aimed at pooling resources and expertise to effectively address the outbreak and prevent its further spread across borders particularly in the Eastern parts of the country.  A critical aspect of the collaborative response was a comprehensive risk assessment that painted the region at a heightened risk due to the easy movement of people and animals between the borders of Burundi and Tanzania. Two separate PPR outbreaks, involving a total of 300 animals, originated at the border with Tanzania, underscoring the need for immediate and targeted interventions such as ;




Rapid Response Teams: which FAO, in conjunction with local authorities, promptly established rapid response teams strategically positioned to assess, contain, and mitigate the spread of PPR. These teams played a crucial role in early detection and intervention. Vaccination Campaigns: Recognizing the importance of proactive measures, targeted vaccination campaigns that were implemented. Priority was given to areas close to the borders, aiming to protect vulnerable herds and prevent further transmission of the virus though it is still found deeming enough to do a gel mass vaccination for all small ruminants with in the country

Information Dissemination: This could only be possible working closely with local authorities, that would actively disseminate vital information to farmers and communities about PPR prevention and early detection. This outreach ensured that communities were well-informed and empowered to actively participate in the collective effort to combat the outbreak and also engage the local veterinary officers to continue being alert. Dr. Fabrice Ndayisenga, the Rwandan Country Chief Veterinary Officer, played a key role in the collaborative response, during the 2nd coordination meeting on October 19, 2023, when he provided detailed insights into the current PPR epidemiological situation in Rwanda, outlining specific actions being implemented. His expertise significantly contributed to enhancing the regional response which was the basis of the cooperation which forth triggered comprehensive monitoring efforts that were implemented throughout Rwanda, with a particular focus on areas close to the borders.

RWANDA ANNOUNCES CLIMATE FINANCE PARTNERSHIP MILESTONES AT COP28

10:31, 2023-12-04

The Rwanda Climate Finance Partnership, which was launched at the Paris Summit for a New Global Financing Pact, will further power innovative climate action thanks to additional contributions from the Government of Rwanda. The partnership is supported by Agence Française de Développement (AFD), the European Union and Team Europe, the European Investment Bank (EIB), the International Finance Corporation (IFC), German Cooperation via KfW Development Bank, and the Italian Cooperation system with the support of Cassa Depositi e Prestiti (CDP); and it complements existing partnerships, including the Rwandan-German Climate and Development Partnership and ongoing initiatives with the World Bank. The formal announcement was made on the sidelines of the COP28 UN Climate Change Conference in Dubai, UAE on 4 December. 

 

It was made clear that the Rwanda Climate Finance Partnership aims to facilitate public-private partnerships to scale-up climate finance and has been made possible by the country’s Resilience and Sustainability Facility (RSF) arrangement with the International Monetary Fund, which is expected to disburse an additional USD 48.5 million in budget support following the approval of Rwanda’s second review of the RSF arrangement by the IMF Executive Board in mid-December. 

To further demonstrate commitment to its RSF-supported climate agenda, the Government of Rwanda also announced two additional reform measures supported by the RSF, related to:

(i) enhanced risk analysis of State-Owned Enterprises and Public-Private Partnerships that are vulnerable to climate change, and

(ii) adopting a green taxonomy adapted to Rwanda’s NDC climate action plan.

 

Other key partnership milestones were also shared at the COP28 side event and include;

  The Government of Rwanda, through the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning, will contribute USD 40 million to support ''IREME'' Invest, the country’s private sector green investment facility complimented by the European Investment Bank and the Development Bank of Rwanda's signed EUR 20 million loan and a technical assistance agreement to support Rwanda’s green transition through ''IREME'' Invest. The loan is the first tranche of an expected EUR 100 million financing package announced at the Paris Summit. The technical assistance will be provided under the EIB Greening Financial Systems programme, supporting the NDC Partnership and backed by the International Climate Initiative Fund and German Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Action. At COP28 the EIB is also outlining a new EUR 100 million agricultural climate finance partnership with Bank of Kigali to support smallholders and agri-business across Rwanda impacted by climate change.

 

AFD and Rwanda Development Bank have also signed a EUR 20 million credit facility and a EUR 1 million technical assistance grant to scale up ''IREME'' Invest. The first investments under the facility have already been undertaken in several sectors: green buildings and renewable energy. AFD has also signed a budget support of EUR 50 million and EUR 3 million technical assistance grant, announced at the Paris Summit, to advance green public financial management in Rwanda. AFD signed a memorandum of understanding with Bank of Kigali, whereby they agree to strengthen their cooperation in the area of climate finance and working on a climate line of credit of EUR 20 million with a technical assistance grant of EUR 1 million.

The Danish International Development Agency and the Rwanda Green Fund have signed a grant agreement of USD 5.27 million to support the Project Preparation Facility of Ireme Invest, which is powered by the Rwanda Green Fund.

CDP, Italy’s Financial Institution for International Development Cooperation, is advancing its partnership with the Government of Rwanda to provide financial support to green transition in the country, in the context of an overall strategy to scale up financial flows towards sustainable development and to counter climate change in Africa.

 

The Rwanda Climate Finance Partnership is a key pillar of Rwanda’s efforts to fund its ambitious NDC Climate Action Plan, and complements a number of existing public and private sector focused initiatives to enable Rwanda to respond to climate change:

Programmatic approach for Rwanda’s NDC investments: Three programmatic investment plans on: (i) Climate-Smart Agriculture (CSA), (ii) Sustainable Urbanization, with lead support of German Technical Cooperation (GIZ), and (iii) Sustainable Landscape Management (SLM), with the support from the World Bank, are currently under preparation. Additionally, the IFC will support the Government of Rwanda through the Rwanda Green Fund, to develop long-term investment plans for climate smart agriculture and sustainable urbanization, specifically focusing on increasing the role of the private sector in greening Rwanda’s economy.




·Green Taxonomy: The Government of Rwanda announced the first phase of its green taxonomy to help catalyze private financing to green projects. Once finalized, the taxonomy will provide clear signals on which projects and activities are aligned with Rwanda’s climate goals. It will help direct private financial flows to the financing of those activities. The initiative is supported by Germany through GIZ, and it is strongly interlinked with Ireme Invest and the Boosting Green Finance, Investment and Trade (GreenFIT) partnership with the World Bank.

·        

Rwanda’s NDC Facility, known as Intego, has developed a rich and promising pipeline of public climate adaptation and mitigation projects since its launch at COP27. The facility was capitalized by Germany through KfW with seed funding of EUR 46 million as part of the EUR 222 million Rwandan-German Climate and Development Partnership. The first call for proposals shows that financing needs and availability of project concepts go far beyond the seed funding and the Government of Rwanda is inviting development partners to join the initiative. Intego shall become a best practice example on how to facilitate access to public finance and to pool funding from various sources for climate projects.

·        

Boosting Green Finance, Investment and Trade (GreenFIT): The World Bank has also partnered with the Government of Rwanda in the design of a new development policy operation (DPO) that encompasses a set of reforms to increase private sector participation in the Rwandan economy and improve resource mobilisation for climate resilience, with a value of USD 250 million over two years. Germany through KfW Development Bank has joined this effort and contributed not only to the provision of hands-on Technical Assistance for the design and implementation of the DPO’s actions, and is considering a financial contribution to the overall funding of the operation for the second year of the DPO.

·        

The EU, as part of the Global Gateway initiative, is also providing budget support for an overall amount of EUR 59 million in grants, including EUR 6.5 million technical assistance, in support of Rwanda’s NDC targets with a specific focus on adaptation in agriculture, in addition to backing the EUR 20 million EIB financing to the Rwanda Development Bank and the Bank of Kigali EIB loan.

·Finally, the Development Bank of Rwanda recently closed a RWF 30 billion (USD 24.8 million) sustainability-linked bond issuance, which was partially credit-enhanced via a World Bank lending operation, representing the first such issuance by a national development bank in the world.

 

The Rwanda Climate Finance Partnership, Rwandan-German Climate and Development Partnership, and ongoing initiatives with the World Bank and other partners, such as the United Kingdom, Denmark, and Sweden, demonstrate the power of collaboration to reshape the global climate finance architecture, including by moving beyond small-scale projects to significant long-term investments that leverage existing mechanisms to facilitate public-private partnerships and attract private sector investments.

JAPANESE SPACE SCIENTIST KOJI MURATA SET TO LAUNCH IN SPACE THE FIRST EVER WOODEN SATELLITE.

14:23, 2023-11-27

Aluminum rockets and steel skyscrapers; slick high-speed shuttles and glassy facades: that’s how “the future” has been imagined for decades.




But that’s not what Koji Murata imagines. A researcher at Kyoto University in Japan, Murata has been exploring how biological materials could be used in space.




Murata wondered if he “could build a wooden house on the moon or Mars,” and decided to test the theory — by creating a wooden satellite.




This comes after Recent research from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) found that 10% of atmospheric aerosol in the stratosphere contained metallic particles from spacecraft, including satellites. The long-term impact of these metal fragments is unknown, but scientists are concerned it could damage Earth’s fragile ozone layer




Wooden satellites would be better for the plane while still providing the same functionality as their metal counterparts, says Murata




''Wood doesn't burn or rot in the lifeless vacuum of space, but it will incinerate into a fine ash upon reentry into Earth's atmosphere — making it a surprisingly useful, biodegradable material for future satellites. After successfully testing their wood samples aboard the International Space Station (ISS) earlier this year, the scientists believe the test satellite is fit for launch.'' Murata added







THE TANZANIAN SLAG TO PURCHASE SUNFLOWER SEEDS FOR FARMERS COULD LEAD TO A REGIONAL DEFCIT OF EDIBLE OIL.

17:15, 2023-11-23

Tanzania’s drive to industrialise its sunflower sector has hits a backlog for the 2023/2024 planting season on a deal to bulk-source high-yield seeds for the country’s one million sunflower

farmers. The deal, funded by the African Development Bank,(AFDB) was for 700 tonnes of hybrid seeds, to deliver yields and oil up to 65 per cent percent greater than traditional varieties. The government had planned to provide the seeds at subsidised prices for the season that began in October 2023, however, the supply has proved difficult to secure on a change of strategy around which hybrid seeds to settle for.




The government has been investing heavily in sunflower processing to reduce its hefty edible oil

imports, which currently account for between $90m and $250m every year and forth has moved to introduce tariffs on edible oil imports, while removing VAT on sunflower oil processing

equipment coming into the country, to favour local oil producers.




This on the other hand leaves processors limited by the lack of domestic raw materials, and the available ones relatively acquired at a high cost, as a result of farmers’ low yields for over a a decade. However the government and private sector have developed, tested, and launched four hybrid seeds in the market whose uptake has been poor.

The bulk-purchase of subsidised hybrids was designed to catalyse new uptake of the hybrid seeds, which produce far better margins for farmers and can supply an expanded processing sector which holds the potential to create thousands of new jobs.

However, at the point of tender, the Tanzanian government selected a new entrant to the seed

industry to provide 700 tonnes of a new hybrid, currently registered and used in India. The yield

and oil content of the new hybrid are not available. It is one of 18 hybrid sunflower seeds

registered with the Indian Directorate of Oilseeds Development (DOD), but the only one that is

registered without information on its yields and oil content.




It is also not recommended, by the DOD, as ideal or suitable for any area in India. However, it is

currently available in large volumes, and has enjoyed price cutting amid rising stockpiles. This

meant the new seed industry entrant was able to offer a far lower price for the sunflower seeds

than the established suppliers in the country, by sourcing the seeds as an open buyer from

India.




But as a single purchase of stockpiled Indian seed, it remains in negotiation, some months later, and has failed to arrive before the season started. When it does arrive it will also then require the creation of new distribution partnerships and networks to deliver.




For Tanzanian farmers, the seed purchase is now unlikely to be available before planting is

finished in early 2024, and the new supply will require storage until the 2024/2025 season a reason anticipated to cause a regional edible oil deficit. It has also been observed by market specialists that the stockpiles of the new seed in India, which had triggered the price cutting, amount to around 500 tonnes, further slowing the completion of the 700 tonne order.

The footage is unedited, in contrast to the selective and misleading content circulated by Hamas and others on social media.

In the pursuit of a comprehensive understanding, it is essential to advocate for a nuanced approach that honors both privacy and the collective right to knowledge, fostering a society built on trust and accountability.

Reports suggest a significant loss of life, with claims of over 1200 civilians, including women and children, falling victim to violence perpetrated by ISIS-linked Hamas militants.




"As we grapple with the aftermath, it is essential to approach these events with a commitment to truth, acknowledging the gravity of the situation, Israel's sovereignty, the citizens' future, and guaranteed security. The only thing we expect from the world is to understand that we were attacked and have a right to fight back, just as the USA did after 9/11," stated Yossi Gadamo, the deputy ambassador of Israel in Rwanda.
