ELECTRIFYING THE FUTURE: THE RISE OF ELECTRIC CARS

12:35, 2023-11-07

The automotive industry is undergoing a revolution, and it's being powered by electricity. Electric cars, also known as electric vehicles (EVs), have gained significant momentum in recent years and particularly in Rwanda as concerns about climate change and the environmental impact of traditional gasoline-powered vehicles have intensified. In this article, we explore the world of electric cars, their benefits, challenges, and the role they play in shaping a more sustainable future.




One of the primary advantages of electric cars is their environmental friendliness. Unlike conventional internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles, electric cars produce zero tailpipe emissions. This means they don't release harmful pollutants like carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, or particulate matter into the atmosphere. As a result, electric cars significantly reduce air pollution and help combat climate change by lowering greenhouse gas emissions.




Electric cars are highly energy-efficient, making them able to convert a higher percentage of the energy from the grid into motion, typically around 85-90%, whereas ICE vehicles are considerably less efficient, with only about 20-30% of the energy from gasoline being used to move the vehicle. This efficiency results in cost savings for EV owners, who spend less on energy to travel the same distance.




Electric vehicles (EVs) have fewer moving parts compared to traditional vehicles. This means there is less wear and tear, leading to lower maintenance costs. Additionally, the cost of electricity for charging is usually lower than that of gasoline or diesel fuel, resulting in substantial savings over time which also makes them known for their quiet and smooth operation. Without the noise and vibrations associated with internal combustion engines, electric cars provide a more pleasant driving experience for passengers and reduce noise pollution in urban areas.




While electric cars have made significant advancements in range, they still tend to have a lower range compared to gasoline-powered vehicles. Range anxiety, the fear of running out of battery power before reaching a charging station, remains a concern for some potential buyers. However, advancements in battery technology are steadily increasing the range of electric cars.




This has however pauses a challenge for governments to encourage the adoption of electric cars, a robust charging infrastructure is essential. Although charging networks are expanding, there are still areas with limited access to charging stations, which can be a barrier for potential electric car owners. Public and private investments are working to address this issue.




Electric cars tend to have a higher upfront cost compared to traditional vehicles. However, this is gradually changing as economies of scale, technological advancements, and government incentives make electric cars more affordable. In the long run, lower operating costs and potential incentives can offset the higher initial purchase price.

The Road to a Sustainable Future

Electric cars are a vital component of a more sustainable and environmentally friendly transportation system. They offer numerous advantages that address concerns related to air pollution, energy efficiency, and operating costs. However, they also face challenges such as limited range, charging infrastructure, and upfront costs. To overcome these challenges, collaboration between the automotive industry, governments, and consumers is crucial.

As technology continues to advance, the electric car landscape is expected to evolve rapidly. Battery technology is improving, which will lead to greater range and reduced charging times. Charging infrastructure will expand, making it more convenient for people to own and use electric cars. Government policies and incentives will play a significant role in accelerating the transition to electric vehicles.




To sum it up, electric cars are not just a mode of transportation; they represent a commitment to a cleaner and more sustainable future. As more people embrace electric cars, we move closer to reducing our carbon footprint and protecting the planet for future generations. The electrification of the automotive industry is a step in the right direction, one that promises to shape a greener and more environmentally responsible world.

''RWANDA SHOULD CONSIDER DOMESTIC MANUFACTURING OF HIV/AIDS DRUGS'' SAYS UNAIDS RWANDA REPRESENTANTIVE.

14:10, 2023-11-06

As the world draws near to the celebration of world Aids day on the 1 December, Hind Hassan, the UNAIDS Representative to Rwanda, has reminded Rwanda to consider manufacturing ARVs since they are a lifelong treatment for patients, yet there is no guarantee that foreign partners will continue providing them to the country.




Currently Rwanda depends on external resources to treat more than 220,000 people living with HIV in the country. The medication is manufactured in foreign countries and provided to Rwanda via an arrangement that is mainly financed through the Global Fund or the US President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).




However, as this is ,a recent report released by UNAIDS recognized Rwanda as one of the top four countries that have effectively managed the HIV/AIDS epidemic. The country has achieved significant milestones in terms of treatment, testing, and raising awareness about HIV status among its population with the Government's move to consider acquiring an injectable HIV drug.




Under the pixie name  "Are efforts for HIV prevention wanting?" the report, unveiled on Thursday, July 13, revealed that Rwanda, along with Botswana, Eswatini, and Tanzania, has successfully met the "95-95-95" targets set by UNAIDS.

The "95-95-95" target entails ensuring that 95 percent of individuals living with HIV in a country are aware of their status, 95 percent of those aware of their HIV-positive status are receiving antiretroviral treatment, and 95 percent of people on treatment have achieved viral suppression.

The report further highlights that 16 other countries, including eight in sub-Saharan Africa, a region accounting for 65 percent of all HIV-positive individuals, are also close to achieving these targets.




"The end of AIDS is an opportunity for a uniquely powerful legacy for today's leaders," Winnie Byanyima, Executive Director of UNAIDS said. "They could be remembered by future generations as those who put a stop to the world's deadliest pandemic. They could save millions of lives and protect the health of everyone. They could show what leadership can do," she added.




AS MOVE AFRIKA COMES TO KIGALI. WE SHED A LIGHT ON KENDRICK LAMAR.

12:43, 2023-11-06

In the world of hip-hop, Kendrick Lamar is a name that resonates with authenticity, lyricism, and innovation. Born on June 17, 1987, in Compton, California, Kendrick Lamar Duckworth, professionally known as Kendrick Lamar, has emerged as one of the most influential and respected artists of his generation. But who is Kendrick Lamar, and what makes his artistry so captivating? In this article, we'll delve into the life and career of this enigmatic talent.

Early Life and Roots

Kendrick Lamar's upbringing in Compton, a city known for its troubled history, deeply influenced his art and perspective. Raised in a neighborhood that grappled with crime, poverty, and gang violence, Lamar's experiences formed the backdrop for his introspective and often socially conscious lyrics. Despite these challenging surroundings, Lamar found solace and expression in music from a young age.




Musical Beginnings

Kendrick Lamar's journey in music started with mixtapes and underground releases, gaining attention in the local hip-hop scene. He adopted the stage name "K-Dot" during this phase. His early work showcased his storytelling abilities and innate talent for wordplay. It wasn't long before he caught the attention of renowned hip-hop figures, leading to a pivotal moment in his career.

Breakout Success

Kendrick Lamar's breakthrough came with his 2011 independent album, "Section.80." This project, characterized by its vivid narratives, introspection, and social commentary, earned critical acclaim and marked the beginning of his ascent in the rap world. It also led to his signing with Top Dawg Entertainment (TDE), a prominent record label.




Album Highlights

Kendrick Lamar's discography is replete with groundbreaking albums, each marking a new phase in his artistic evolution:

"good kid, m.A.A.d city" (2012): This album catapulted Kendrick to superstardom, exploring themes of life in Compton and his personal journey. It received widespread acclaim and is often considered a modern classic.
"To Pimp a Butterfly" (2015): An ambitious and politically charged album, this Grammy-winning work delves into issues of race, identity, and societal struggles. It showcased Kendrick's ability to blend jazz and funk influences with hip-hop.
"DAMN." (2017): A more introspective and emotionally charged album, "DAMN." brought Lamar his first Pulitzer Prize in Music, highlighting his exceptional storytelling and lyrical prowess.

Artistic Influence

Kendrick Lamar's artistry transcends traditional hip-hop boundaries. He's known for his intricate wordplay, thought-provoking social commentary, and willingness to experiment with various musical styles. His influence extends beyond music, as he often collaborates with visual artists and is actively involved in social and political causes.

Also read ;

Kendrick Lamar's impact on the music industry and culture at large is undeniable. He has not only pushed the boundaries of hip-hop but has also inspired a new generation of artists to embrace vulnerability and authenticity in their work. His albums continue to spark conversations about race, identity, and the human experience.




Kendrick Lamar's journey from Compton to global recognition is a testament to his talent, dedication, and the power of storytelling through music. As an artist who consistently challenges the status quo, his influence will undoubtedly continue to shape the future of hip-hop and the broader world of entertainment. Kendrick Lamar is not just a rapper; he is a storyteller, a visionary, and a voice for change in a complex world.

CHINA'S HESITATION TO INVEST IN AFRICAN ENERGY PROJECTS: SHORT TERM IMPACTS

10:56, 2023-11-06

China has long been a key player in financing infrastructure and energy projects across the African continent. The partnership between China and African nations has resulted in significant developments, from roads and railways to energy facilities. However, in recent years, there has been a noticeable shift in China's approach, with increasing hesitation to finance African energy projects with it going down to only USD 1 billion. In this article, we will explore the causes behind this change and the potential consequences for both China and African nations.




The Changing Landscape

China's involvement in Africa's energy sector has been substantial, with investments ranging from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources. Historically, China has been a reliable source of funding for energy projects in Africa, often providing financial support when other international organizations were reluctant. However, several factors have contributed to China's changing stance:




Economic Challenges: China's economy has faced headwinds, including a slowdown in economic growth and rising debt levels. As a result, the Chinese government has become more cautious in its overseas investments, seeking to prioritize domestic interests.

Debt Concerns: China's extensive financial support for African projects has led to concerns about unsustainable debt levels in African nations. These concerns have prompted China to reconsider the terms and conditions of its investments. Beijing’s shift in its lending policy towards Africa has been bolstered by President Xi Jinping’s determination towards ‘greening’ his massive Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and supporting small scale projects (with values under $50 million) which are economically feasible, with more beneficial social and environmental impacts.




Environmental Considerations: China has made significant strides in environmental sustainability and is increasingly focused on clean energy solutions. This has led to a reassessment of its involvement in projects that rely heavily on fossil fuels, which can have adverse environmental impacts.

Political Instability: Some African nations have faced political instability, corruption, and governance issues, which have made Chinese investors more cautious about the security of their investments.

Consequences of China's Hesitation

The hesitancy of China to finance African energy projects has notable consequences for both China and African nations:

Funding Gap: African nations may find it more challenging to secure financing for critical energy projects, hindering their economic growth and development.

Diversification: African nations may need to diversify their sources of funding, looking to international organizations, Western nations, and private investors, which could lead to greater competition and potentially improved project terms.

Environmental Shift: As China becomes more selective in its investments, African nations may need to explore cleaner and more sustainable energy solutions, aligning with global efforts to combat climate change.

Diplomatic Relations: The evolving dynamics in financing energy projects can influence diplomatic relations between China and African countries. Maintaining a balanced relationship will be crucial for both parties.

Infrastructure Development: The pace of infrastructure development in Africa, especially in the energy sector, may slow down as a result of China's hesitation, affecting job creation and the overall economic growth of African nations.




China's hesitancy to finance African energy projects is a reflection of changing economic, environmental, and political dynamics. While this shift may pose challenges for African nations in the short term, it also offers an opportunity for them to explore diverse sources of funding and cleaner energy solutions. For China, a more cautious approach can help address domestic concerns and align with global environmental goals. As the situation unfolds, it will be essential for China and African nations to find common ground and maintain strong diplomatic relations to ensure sustainable development on the African continent.

The 'Move Afrika' initiative is driven by a shared vision among Global Citizen, pgLang, and the Rwanda Government to create a platform that empowers African artists and communities while fostering global connections and collaborations. The project's primary goals are:

Elevating African Talent: 'Move Afrika' seeks to highlight the immense talent present in Africa's music and arts scene. By providing a platform for African artists to reach international audiences, the initiative aims to amplify their voices and stories on a global scale.

Fostering Cultural Exchange: This groundbreaking music touring circuit will serve as a bridge between African and international artists. It will encourage cultural exchange and collaboration, enriching the global music industry with the diverse and vibrant African music landscape.

Driving Social Impact: 'Move Afrika' is deeply committed to creating social change. Through its unique approach, the project will support education, healthcare, and economic development initiatives in the communities it visits, ensuring a positive impact reaches the local populations.

Building Economic Opportunities: The initiative aims to boost the African entertainment and tourism industries, creating jobs and economic opportunities across the continent. This sustainable model can lead to long-term benefits for African economies.

Pan-African Circuit: 'Move Afrika' is designed to travel to multiple African countries, showcasing the incredible cultural diversity and musical heritage of the continent.

Educational Programs: In each host country, 'Move Afrika' will collaborate with local educational institutions to provide music and arts education, offering opportunities for aspiring artists and young talents.

Philanthropic Initiatives: The project will support social and environmental initiatives in each host country. These will range from promoting access to clean water and healthcare to supporting education and sustainability efforts.

Sustainability: 'Move Afrika' will prioritize sustainability at every step of the journey, ensuring that the events have a minimal environmental footprint and promote eco-friendly practices.

As the 'Move Afrika' caravan sets forth on its musical journey, it carries with it the hope of a brighter and more connected future for Africa and the world.

''We were organising an Israel Rwanda Business forum that was meant to take place on the 16,October but now because of the war it all had come to a halt'' Ms Weiss remarked




''But i am still working hard to get people to go work in Israel especially like now most people have died, others kidnapped, yet we have fruits on tress rotting because no one to pick them''




This initiative aims to enhance agricultural productivity in Rwanda, drawing from Israel's expertise in innovative and sustainable farming practices. The project she has hope that Rwandans will be exposed to better farming mechanisms thus making a positive impact by increasing food security and improving livelihoods in rural communities upon return.




As Ambassador Weiss's tenure in Rwanda continues, her commitment to Africa remains resolute. She firmly believes that through cooperation, mutual understanding, and shared values, the future holds even greater promise for the continent.

"I have had the privilege to witness the growth, resilience, and beauty exhibited by Rwanda in only 30 years," Ambassador Weiss said, her eyes filled with determination. "This is a journey I am wholeheartedly committed to, and I am eager to see the positive impact we can create together."




Ambassador Einat Weiss's dedication to Israel-Rwanda relations and her passion for Africa serve as an inspiring example of how diplomacy, partnership, and genuine affection for a region can drive positive change and promote international cooperation. MESSI CROWNED G.O.A.T AGAIN

13:00, 2023-10-31

The Ballon d'Or. Love it or loathe it, it's the award every footballer in the world dreams of one day winning. And now, after a memorable and unique 2022-23 campaign, the winner of the 2023 Golden Ball has been announced: Lionel Messi.




The Argentina and Inter Miami forward picked up his eighth Ballon d'Or at a lavish ceremony in Paris on Monday, October 30 after a 2022-23 season that saw him finally get his hands on the trophy that had alluded him throughout his glittering career: The World Cup.

Messi won the Golden Ball at Qatar 2022 as the tournament's best player, and having also helped Paris Saint-Germain win another Ligue 1 title over the course of the campaign, he was able to beat out competition from the likes of Erling Haaland and former team-mate Kylian Mbappe for the award.




That trio were up at the very top of the rankings for 2023, but how did the rest of the 30-man shortlist shake out when all the votes were counted? Check out the official rankings below:




30Ruben Dias (Manchester City)

Man City effectively played with four centre-backs during their 2022-23 treble run, and Dias was the best of them all. His start to this season suggests he has no plans to slow down anytime soon.

29Martin Odegaard (Arsenal)

Saka was very good last year, but Odegaard was better. 15 very important goals and seven assists — all while wearing the armband — made for a standout season. An immense talent is now among the best players in Europe.




28Randal Kolo Muani (PSG)

One of France's brightest talents, Kolo Muani finally realised his potential last season, scoring 14 for a struggling Frankfurt outfit. That, plus a promising World Cup campaign, saw him earn a big-money move to Paris Saint-Germain, where he should flourish alongside France team-mate Kylian Mbappe.




27Nicolo Barella (Inter)

The heart and soul of one of Europe's best midfield trios, Barella was the driving force behind Inter's late-season magic. He's been impressive for a few years now, and has finally gotten some much-deserved recognition for it.




26Jamal Musiala (Bayern Munich)

One of Europe's brightest talents, Musiala continued to develop throughout 2023, bagging 12 goals and adding 10 assists as Bayern Munich made a late push for the Bundesliga title. His winner against Koln on the final day of the season will go down as one of the most important goals in club history.

25Josko Gvardiol (Man City)

A standout for both Croatia and RB Leipzig during the 2022-23 season, Gvardiol did enough to earn a big-money move to Man City. Chances are, he will get even better there.

24Bukayo Saka (Arsenal)

Another youngster always on the up, Saka was part of the reason Arsenal lept from fifth to second in 2023, scoring 14 and adding 11 assists in the Premier League. There will be much more to come from the PFA Young Player of the Year.

23Andre Onana (Manchester United)

Onana turned in countless big performances as Inter made an unexpected run to the Champions League final. And although his side lost to Man City in the showpiece, Onana was one of the best keepers in Europe last year.

22Kim Min-Jae (Bayern Munich)

Perhaps the signing of the season, Kim's defensive performances are a big part of the reason why Napoli achieved elusive Serie A glory. 'The Monster' should only improve under Thomas Tuchel at Bayern.

21Antoine Griezmann (Atletico Madrid)

Vini Jr and Ronald Araujo may have stood out, but many would argue for Griezmann as La Liga's best player last season. With 31 goal contributions in La Liga alone, his proponents might just have a point.

20Lautaro Martinez (Inter)

A World Cup winner's medal alone would be enough to justify his inclusion. Add Martinez's vital run for Inter at the back end of last season, and he can be considered one of the campaign's star performers.

19Harry Kane (Bayern Munich)

The best No.9 in Europe not named Erling Haaland, Kane had arguably his best season for a tumultuous Spurs side, scoring 30 in the Premier League.

18Jude Bellingham (Real Madrid)

It's hard to believe Bellingham just turned 20. The English midfielder was Dortmund's best player last season as they fell just short of the Bundesliga title, and has hit the ground running in Spain, too. He may not have won the award this year, but there seems to be one in his future.

17Khvicha Kvaratskhelia (Napoli)

Kvaratskhelia came out of nowhere in 2022-23, and swiftly announced himself as one of the best left-wingers in Europe. Napoli won their first Scudetto in 33 years last season, and couldn't have done it without their Georgian sensation, who tallied 22 goal contributions in Serie A alone.




16Karim Benzema (Al-Ittihad)

Benzema had an under-par season for Los Blancos and still managed to bag 19 goals in 24 La Liga starts — as well as a hat-trick against Barcelona in the Copa del Rey semi-final. Not bad for a 35-year-old with chronic injury issues.

15Emi Martinez (Aston Villa)

Argentina's World Cup win was all about Messi, but it couldn't have happened without Martinez, who made crucial saves in two penalty shootouts. His one-on-one stop against Kolo Muani late on in the final is worth a nomination alone.

14Ilkay Gundogan (Barcelona)

When Haaland endured a rare cold spell towards the end of last season, Gundogan picked up the slack. He was immense for Guardiola for a few years, and, at 33, is finally getting his plaudits. Barcelona will be delighted to have him.

13Yassine Bounou (Al-Hilal)

Morocco were the surprise side of the 2022 World Cup, and Bounou was a big reason why. His Europa League final heroics also helped Sevilla pick up more European silverware.

12Robert Lewandowski (Barcelona)

What else did you expect? Lewandowski wasn't at his best last year, and still scored 23 league goals to lead Barca to a first La Liga title in three years. He's ageing wonderfully.

10Luka Modric (Real Madrid)

Modric is slowing down slightly, but can still turn in masterful performances on a big stage — something he showed in the Champions League and World Cup. This might be his final nomination, but it is richly deserved.

9Bernardo Silva (Man City)

He was solid in the Premier League, but Silva's season will be best remembered for his showing in the Champions League semi-final, when he tore up Real Madrid to send City on the way to a historic treble. Guardiola must be grateful that one of his most loyal servants has elected to stay at the club.

8Victor Osimhen (Napoli)

He was always going to be good, but Osimhen found another level last year, tearing through Serie A to the tune of 26 goals and four assists. He added five in five starts in the Champions League for good measure, too.

7Julian Alvarez (Man City)

If Messi was the star for Argentina, Alvarez was the cutting edge - a crucial sidekick for a World Cup winning team. His impressive start to the 2023-24 season point towards another big campaign for a side that wants to build on its already historic successes.

6Vinicius Jr (Real Madrid)

Vinicius eclipsed the 20 goal and 20 assist mark for club and country last season, and is now Madrid's bonafide Galactico. Los Blancos will go as far as he can take them this year.

5Rodri (Man City)

A No.6 who can attack like a No.10 and defend like a centre-back, Rodri was arguably the most important player for Man City last year. His winning goal in the Champions League final wasn't bad, either.

4Kevin De Bruyne (Man City)

Haaland grabbed the headlines for City, but once again it was De Bruyne who pulled the strings for Pep Guardiola's side. They have won five of the last six Premier League titles and secured a treble in 2022-23, and De Bruyne is a big reason why.

3Kylian Mbappe (PSG)

World Cup final hat-tricks don't come around very often. Mbappe made his look easy. He wasn't bad at club level either, carrying the Parisians to the title with 29 in Ligue 1. Mbappe has hit the ground running for a revamped PSG to start this campaign, and could be in with a real shout for the award next season.

2Erling Haaland (Man City)

After scoring 52 goals for City last season, Haaland may feel hard done by not bringing home the top prize. He was a transformative talent for a team that somehow got better, and is showing no signs of slowing down.

1Lionel Messi (Inter Miami)

Finally. Messi completed football last season, winning a much-coveted World Cup, and playing a starring role in the process. His electric start to life in Miami has proved that there's still some life in those legs, too. Ballon d'Or No.8, accomplished.

INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND, GOV OF RWANDA REACH AGREEMENT ON IMPLEMENTATION OF ECONOMIC &FINANCIAL POLICIES.

12:29, 2023-10-31

Government of Rwanda officials and the

International Monetary Fund (IMF) mission team have on 31 October, reached a staff-level agreement on successful implementation of the economic and financial policies that were required to complete the second reviews under both the Policy Coordination instrument (PCI) and the Resilience and Sustainability Facility (RSF). The mission team and government officials also reached understandings on economic policies that will be supported under a new 14-month Stand-by Credit Facility (SCF) with total access of about US$ 262 million to help mitigate the balance of payment pressures arising from climate-related shocks.







In a statement released on 30 October, the IMF mission team noted that Rwanda coped with

overlapping recent shocks well, but external and domestic imbalances have intensified.

Economic growth remained robust at 6.3 percent in the second quarter of 2023, notwithstanding repeated droughts and the severe floods in May 2023.




Speaking at the conclusion of the Mission, Mr. Ruben Atoyan, the IMF Mission head said:

“Despite the challenging environment, macroeconomic policy performance through end-June 2023 remained broadly in line with program objectives under the PCI.''




''Most quantitative targets were met, and reforms to boost domestic revenue mobilization, advance expenditure rationalization, enhance fiscal transparency, and strengthen foreign exchange market functioning are progressing well.” Reuben added




The mission pointed out that going forward, increasing imbalances require further recalibration of policies to safeguard macroeconomic and external sustainability. Continued fiscal consolidation, proactive and data-driven monetary policy, and further exchange rate adjustment are necessary to rebuild buffers, curb inflation, and improve debt sustainability.

It urged implementation tax reforms to broaden the domestic tax base and improve tax compliance are critical for achieving Rwanda’s revenue objectives. The mission further called

for enhanced efficiency of public investments, better targeting of subsidies and transfers, and

digital delivery of public services.

The team commended strong progress on the climate agenda under the RSF. It noted that

reforms under the RSF will improve transparency and efficiency of allocation of climate-related

public spending and create a conducive environment for attracting climate finance. To further demonstrate the unwavering commitment to the RSF-supported climate agenda and to fully capitalize on the catalytic effect of the RSF, Rwanda is accelerating the implementation of the originally agreed reform measures to enhance the reform agenda by introducing new measures, including the implementation of an internationally recognized green taxonomy,




This agreement, which is subject to approval by the IMF Executive Board in December 2023,

will allow Rwanda to access about US$ 48.5 million under the RSF and US$ 87.5 million

under the SCF as noted by the Minister of finance and Economic planning Dr Uziel NdagijImana

UNDP RWANDA USES SCHOOLS TO SENSTISE COMMUNITIES ON CLEAN COOKING ENERGY.

13:56, 2023-10-30

The United Nations Development Programme Rwanda(UNDP) has embarked on a unique initiative to educate communities about the importance of clean cooking energy. The strategy? Using schools as a platform for outreach and information dissemination since most if not all students come from vast community backgrounds.




Recognizing the influence that educational institutions hold within communities, UNDP and partners Rwanda Environmental Management Authority (REMA) chose to collaborate with over 5 schools in Nyanza district through the famous Green Amayaga to drive their clean energy campaign with the aim to sensitize communities on the benefits of clean cooking energy and promote a shift away from traditional, harmful energy sources that were traditionally used such as firewood that fueled deforestation but also paved way for contamination of food, aiding of respiratory diseases and much more.




According to available research Schools, prisons and Hospitals have been named top consumers of firewood usage than any other sector making schools to serve as the epicenter of communities and play a crucial role in shaping societal norms and values. The initiative leverages this influence, encouraging students to act as ambassadors of change, spreading the word about clean cooking energy within their families and wider communities.




The programme introduced students to the concept of clean cooking energy, highlighting its environmental, health, and economic benefits making them the number one beneficiaries of timely meals served at lunch and dinner breaks yet their schools not mushroomed in smoke like it was in the previous times.

While speaking to the Head teacher of one of the beneficiary schools; Christ Roix High school in Nyanza district, he mentioned that there was a cost cutting on what the school has normally spent on cooking energy by 45%.

''It is expensive to use charcoal or firewood in very many terms, transport, cleaning and renovating the kitchens and utensils themselves yet food takes longer than when we use the Gas facilities that were given to us'' Said HakizaImana Innocent




''Matter of fact if we can get at least 6 more stoves we would totally get rid of the firewood section and fully transform our kitchen into a smart on especially now that we know that our students' meals can be prepared on gas and get ready quickly.'' HakizaImana added




The project has gone ahead to explain how clean energy sources are not just sustainable, but also reduce household air pollution, lower healthcare costs, and contribute to the global fight against climate change.

Additionally, the programme has kept it's focus on the grave health risks associated with traditional cooking methods that rely on biomass fuels like wood and charcoal. By making students aware of these risks, the UNDP hopes to inspire a shift towards clean cooking energy.




''The initiative also includes practical demonstrations of clean cooking technologies, sessions which give students, teaching and non teaching staff a firsthand experience of using clean energy sources, making the concept more tangible and relatable.'' Said Mable Nseng'Imana the district environmental officer.




''We requested UNDP to work with school administrators to adopt clean cooking energy in school cafeterias this move was not only to make schools more eco-friendly but also serve as a practical, everyday demonstration of the benefits of clean energy.'' Mable added




Through this initiative, UNDP aims to create a ripple effect, using the influence of schools to reach out to wider communities. As students take the message of clean cooking energy home, the hope is that families will be encouraged to adopt cleaner, safer, and more sustainable cooking methods.




The strategy is a brilliant example of how institutions can be employed to drive societal change with promises to make significant strides towards achieving Sustainable Development Goal 7 - ensuring access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern energy for all.

As schools become a hub for clean cooking energy awareness, UNDP and partners are not just educating a new generation but also fostering a healthier, more sustainable future.

























PARTNERS IN IMPACT: HOW UNDP AND HVP- GATAGRA ARE CHANGING LIVES IN RWANDA

12:49, 2023-10-30

In a move that promises to significantly advance healthcare access in Rwanda, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has partnered with HVP-Gatagara Orthopedic, Rehabilitation and Physiotherapy Hospital. This alliance aims to offer affordable and quality orthopedic and physiotherapy services to the country's residents, marking a significant stride towards improved healthcare.




The UNDP, through its numerous global initiatives, has always championed accessible and affordable healthcare, recognizing it as a fundamental human right. This partnership with HVP Orthopedic specialised Hospital serves as another testament to UNDP’s commitment to advancing the Sustainable Development Goals, particularly Goal 3 - ensuring healthy lives and promoting well-being for all at all ages.

HVP- Gatagara Orthopedic Hospital, a renowned institution in Rwanda, with its state-of-the-art facilities and a team of highly skilled medical professionals, has been at the forefront of orthopedic care and physiotherapy, however still lacked modern state of the art equipment to manufacture prosthetic limbs and its from this background that UNDP extended a helping hand in acquiring the machines. The hospital's mission aligns seamlessly with UNDP's commitment to fostering equitable access to quality healthcare services particularly those with disabilities.




By joining forces, these two entities aim to break down the barriers to healthcare access by making orthopedic and physiotherapy services more affordable for all residents of Rwanda. This partnership will focus on developing sustainable healthcare models, enhancing the skills of healthcare professionals, and increasing awareness of orthopedic care and physiotherapy among the general population.

Moreover, this collaboration is expected to fast-track the adoption of innovative healthcare solutions, such as telemedicine, to extend quality healthcare services to remote areas of the country. With the UNDP's global expertise and Gatagara Hospital's local knowledge and technical skill, the partnership aims to deliver a revolutionary change in Rwanda's healthcare landscape.

The alliance also underscores the importance of public-private partnerships in advancing healthcare access and quality. It's a model that has the potential to transform healthcare services, not just in Rwanda, but also her neighbours who are considered developing nations as well.




''This partnership between UNDP and HVP-Gatagara is more than just an alliance between two organizations. It's a beacon of hope for countless individuals who, until now, might have found quality healthcare services out of their reach due to financial constraints or geographical limitations. said Brother Kizito Misaga the director general of the hospital.




''As we look forward to the progress this partnership will bring, it's clear that this collaboration is a significant step towards a future where quality healthcare is not a privilege, but a right accessible to all.'' Bro Kizito added




However he continued to highlight challenges facing the hospital in which were understaffing, dilapidated infrastructure, adequate funding which was mainly affecting the low income earners who accessed some of the hospital services via the national insurance [Mutuelle desante] that could not cover some of the treatments if not a few sessions thus hindering treatment pattern.

LEWIS HAMILTON DISQUALIFIED: A TWIST IN THE TAPESTRY OF FORMULA 1

07:35, 2023-10-24

In yet another unexpected turn of the dramatic narrative in Formula One, Lewis Hamilton, the seven-time World Champion, was disqualified from a recent U S A Grand Prix. This news has undoubtedly sent shockwaves through the auto racing world and thrown an unexpected curveball into the ongoing championship as this was the second disqualification in a row.




Ever since his debut in 2007, Hamilton has been a dominating force in the Formula One circuit, with his tenacity and talent earning him a place amongst the sport's legends. But, as any seasoned fan knows, the world of Formula One is as much a test of strategy and adherence to rules as it is a showcase of speed and skill.

Hamilton was just two seconds behind Verstappen at the flag but his car was later declared illegal for excessive wear on the underfloor skid blocks.




Ferrari's Charles Leclerc suffered the same fate after finishing sixth.

Hamilton's disqualification promoted McLaren's Lando Norris to second and Ferrari's Carlos Sainz to third.

Verstappen was measured, slowly picking off the cars in front of him and then holding on for his 50th career win.

Hamilton passed Norris for second in the final laps but ran out of time to catch Verstappen for the lead. Although it's important to note that these rules are in place to ensure fair play and safety, the decision has sparked a flurry of debates among fans and pundits.




Hamilton's disqualification meant it was difficult to draw conclusions from a race after which, before the late technical drama, hindsight had left Hamilton and Mercedes ruing a lost potential victory had they played the strategy differently.

The skid blocks are in place to prevent teams running cars too low, which can be a potential aerodynamic advantage.

The Red Bull did not have the pace off-set it has had so often this year and Norris and Hamilton made Verstappen work for the win.

But Mercedes' inadvertent transgression confuses the picture of a race in which the team seemed to have made a step forward with an upgraded car.

Mercedes tried to make a one-stop strategy work while Verstappen and Norris went for a two, but the decision backfired on them and cost Hamilton more time than the margin by which he eventually lost the race.

SWEEPING CHANGE: RWANDA TO SUBSTITUTE WHEAT FLOUR WITH SWEET POTATO FOUR

12:28, 2023-10-23

As Rwanda moves to celebrate world food day on the 27 October, they take an unprecedented move to substitute wheat flour with sweet potato flour in an attempt to bolster food security, encourage local production, and promote healthier eating habits among its population. This groundbreaking initiative goes hand in hand with the country's commitment to sustainable agriculture and its ongoing efforts to combat the impacts of climate change but also workout a plan on the rising prices of wheat flour that have been hiking over the time.




This comes after Rwanda has started to look for alternative sources of wheat imports following hefty trade sanctions on its major supplier, Russia.

Prior to the sanctions, Rwanda heavily depended on Russia for wheat imports, with at least 64 per cent of the country’s wheat coming from Russia. However, Russia is now facing export and import sanctions as a consequence of its military incursion into Ukraine, which has disrupted this supply.

The data indicate that in 2019, Russia was Rwanda’s top wheat import partner where more than 73,324 tonnes worth $17.5 million (approx. Rwf21 billion) were imported, while in 2020, the United Kingdom came first with 67,145 tonnes of wheat for $16.1 million (approx. Rwf19 billion), followed by Russia with over 60,855 tonnes for $15.2 million (approx. Rwf18 billion).




However this will in turn be of an advantage to the country with the government looking forward to empower population to improve the production from just 8 to 30 tonnes per hectare using six new varieties. 

While speaking to press, Jean Ndirigwe, a sweet potato breeder at Rwanda Agriculture and Animal Resources Board (RAB) said, they have sweet potato varieties that can increase production and these Sweet potatoes can replace wheat in baking factories and cut the wheat imports

INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY SEES SAD NEWS FOR MARKETS FROM MIDDLE EAST WAR

11:58, 2023-10-17

Credit Ap News

The Israel-Hamas war is affecting oil markets already stretched by cutbacks in oil production from Saudi Arabia and Russia and expected stronger demand from China, the head of the International Energy Agency said Tuesday 17 October.




“As we see the tensions in the Middle East, the market becomes much more jittery, and it is definitely not good news coming out of this crisis,” Fatih Birol, executive director of the Paris-based IEA, told The Associated Press.




“We may very well see much more volatile prices, and it can push prices higher, which is definitely bad news for inflation,” he added.




Developing countries that import energy would be the most affected by higher prices, Birol said.

International benchmark Brent crude traded close to $90 per barrel on Tuesday, up from $85 on Oct. 6, the day before Hamas attacked Israel. Fluctuations last week pushed prices as high as $96.

WHAT KIND OF DRUG IS THE NEWLY APPROVED R21/Matrix-M?

07:39, 2023-10-05

According to Sir Brian Greenwood professor of clinical tropical medicine at London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, the R21/Matrix-M™ vaccine was along outstanding project of research developed by researchers at the University of Oxford and the Serum Institute of India.

The R21 as code named is the second malaria vaccine to be recommended for global use, following in the footsteps of the RTS,S vaccine evaluated by researchers at the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) and manufactured by GSK. 

Both the RTS,S and R21 vaccines induce an immune response to the same circumsporozoite protein antigen found on the surface of the Plasmodium falciparum sporozoite, the stage of the parasite injected by a mosquito. 




Sir Brian Greenwood, Professor of Clinical Tropical Medicine at LSHTM, who has paved the way in malaria research with his contributions to the development of the RTS,S vaccine, said: 

“The wait for an effective malaria vaccine has been a long one and it was only in October 2021 that World Health Organisation(WHO) recommended deployment of the world’s first malaria vaccine RTS,S. Now, two years later, a second malaria vaccine, R21, has also been approved by WHO. 

“No direct comparison of the two vaccines has been done, but it is likely that the level and duration of protection that each provides are similar, as they both induce a comparable immune response to their target antigen on the surface of the Plasmodium falciparum parasite.




“The manufacture and deployment of two similar malaria vaccines is not redundant. Restriction of vaccine production at a single site, or by a single company, carries a risk of interrupted supply should there be an unanticipated external event and further research will still be needed to study the long-term safety of R21. Production of the R21 vaccine is likely to be cheaper then RTS,S, which will help improve the reach of vaccination.'' Sir Greenwood said

Governments world over upon receiving this news, went on in high gear to prepare to rollout the vaccinations particularly to be deployed to areas prone to the disease considered to kill more people in the world than any other

Strengthening Collaboration

This partnership exemplifies the commitment to address the healthcare challenges faced by underserved regions and improve the overall well-being of the population. The Butaro Hospital expansion stands as a testament to the transformative power of collaboration in advancing healthcare services.

SCIENTISTS BEHIND THE COVID MRNA VACCINE TO MAKE IT ON THE LIST OF NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNERS.

09:03, 2023-10-02

Two scientists won the Nobel Prize in medicine on Monday 2 October for discoveries that enabled the development of mRNA vaccines against COVID-19.

The award was given to Katalin Karikó, a professor at Sagan’s University in Hungary and an adjunct professor at the University of Pennsylvania, and Drew Weissman, who performed his prizewinning research together with Karikó at the University of Pennsylvania.

“Through their groundbreaking findings, which have fundamentally changed our understanding of how mRNA interacts with our immune system, the laureates contributed to the unprecedented rate of vaccine development during one of the greatest threats to human health in modern times,” the panel that awarded the prize said.




Thomas Perlmann, secretary of the Nobel Assembly, announced the prize and said both scientists were “overwhelmed” by news of the prize when he contacted them shortly before the announcement

The Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine was won last year by Swedish scientist Svante Paabo for discoveries in human evolution that unlocked secrets of Neanderthal DNA which provided key insights into our immune system, including our vulnerability to severe COVID-19.

The award was the second in the family. Paabo’s father, Sune Bergstrom, won the Nobel Prize in medicine in 1982.

Nobel announcements continue with the physics prize on Tuesday3 October, chemistry on Wednesday and literature on Thursday. The Nobel Peace Prize will be announced Friday and the economics award on Oct. 9.

MALI TO POSTPONETHE 2024 ELECTIONS TO A LATER DATE

11:01, 2023-09-27

Mali’s military government on Monday 25 September said it would postpone February elections for technical reasons, further pushing back a timeline for a return to democratic rule after two coups.

Mali had been expected to hold the first round of the vote on Feb. 4, 2024, and a second round two weeks later, which was already a two-year delay to a timetable originally agreed by the West African country’s interim authorities.

The junta’s statement said the delay would be small and was due to several factors including a dispute with a French firm over a civil registry database. It said it would give a new timeline at a later date. This comes with accusations pointing to a French-based international tech company IDEMIA, which provided a civil identification system known as RAVEC to the former government, of holding its database “hostage” since March due to unpaid bills.

The situation makes it impossible to register newly eligible voters and update the voter registry, and is slowing down the roll out of a new biometric identity card, making it hard to go on with the organisation of the elections.

A spokesperson for IDEMIA however said that the company has no contract with Mali’s interim authorities and confirmed that its service had been shut down because of outstanding invoices.

A US judge ruled that Donald Trump committed fraud for years while building the real estate empire that catapulted him to fame and the White House, and he ordered some of the former president’s companies removed from his control and dissolved.

Judge Arthur Engoron, ruling in a civil lawsuit brought by New York Attorney General Letitia James on 27 September, found that Trump and his company deceived banks, insurers and others by massively overvaluing his assets and exaggerating his net worth on paperwork used in making deals and securing loans.

Engoron ordered that some of Trump’s business licenses be rescinded as punishment, making it difficult or impossible for them to do business in New York, and said he would continue to have an independent monitor oversee Trump Organization operations.

Trump, in a series of statements, railed against the decision, calling it “un-American” and part of an ongoing plot to damage his campaign to return to the White House.




“My Civil rights have been violated, and some Appellate Court, whether federal or state, must reverse this horrible, un-American decision,” he wrote on his Truth Social site. He insisted his company had “done a magnificent job for New York State” and “done business perfectly,” calling it “A very sad Day for the New York State System of Justice!”

Trump’s lawyer, Christopher Kise, said they would appeal, calling the decision “completely disconnected from the facts and governing law.”

20 MINNERS DIE IN A ROAD TRAGEDY IN SOUTH AFRICA.

08:57, 2023-09-18

At least 20 employees of mining giant De Beers have been killed in a road accident in South Africa, local officials said September 17.

The bus involved was ferrying staff from the Venetia mine, one of the biggest diamond mines in the country, said a transport official in Limpopo province, in the north of the country.

"The bus came into collision with a lorry," said Vongani Chauke.




Chauke told AFP the accident happened at around 1600 GMT, some 25 kilometres (15 miles) from the mine, at the village of Musian on the border with Zimbabwe.

The cause of the accident has not been established. South Africa has one of the most developed road networks on the continent, but also has one of the worst road safety records.




The Venetia mine, which lies near the borders with Botswana and Zimbabwe, has been run by the De Beers group for more than 30 years.

It accounts for more thatn 40 percent of the country's annual diamond production, employing more than 4,300 staff including many local people. It was once the country's largest open-cast mine, before De Beers invested $2 billion in a major underground project to access the less easily available diamonds . The group aims to produce four million carats a year.

In July, De Beers announced the start of underground diamond production from the new seams opened underneath the open-cast mine.

French regulators ordered Apple to stop selling the iPhone 12, saying it emits electromagnetic radiation levels that are above European Union standards for exposure. The company disputed the findings and said the device complies with regulations.

FLOODS ALOOW CROCODILES TO ROAM FREE IN CHINA

12:08, 2023-09-12










Authorities in a southern Chinese city have launched an operation to recapture more than 70 crocodiles that escaped from a commercial farm after intense flooding swept through the region, multiple state media outlets have reported, with some residents warned to stay indoors.

The toothy reptiles were originally kept at a crocodile farm in Maoming, in the southern province of Guangdong. But a recent deluge caused a local lake to overflow, allowing the animals to escape.

At least 69 adult crocodiles and six juveniles were on the prowl at one point near the village of Peng Cun, Shandong-based outlet Hai Bao News reported. The outlet said it contacted local authorities who had warned residents not to venture out




An emergency force was deployed to round up the missing crocs using sonar detection equipment, according to The Beijing News.

But the depth of the floodwater posed an immense challenge to the operation, it added, prompting authorities to appeal to residents not to leave their homes.

A member of the emergency squad told Nanfeng Plus that they may have to euthanize the crocodiles rather than capture them.




"Chinese crocs hibernate in the winter. We usually move them out of houses in March when the temperature is above 16 Celsius degrees," said workers at Anhui Yangtze Alligator Reserve in Xuancheng city.

Wild Chinese crocodiles often go through the hibernation in a cave in winter, while alligators bred in captivity spend the period indoors.

Each one needs to do physical examination and only healthy and strong ones are allowed to get outside, the reserve said.




"They are still in the semi-dormancy period and can not eat or drink right after they were move out. They live on their saved energy," said workers at the reserve. "They will not start to eat until April when the temperature rises above 25 Celsius degrees. We will feed them some mussels and snails to practice their hunting skills."

Members of an emergency force search for escaped crocodiles on boats in Maoming.

This comes after  Revenue Authority (RRA) has taken a step to curb tax evasion and avoidance by inaugurating an information exchange office dedicated to enhancing collaboration with tax authorities in other nations. This initiative seeks to fortify efforts against illicit financial flows while promoting transparency in taxation.




The Rwanda Revenue Authority officials anticipate that the newly established office will augment the institution's capabilities in exchanging tax-related information, reinforcing Rwanda's commitment to fostering transparency and responsible financial practices.

Richard Tusabe, the Minister of State in charge of the National Treasury, emphasized the pivotal role of this office in combating illicit financial flows.

Rwanda has committed to adhering to both the Exchange of Information upon Request (EOIR) and the Automated Exchange of Information on Financial Accounts (AEOI) standards under this partnership. INDIA TO CHANGE COLONIAL NAME TO REPUBLIC OF BHARAT.

12:08, 2023-09-07

 Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government has set stage to replace the name India with a Sanskrit word in dinner invitations sent to guests attending this week’s Group of 20 summit, in a move that reflects his Hindu nationalist party’s efforts to eliminate what it sees as colonial-era names.

Indian President Droupadi Murmu is referred to as “President of Bharat” instead of “President of India” as formerly known, in the invitation sent to G20 attendees. The nation of more than 1.4 billion people is officially known by two names, India and Bharat, but the former is most commonly used, both domestically and internationally.

Bharat is an ancient Sanskrit word which many historians believe dates back to early Hindu texts. The word also means India in Hindi.




The change in nomenclature is backed by officials of Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party. They argue that the name India was introduced by British colonial masters and is a “symbolises slavery.” The British imposed their rule unto India for about 200 years until the country gained independence in 1947.

Modi’s party has long tried to erase names related to India’s Mughal and colonial past.

In 2015, New Delhi’s famous Aurangzeb Road, named after a Mughal king, was changed to Dr. APJ Abdul Kalam Road after protests from Modi’s party leaders. Last year, the government also renamed a colonial-era avenue in the heart of New Delhi that is used for ceremonial military parades.

Modi’s government says the name changes are an effort to reclaim India’s Hindu past.




“Another blow to slavery mentality,” the top elected official of Uttarakhand state, Pushkar Singh Dhami, said on X, formerly known as Twitter. Dhami, who is a leader of Modi’s governing party, shared the dinner invitation sent to G20 guests in his post.

Both leaders inspected an honor guard and then headed for talks that focused on regional efforts to find a settlement to the conflict in Sudan, according to the Sovereign Council.




In April, simmering tensions between the military, led by Burhan, and the powerful paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, commanded by Mohammed Hamdan Dagalo, exploded into open fighting in the capital and elsewhere.

The fighting has reduced Sudan’s capital, Khartoum, to an urban battlefield, with neither side managing to gain control of the city. The military headquarters, where Burhan has purportedly been stationed since the conflict began, has been one of the epicenters of the conflict which has had very much life threatening impacts like more than

 500 children who have died from hunger in Sudan since fighting erupted in April,millions that have lost their parents and fled the country as refugees

The Business Development Fund (BDF) on Monday 28 August announced and signed MOUs with partners to fully rollout the new product that is meant to even further more availability of funding for all Rwandans.

This collaboration with prominent financial institutions will see the introduction of what is known as the Partial Credit Guarantee.




The official signing event took place on Monday, August 28 at the BDF head office in Kigali.

This groundbreaking initiative is designed to foster a supportive environment for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in Rwanda, by addressing barriers to accessing finance and facilitating the growth of the MSME ecosystem.




The Partial Credit Guarantee of BDF aims to provide a comprehensive solution for MSMEs

seeking financial support. Through this program, BDF is committed to removing obstacles

that often hinder MSMEs from accessing the necessary capital for growth and development. The program&#39;s vision is to create a thriving environment that enables MSMEs to flourish and contribute significantly to Rwanda&#39;s economic landscape.




Key Objectives of the Partial Credit Guarantee:

Accessibility: The program aims to enhance accessibility to finance for MSMEs, ensuring

that deserving businesses have the financial resources they need to thrive.

Demand-Driven Solutions: BDF is dedicated to providing solutions that are tailored to the

specific needs of MSMEs, promoting sustainable growth and success.




Sector Expertise: The program leverages sector expertise to guide and support MSMEs

through their financial journey, enabling them to make informed decisions.

Targeted beneficiaries of the Partial Credit Guarantee.







At this event was the CEO of the Development Bank Of Rwanda {BRD} Ms Kampeta Sayinzoga, who signed on behalf of BDF but also said as BRD they were excited to these possibilities that are happening to avail financing for all Rwandan businesses regardless of the size.




''Our role as a bank is to ensure the growth and development of all Rwandans through availing financing and favorable financial solutions to them as individuals or even as cooperatives, which we believe with this initiative that will be achieved.'' Kampeta added




Business Development Fund (BDF)CEO Vicent Munyeshaka said that they were looking forward to increase their financing to up to Rwf 14 billion in this financial year. He said it's from the confidence they have had the past successful financial years where they have usedRwf6 billion and achieved quite tangible and visible results.




''We work with very many financial insitutions in the country to get our different products to the grass root, we are not limited to only SACCOS.

Because the origin of this was to be able to avail financial services to all Rwandans regardless of where they are.'' Munyeshaka added.




The Partial Credit Guarantee program encompasses a range of benefits for MSMEs,

including preferential access to finance and affiliated services. The program&#39;s scope

extends to special groups such as people living with disabilities, vulnerable genocide

survivors, and veterans.




WORLD'S BIGGEST AUTO MAKER RECOVERS FROM SYSTEM MALFUNCTION.

11:58, 2023-08-29




World's biggest auto make Toyota will resume operations at its Japanese assembly plants Wednesday 30 August after a 24-hour stoppage caused by disruption to its finely-tuned supply chain.

This big name automaker by sales said that its 14 vehicle factories in the country had paused activity because a system malfunction that began on Monday 28 August was preventing it from processing orders for automotive components.




Production is expected to be back to normal at all 14 plants in Japan from the start of the second shift on Wednesday30 August, the company said in a statement.

“It is our understanding that the malfunction of the system was not caused by a cyber attack. However, we will continue to investigate the cause,” Toyota (TM) said. “We would like to apologize once again to our customers, suppliers, and related parties for any inconvenience caused by the suspension of operations.”

Toyota was a pioneer of “just-in-time” production, which is based on the delivery of component parts to assembly plants in the right quantities just before they are required. The system saves warehouse space and money but is vulnerable to disruption if any link in the chain is broken.

Analysts said Toyota could be tested in making up for output lost during the outage, such as by running extra shifts.

"Output was running at full capacity so there's little additional room for production," said Seiji Sugiura, an analyst at Tokai Tokyo Research Institute.




Toyota is a pioneer of just-in-time inventory management, which keeps down costs but means supply chain snarls put production at risk.

While the cause of the latest malfunction was unclear, corporate Japan has been on alert in recent days as businesses and government offices reported harassing phone calls.

The government said the calls were likely from China and related to Japan's release of treated radioactive water from the wrecked Fukushima nuclear power plant into the Pacific Ocean.

Toyota's share price closed down 0.21% at 2,431.5 yen after spending much of the morning deeper in negative territory.

''AFRICA TO BE INVITED TO THE G 20 SUMMIT'' INDIA PM MODI SAID

11:30, 2023-08-29

Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said the country’s role as the G20 host this year would focus on highlighting the concerns of the developing world, and has proposed the African Union to become permanent members of the forum.

“We have a vision of inclusiveness and with that vision, we have invited the African Union to become permanent members of the G20,” Modi said on Sunday as he addressed the Business 20 Summit in New Delhi.

The B20 is an industry event and part of the summit of the 20 leading rich and developing nations, which will be hosted in the Indian capital next month.




Over three days, industry and policy leaders from around the world have discussed themes like building resilient supply chains, digital transformation, debt distress facing developing countries and how to advance on climate change goals. Their recommendations will be shared with the G20 governments, organizers said.

As host of the G20 this year, India has struggled to bridge the differences among member countries over the war in Ukraine. None of the several meetings held in the country has succeeded in producing a communique, sparking questions over whether the leaders meeting next month will break the deadlock.

Instead, India has consistently appealed for the fractured grouping to reach consensus on issues that disproportionately affect developing countries, or the so-called Global South. They include unsustainable debt levels, inflation and the threat of climate change, even if the broader East-West split over Ukraine can’t be resolved.

A key part of that strategy is bringing the African Union into the G20 fold, analysts say.

“When India assumed the G20 presidency last December, we were acutely conscious that most of the Global South would not be at the table when we meet,” said External Affairs Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar. “This mattered very much because the really urgent problems are those faced by them. ... And India, itself so much a part of the Global South, could not stand by and let that happen.”

NEW TRANSPORTATION LAW TO SHIFT TENDERING TO LOCAL GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES.

07:22, 2023-08-28

Rwanda's utility governing authority commonly know as RURA,will no longer be responsible for issuing tenders to public transport operators in the country.

The newly established law governing land and waterways transport. explains that;

 Local government authorities, such as city administrations, will assume the role of issuing tenders. However, RURA will maintain its oversight function in regulating private transport companies, ensuring they meet all necessary requirements before applying for tenders.




This comes as a move to decentralize the power and management system of the transport sector in the country which has been facing criticism from the citizens who are the main consumers and being named as inefficient, yet this blame would be transferred unto the regulators by the operators.

Patricie Uwase, the Minister of Infrastructure, explained that the institution responsible for both issuing tenders (RURA) and regulating public transport operators created an operational overlap, leaving room for inefficiencies.




"In cities like Kigali where public transport is essential, tenders will now be directly negotiated between private investors and city administrations, rather than through RURA. Nevertheless, RURA will continue to play a pivotal role in ensuring that investors fulfill the prerequisite criteria before submitting their bids," she added.




The new law stipulates that  investors will first need to approach RURA to obtain a license before participating in public transport tender processes facilitated by city authorities. To streamline the process and reduce bureaucracy, all licensing and tender application services will be consolidated into a one-stop center known as the Mobility Department.




This comes as a way to encourage other investors in the sector which was also followed by the a promising partnership between the government and Vivo Energy is set to bring 205 electric buses to the country next year. To accommodate these electric buses, Rwanda is actively working on establishing the necessary infrastructure, including charging stations.

Vivo Energy Rwanda will spearhead the procurement of electric buses and the establishment of a dedicated charging and maintenance depot.




This collaboration stems from a comprehensive feasibility study conducted by Vivo Energy in conjunction with the Ministry of Infrastructure and the City of Kigali, with a specific focus on electrifying Kigali's public bus fleet.

THE MOST FAMOUS MUG SHOT IN THE HISTORY OF USA-'' WAS TRUMP GENUINELY ANGRY OR IT'S ANOTHER FAME STUNT?''

06:12, 2023-08-25

The modern day photography gadget known as a camera clicks, in just a blink of an eye also referred to as a fraction of a second, the shutter opens and then closes, freezing forever the image in front of it.

When the camera shutter blinked inside a jail in downtown Atlanta on Thursday August 24, it both created and documented a tiny inflection point in American life. Captured for posterity, there was a former president of the United States, for the first time in history, under arrest and captured in the sort of frame more commonly associated with drug dealers or drunken drivers.




The trappings of power gone, for that split second.Left behind: an enduring image that will appear in history books long after Donald Trump is gone.

In the photo, Trump confronts the camera in front of a bland gray backdrop, his eyes meeting the lens in an intense glare. He’s wearing a blue suit, white shirt and red tie, his shoulders squared, his head tilted slightly toward the camera.

The sheriff’s logo has been digitally added above his right shoulder.




Some of the 18 others charged with him in Georgia smiled in their booking photos like they were posing for a yearbook. Not Trump.

His defiance is palpable, as if he’s staring down a nemesis through the lens.




Trump is unlikely to treat the mug shot as a moment of shame as he seeks a second term in the White House while fighting criminal charges in four jurisdictions. His campaign has reported a spike in contributions each time he’s been indicted.

And the imagery itself? Trump hasn’t shied away from it. In fact, his campaign concocted one long before it became real.

Months before he was photographed in Georgia on Thursday evening, his campaign used the prospect of a mug shot as a fundraising opportunity. For $36, anyone can buy a T-shirt with a fake booking photo of Trump and the words “not guilty.” Dozens of similar designs are available to purchase online, including many that appeal to Trump’s critics.

Now they have a real one to work with. Within minutes of the mug shot’s release, Trump’s campaign used it in a fundraising appeal on its website. “BREAKING NEWS: THE MUGSHOT IS HERE,” reads the subject line of the campaign’s latest fundraising email, which advertises a new T-shirt with the image. And this quote: “This mugshot will forever go down in history as a symbol of America’s defiance of tyranny.”

CANADA CONSIDERING A 10 POINT RECOMMENDATION APPROACH TO SOLVE HOUSING CRISIS.

13:21, 2023-08-23

The federal government is examining its approach to immigration as part of a wider look at what is driving Canada's housing crunch and what it can do about it.The Liberal government set new immigration targets last fall that would see Canada welcome 500,000 newcomers in 2025. That compares with 341,000 immigrants arriving in 2019, and a record high of 431,645 in 2022




Immigration Minister Marc Miller said Tuesday that at present he has no intention of adjusting that target, but that population growth fuelled by new arrivals cannot be ignored as the federal Liberal cabinet considers what is behind a worsening affordability crisis for buying or renting a home.







"I don't see a world in which (changing the target) happens, but again, I'm going to be looking at the facts and I'm not a dogmatic person," he said in Charlottetown, where federal ministers are holding a three-day retreat.

"We have to look at what that impact is, and what the impact of immigrants actually is on the housing supply."

Multiple ministers, including Miller, stressed that immigrants are not to blame for Canada's housing challenges, but he said the volume of immigration, including international students, does impact the availability of housing.

"You'll find a wide divergence of views of what that impact is, of immigration on housing," he said.

"Volume is volume, and it does have an impact. There's no denying that. But the specific role that immigration plays in certain areas is something we have to kind of break down a little more."

The housing crisis is a chief topic of conversation at the retreat, which comes as the federal Liberals prepare their agenda for the fall sitting of Parliament.

The Liberals introduced a national housing strategy in 2017, promising to spend billions over a decade to restore Ottawa's involvement in building social housing. In 2019, legislation was passed designating housing as a human right.

But little progress has been made to improve the situation, and the post-pandemic cost-of-living crisis, rising interest rates and rapid population growth are exacerbating the problem.

The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. estimates Canada needs about 5.8 million new homes by 2030 to restore housing affordability.







In Charlottetown, ministers received a briefing on Tuesday afternoon from two national housing and homelessness experts who last week published a report identifying 10 ways the federal government could improve the situation.

That included a national housing accord between the federal government, provinces, municipalities, housing builders and not-for-profit agencies. The report pointed to a lack of co-ordination between those responsible for housing as one thing getting in the way.

On Monday August 21, Housing Minister Sean Fraser said it was too early to commit to all 10 recommendations in the report, but that the government would be examining them and deciding what the next steps will be.




"So there's a number of different elements to what we want to do next," he said.

"How we precisely frame it, and whether that is a revisitation of the national housing strategy, is something that I'm sure we're going to get into really interesting discussions on over the course of the next couple of days here in Charlottetown," he said.

ZIMBABWE GOES TO SECOND POLL AFTER THE OUSTING OF MUGABE.

12:48, 2023-08-23

Delays marked voting in Zimbabwe on Wednesday as President Emmerson Mnangagwa seeks a second and final term in a country with a history of violent and disputed elections.

This is the second general election since the ouster of longtime ruler Robert Mugabe in a coup in 2017.




Twelve presidential candidates are on the ballot, but the main contest is expected to be between 80-year-old Mnangagwa, known as “the crocodile,” and 45-year-old opposition leader Nelson Chamisa. Mnangagwa narrowly beat Chamisa in a disputed election in 2018.

Chamisa hopes to break the ruling ZANU-PF party’s 43-year hold on power. Zimbabwe has had only two leaders since gaining independence from white minority rule in 1980.A runoff election will be held Oct. 2 if no candidate wins a clear majority in the first round. The election will also determine the makeup of the 350-seat parliament and nearly 2,000 local council positions.




“It’s becoming tougher to survive in this country,” said Basil Chendambuya, an early voter in a working-class township in Harare. “I am hoping for change. This is my third time to vote and I am praying hard that this time my vote counts. I am getting desperate, so God has to intervene this time round.”

The father of three said his two adult children are working menial jobs and surviving “hand to mouth.”




The southern African nation of 15 million people has vast mineral resources, including Africa’s largest reserves of lithium, a key component in making electric car batteries. But watchdogs have long alleged that widespread corruption and mismanagement have gutted much of the country’s potential.
