FROM TRIBULATIONS, TRAIL TO TROPHIES, REFUFUGEE ATHLETES DOMINATE IN THE SPORTING WORLD.

11:42, 2023-06-20

They say sport has the power to change lives.

What might sound like a cliche to many, holds immense truth for people like Marzieh Hamidi and Ahmad Badreddin Wais.

It was the sport that gave Hamidi and Wais a refuge from the tribulations of a life defined by war and conflict, factors completely out of their control.

However, what did give them a semblance of control over their destiny was a sport, combined with sheer hard work, grit, and a passion for their discipline of choice.

Both Hamidi and Wais are refugees, among the tens of millions around the world driven out of their homes and homelands by the evils of men or the forces of nature.

On World Refugee Day, marked globally on June 20, they shared their inspirational stories with A a jounalist at Anadolu – stories that may have played out thousands of miles apart but are equally powerful testaments to the resilience of the human spirit.




Ahmad Badreddin Wais kept alive only to Live the Olympic dream’

Unlike Hamidi, Wais, 32, is a professional road cyclist who was born in Aleppo, back when the northwestern Syrian city knew peace.

He was a university student when the civil war, which has claimed countless lives and left the country in ruins, erupted in 2011.




Three years later, Wais had no other option but to leave Syria, like all the dreamful youth taking the perilous sea route to Greece.

He was eventually granted refugee status in Switzerland, where he has been living for eight years.

He competed in the World Championship four times and acquired an IOC Refugee Athlete Scholarship, before being selected for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

Whereas Marzieh Hamidi: ‘Born a refugee’ rising to glory.

Hamidi was born into an Afghan refugee family in Iran 21 years ago.

It was in Iran that she first took up taekwondo, a sport in which she is now widely considered a rising star.

Hamidi and her family returned to Afghanistan in 2019 with high hopes, but fate had other plans in store.

“I was born in Iran as a refugee. When I moved to my country, I moved with a lot of hope. I said to myself: ‘I’m going to my country. I will be in the national team of my country’,” Marzieh told Anadolu.

In August 2021, two years after her return, the Taliban retook power in Afghanistan.

She was living in the capital Kabul, but soon made the difficult choice of leaving her homeland.

“I left Afghanistan because of the Taliban. They said that women are not allowed to study, to do sport, or to do whatever they want. They said that women should stay at home … everything was punished,” she said.

Hamidi’s coach soon told her that girls could no longer continue with their training. She saw women being barred from sports in the country and how her fellow athletes were forced to abandon all that they loved.

“When I went outside in the street and I saw the Taliban, it was more painful for me because, every day, I could see what’s happening in my country to my people,” she said.

Hamidi was evacuated to France a couple of months later and now lives in Paris.

She holds an International Olympic Committee (IOC) Refugee Athlete Scholarship and is aiming to join the Refugee Olympic Team for the 2024 Paris Games.

Her journey in taekwondo began with some encouragement from a friend at her school in Iran.

“When I started taekwondo, it felt like something that was more than just fun for me. I felt like something was going out of my body, like the stress and pain,” she said.

“I won a silver medal in my first fight. My coach told me if you continue like this, you can have a good future in taekwondo. That’s when I chose to be a professional taekwondo athlete, and I’ve given all my life to taekwondo.”

“This is a landmark deal where we bring focus and support to basketball as part of our vision to promote sport in the country and regionally. Our vision is to tap into opportunities that create a development avenue for our sports men and

women while giving fans an entertaining experience,” Mouyelo remarked.




Mouyelo said Rwanda’s basketball growth is an African success story set to inspire policy makers and federations across the continent.




“We just witnessed the successful hosting of the BAL finals here in Kigali last month, an event that brought about people of all walks of life together including former and current sports stars,” he remarked.

This, he added, is why Rwanda’s basketball is going places; noting that the fans, government and FERWABA have done their part to promote the game and, Mchezo couldn’t wait to enter into partnership and turbo charge these efforts.

RWANDA ON SET TO TRY HIV VACCINE- INTERNATIONAL AIDS VACCINE INNITIATIVE SAYS.

11:23, 2023-06-14

The trial process that began in 2021 involving Rwanda and South Africa has been reported to be attaining incredible progress as results continue to exhibit arrow head hope.




This trial process of an mRNA vaccine for HIV in Rwanda is known to be sponsored by a global non profit organisation called the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI), which has had a couple of parteners on deck to make this process swift and yet result oriented. Moderna's mRNA HIV vaccine being tried in the two countries is believed to have an  effectiveness of eOD-GT8 60mer, an HIV immunogen developed by scientific teams at IAVI and Scripps Research via the Modern’s mRNA platform.




The project code named  IAVI G003 was given to a trial in Rwanda and South Africa and is meant to build upon earlier advancements in HIV vaccine research that were documented from findings in the IAVI G001, a previous trial conducted in the USA which  demonstrated that vaccination with the immunogen safely induced the desired immune responses in 97 percent of healthy adult recipients all over the US.




This trial IAVI G003 seeks to test the hypothesis that vaccination with eOD-GT8 60mer can elicit similar immune responses in African populations as observed in USA’s IAVI G001.Progress insights on the first phase of the trials had triggered optimism about their trajectory as expressed by Karie Youngdahl, the Executive Director of Communications at IAVI.




"We are confident that the IAVI G003 Phase I trial is on a promising track. Earlier this year, we presented interim analysis from a related US-based trial called IAVI G002 at scientific meetings and a Moderna forum. The preliminary results from mRNA delivery of the same vaccine candidate used in IAVI G003 suggest that the vaccine candidate, when delivered via mRNA, induces immunological responses that are equally or more robust than when delivered via protein in a previous US trial known as IAVI G001," Karie said




 ‘’ In as much as all vaccinations have been administered in this phase of trial, volunteer follow-up and data analysis is ongoing, given the complex nature of the vaccination approach pursued by IAVI and partners. We anticipate conducting more Phase I trials as we refine aspects of what is believed will be a sequential vaccine regimen," she added.




There is an aim to enroll a total of 18 healthy, HIV-negative adult volunteers across multiple trial sites and these participants will receive two doses of eOD-GT8 60mer, which contains a portion of the viral sequence that cannot cause HIV infection.

Participants are monitored for safety for six months after receiving the final dose, and their immune responses are extensively analyzed to evaluate the achievement of targeted responses.




Dr. Gallican Rwibasira, the manager of the HIV Division at Rwanda Biomedical Center (RBC), emphasized the significance of such vaccine trials as an opportunity for Rwanda, a country guided by scientific evidence.




"Clinical trials provide the best evidence for strategies and interventions," he said, adding that Rwanda's well-established HIV program can attract further trials and clinical investigations to support continued control of the epidemic




It should be noted that in South Africa the same trials are being spearheaded by the Desmond Tutu.

Desmond Tutu Foundation was founded by the famous South African cleric to carry out HIV research and find treatments, including a vaccine. The foundation also studies other diseases such as tuberculosis, which is often comorbid with HIV, as well as COVID-19.

Researchers at the foundation hope messenger RNA technology may provide a breakthrough in their search for a vaccine but warn that HIV is a more complex virus.

10:36, 2023-06-13

Traders in the Central Rift and parts of western Kenya have decried the Kenya Dairy Board's blockade of milk imports from neighboring Uganda.

The fighters massacred vulnerable displaced people at the Lala displacement site in Djugu territor.

''some of the people were burnt inside their houses'' noted one local person.

IRAN UNVEILS THEIR NEWEST MARC-15 FATTAH MISSILE.

12:16, 2023-06-12

The new weapon unveiled by the government in Tehran on Tuesday is said to travel at 15 times the speed of sound; it appears to have a movable nozzle, which could allow it to evade air defences. The code named Marc - 15 missile was unveiled in a tightly choreographed segment on state TV, and no footage was released of it successfully launching and striking a target.




The new missile – called Fattah, or “Conqueror” in Farsi – was unveiled even as Iran announced it would reopen its diplomatic posts in Saudi Arabia after reaching a detente with Riyadh following years of conflict.

The tightly choreographed segment on Iranian state television apparently sought to show that Tehran’s hard-line government can still deploy arms against its enemies across much of the Middle East.




While speaking at the launching event,Iranian president Ebrahim Raisi said, they felt that the deterrent power had been formed.




“This power is an anchor of lasting security and peace for the regional countries.”Ebrahim added




General Amir Ali Hajizadeh, the head of the paramilitary Revolutionary Guard’s aerospace programme, unveiled what appeared to be a model of the missile. Hajizadeh asserted that the missile had a range of up to 1,400km (870 miles).




This comes as the by far greatest modern war weapon yet show cased by the Iranian government to the world as a way of no amount of intimidation would let them backoff from their extensive military hardware development.



















That is about mid-range for Iran’s expansive ballistic missile arsenal, which the Guard has built up over the years as Western sanctions largely prevent it from accessing advanced weaponry.

“There exists no system that can rival or counter this missile,” Hajizadeh claimed.

That claim, however, depends on how manoeuvrable the missile is. Ballistic missiles fly on a trajectory in which anti-missile systems like the Patriot can anticipate their path and intercept them.

The schemes are pension; occupational hazards; medical scheme (consisting of medical insurance for formal employees of public and private sectors); maternity leave, community-based health insurance scheme (CBHI); and the long-term savings scheme (EjoHeza) which is mainly meant for retirement benefits for informal sector workers.




''The training of the personnel is a key ingredient to deliver the RSSB strategic plan 2025 to make RSSB a Member First, Data Driven, High Performing modern organization.'' Said Regis Rugemanshuro CEO RSSB




He also pointed out that this particular training by ILO, among many others, equipped RSSB personnel, especially managers with the required up-to-date knowledge and skills for efficient social security administration.




Participants in the training highlighted that it was fruitful as it equipped staff with knowledge of governance structure and mechanisms that support and promote good governance practice in key areas of social security administration and governance.




one of the RSSB staff in attendance, James Nkurunziza, said “we are going to do whatever possible to implement what we have learnt from the training, more especially in extension of coverage [particularly to the informal sector].”

TRUMP IN TROUBLE WITH THE LAW AGAIN, HIS LAWYERS RESIGN.

16:45, 2023-06-09

A federal grand jury has indicted Donald Trump again on seven charges, including conspiracy to obstruct, in special counsel Jack Smith's classified documents investigation. The former president broke the news of his indictment on his Truth Social platform tonight. He says he has been summoned to appear in Miami federal court on Tuesday 13 June.

Trump is now the first U.S president, sitting or former, to face federal charges whose root charge sheet is under the Espionage Act, his attorney Jim Trusty told the news on Thursday 8 June, as well as charges of obstruction of justice, destruction or falsification of records, conspiracy and false statements.




The prosecution side is said to have been investigating Trump’s handling of classified documents that were brought to his Mar-a-Lago Florida resort after he left the White House in 2021, as well as possible obstruction of the investigation and government efforts to retrieve the material.




The former president who wrote on his Truth Social platform that he had been informed  by the Justice Department  to appear in a Miami court on Tuesday 13 June.




“The corrupt Biden Administration has informed my attorneys that I have been Indicted, seemingly over the Boxes of Hoax,” Trump posted




This federal indictment is the second time that Trump has been charged criminally this year. In April, the Manhattan district attorney charged Trump with 34 counts of falsifying business.

But the indictment from the special counsel marks a new and more perilous legal phase for a former president, who is running for president again in 2024 while facing criminal charges in two jurisdictions – and with two additional investigations into his conduct still underway.




Meanwhile Two lawyers who represented Donald Trump in the months before the former president was indicted on federal charges over his handling of classified documents quit working for him. The attorneys, Jim Trusty and John Rowley, did not explain in detail why they had resigned, other than to say that “this is a logical moment” to do so given his indictment Thursday in U.S. District Court in Miami.

Trump said he would now be represented by Todd Blanche, a New York lawyer who is representing him in another criminal case in Manhattan related to a 2016 hush money payment to porn star Stormy Daniels.

IS TAIWAN SAFE; CHINESE FIGHTER JETS ARE SEEN ON THE RADARS.

12:30, 2023-06-08

Taiwan activated its defence systems on Thursday 8 after reporting a 37 Chinese military aircraft swarm into the island's air defence zone, some of which then flew into the western Pacific, in Beijing's latest mass air incursion.




Democratically governed island of Taiwan has been viewed by the worlds emerging super power as one of their territories and so has often times flown it's air force crafts over the Taiwan air space.




Taiwan's defence ministry said that from 5 a.m. (2100 GMT on Wednesday 7) it had detected 37 Chinese air force planes, including J-11 and J-16 fighters as well as nuclear-capable H-6 bombers, flying into the southwestern corner of its air defence identification zone also known as ADIZ. The ADIZ is a system that was deployed by the Taipei government to monitor their borders and also avail enough time for their response forces to prepare for any counter insurgence.




The ready Taiwan sent it's aircraft and ships to keep watch and activated land-based missile systems, using its standard wording for how it responds to such Chinese activity.

China's defence ministry had not yet responded to a request for comment.




China who's also said to have completed a second phase of joint air patrols with Russia over the Western Pacific on Wednesday7, following flights on the previous day over the Sea of Japan and East China Sea, prompting concern in Japan over its national security.

Paul Kagame made a major shakeup in the military leadership that saw the appointment of a new Minister of Defence Juvénal Marizamunda succeeding Maj Gen Albert Murasira whereas Lt Gen Mubarakh Muganga was appointed as the new Chief of Defence Staff, taking over from Gen Jean-Bosco Kazura.

The dismissals were announced in a statement issued by RDF dated June 7.

“His Excellency the President of the Republic of Rwanda and C-in-C of RDF has dismissed from RDF Maj Gen Aloys Muganga, Brig Gen Francis Mutiganda along with 14 officers. He has also authorized the dismissal of 116 other ranks and approved the rescission of service contracts of 112 other ranks. The dismissals and rescission of service contracts take immediate effect,” read the statement.




Army spokesman Brig.Gen. Ronald Rwivanga told media that the two long-serving generals, Major General Aloys Muganga and Brigadier General Francis Mutiganda, had been dismissed on grounds of "indiscipline."

"According to the law, this means that they have to hand over military equipment and leave the army without any benefits, because of what they did," he added , 

This in accordance to the 2015 law on downsizing, discharge, demobilisation and dismissal in RDF, officers or troops can be dismissed due to gross misconduct. These were dismissed along with 14 other officers from Rwanda Defence Force (RDF).

It has been said that on realising the machine had claimed a life, the driver swiftly ran away shortly before the police could arrive.

The Rwanda national police traffic unit arrived to asses the situation and shortly swung in action with their heavy duty break downs to retrieve the wreckage and the body was taken to the morgue.

While speaking to the police spokes person CPJB Kabera, he said that the accident was very unfortunate, and that is why they continue to encourage the public to be careful while using the roads especially in such places that are considered blind spots.

''Every accident is unfortunate , because 80% of the accidents are avoidable according to all available reports, so road users should know, understand this and if they drive carefully, then we will be able to eradicate all these accidents.

People must understand that though some places are blind spots or whatever we can call them, they should be able to follow the existing laws.'' Kabera added




This comes after more than four accidents involving motor vehicles, motorists and pedestrians have occurred on the same road and the Rwanda National police continues to sensitise the masses on road safety in a campaign dubbed '' Gerayo amahoro.''

Rwanda Air CEO becomes the first ever woman chair to this governing body and is the 81st in line of succession.

At the top of the agenda are decarbonization, improving safety, the transformation to modern airline retailing, and ensuring we have cost-efficient infrastructure. I am particularly pleased to be taking on this role as IATA launches Focus Africa with the aim of unifying the continent’s stakeholders so that together we can strengthen the contribution of aviation to Africa’s social and economic development,”




Yvonne brought her 11 years of commercial expertise to her current role, from telecommunications company MTN Rwanda in 2006, before she would start her aviation career in 2017 when she was appointed as RwandAir’s Deputy CEO in Charge of Corporate Affairs. and later appointed CEO in April 2018.  Under her leadership, the national carrier has become one of Africa’s fastest growing airlines with a fleet of 13 modern aircrafts, without forgetting cultural change at the airline with a focus on inclusion and diversity while growing the number of women in under-represented roles. 

'' Congratulations!, and i look forward to working with Yvonne as we tackle the important challenges of sustainability, rebuilding the aviation workforce while growing diversity and reinforcing the global standards that are so critical for efficient connectivity. GONE BUT NOT FORGOTTEN, RWANDA CELEBRATES THE LIFE OF FOREIGN SENEGALESE PEACEKEEPER DIAGNE.

14:03, 2023-06-02

As Rwanda celebrates the life of a foreign hero from Senegal that went face to face with armed men, stood in between civilians and armed militias yet never lost his smile, most people in the world asked themselves who is Capt. Mbaye Diagne?

 Mbaye Diagne was born on 18 March 1958, was a Senegalese military officer who served in Rwanda as a United Nations military observer from 1993 to 1994. During the Rwandan genocide against the tutsi he undertook many missions on his own initiative to save the lives of civilians.

Diagne was born in Senegal, ahortly after graduating from the University of Dakar he enrolled in the Senegalese Army's École Nationale des Officiers d'Active where he completed his schooling.

 The following year, he  attained the rank of captain and was given command of the 3rd Company of the 6th Infantry Battalion where he fought in the Casamance conflict from 1989 to 1993.

That year Diagne was sent to Rwanda as part of an Organisation of African Unity(OAU) military observer team tasked with monitoring the Rwandan Civil War, a conflict fought between the Hutu-dominated government and the Tutsi-led Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF). Later he was assigned to the United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda (UNAMIR), a UN peacekeeping force meant to oversee the implementation of the Arusha Accords—a peace agreement designed to end the war. In April 1994 the President of Rwanda was killed. Hutu extremists initiated the Rwandan genocide, targeting members of the Tutsi ethnic minority. They murdered moderate Hutu Prime Minister Agathe Uwilingiyimana, and Diagne rescued her children and secured them safe passage out of the country. He then undertook numerous missions on his own around Kigali in violation of the UN's rules of engagement, hiding Tutsis in his car and evacuating them to UN installations. He also protected some Hutus and worked to safeguard the Senegalese expatriate community. Various estimates exist for the number of lives Diagne saved, ranging as high as over 1,000 according to his then confidant, BBC journalist Mark  Doyle.

Mbaye who is believed to have been on his last trip of the day from the hotel back to the Un headquarters carrying a certain message to his then commander, was stopped at a blocked bridge shortly before a mortar was launched on the location and a fragment through his rear windscreen struck his head and he died instantly. Instead of returning home in 12 weeks like earlier anticipate, Mbaye was retrieved later in a body bag home where he was accorded an full military burial.

Ever since then a couple of medals have been posthumously awarded to the foreign soldier, among them are rank of Knight in Senegal's National Order of the Lion, the UN Security Council’s Captain Mbaye Diagne Medal for Exceptional Courage, Rwanda’s Umurinzi honor, USA’s Persons Of Courage certificate, and an Italian veteran of UNAMIR created an association to "promote Diagne’s memory and support his family’s development, finally On 31 May 2019 the Senegalese Army renamed its training centre in Thiès after Diagne.

Like the Rwandan people say, ‘‘the brave never die, they rest’’, he shall forever live and be remembered by those whose life he saved and still testify for his good deeds.




ANOTHER WIN FOR THE BIDEN ADMINSTRATION: US PASSES DEBT CEILING BILL.

00:22, 2023-06-01

 A divided U.S. House of Representatives passed a bill to suspend the $31.4 trillion debt ceiling on Wednesday 31st may,, with majority support from both Democrats and Republicans to overcome opposition led by hardline conservatives and avoid a catastrophic default.




The Republican-controlled House voted 314-117 to send the legislation to the Senate, which must enact the measure and get it to President Joe Biden's desk before a Monday deadline, when the federal government is expected to run out of money to pay its bills.




The U.S. is one of only two industrialized nations that separate the government’s ability to spend from its ability to borrow (the other is Denmark). In 1917, Congress instituted a maximum debt limit—often referred to as the debt ceiling—to protect the government and its citizens against a blank-check mentality that could lead to unbridled spending.

While the debt ceiling worked well as a fiscal balancing tool for nearly 100 years, it has recently become a point of contention.

What is clear is that the U.S. government has experienced unsustainable debt growth, accumulating debt far greater than what it earns in any given year. And, while most people agree that the government needs to bring its budget deficit under control, building consensus behind the best approach seems full of political potholes.




Could this be another heavy thrill sent to the Biden opposition a head of next year's run for the White House?, we keep our fingers crossed

KIGALI WATER SHORTAGE TO FINALLY BE SORTED BY 600 KM SUPPLY PROJECT.

23:41, 2023-05-31

As Rwanda is still on its way to make sure all people have safe and piped water by the Year 2024 

The Kigali Water Network Project has begun bearing fruits in addressing water shortage in the City and other peri-urban areas.




A project undertaken by WASAC in 2019 consists of constructing rehabilitating, upgrading, and extension of over 600km water supply network. 




It was implemented by WASAC since 2019 with Rwf62 billion loan from African Development Bank (AFDB).




With the project's success, places that would have lost water for four consecutive days now have water regularly according to Xavier Rwibasira the project coordinator.




Only 16 km out of more than 600 km water supply system have not yet been completed and the works will be complete at the end of June this year," he said.

To improve the network efficiency, the project interventions include the replacement of old pipes to reduce non-revenue water, replacement of small distribution pipes, increase of storage capacity and construction of pressure break tanks, and extension of the network in new development areas.

In 2021, the beneficiaries who used to face regular water shortages began to have access to clean water after two years of the project, Rwibasira and.

Approximately 398,300 people will have access to clean water in Nyarugenge, Gasabo, Kicukiro districts of Kigali City, Runda and Rugalika areas of Kamonyi District in Southern province, Bugesera District in Eastern Province, Muyumbu and Nyakariro of Rwamagana District in Eastern Province and, Shyorongi of Rulindo District in Northern Province.

BRAZIL CORN OUT COMPETES US CORN ON CHINA MARKET.

11:29, 2023-05-30

Over 400 Brazilian companies are set to start exporting corn to China.

This comes in bid to strengthen the BRICS alliance which saw more Chinese companies set their arrows for Brazilian corn as compared to US expensive options.

China currently is world's top corn consumer and a member of the BRICS alliance.




According to market estimates, Brazil may export around 5 million tones of corn to China this year which is 10% of total global corn exports and 94% more than Brazilian corn exports to China as compare to 2022.




In December alone, just after China and Brazil concluded a corn trade deal, Brazil exported 1.1 million tones of corn to China. In January, almost 1 million tones were exported. “Since May 2022, Brazilian corn prices became cheaper than the US corn by US$ 0.05 per kg on average”, says Sandra Steinbach Director of the Center for Agricultural Policy and Trade Studies of North Dakota State University in an interview with Czapp.




China is ramping up corn imports from Brazil: one of the main reasons is the loss of competitiveness of the US corn? Is it cheaper now to buy Brazilian corn than the US corn?

A trend of increasing price difference between the two countries can be observed since May 2022, with Brazil’s average corn export price being lower.

Moreover, it is noted that since 2019 an additional tariff of 10% was imposed on corn imported from US by China as a measure of trade retaliation.

It is possible that the combination of higher corn export price and the additional retaliatory tariffs has made it difficult for corn importing companies in China to continue sourcing from the United States. As a result, these companies may have turned to alternative suppliers with lower prices.

Aganira n’abacungamutungo batandukanye baturutse mu bigo bya leta, umugenzuzi mukuru w’imari ya leta yabanje gutanga urugero rwa RAB, Akarere ka Nyanza na Gisagara nka bimwe mu bigo byashoye leta mu manza zitari ngombwa, anasaba abandi kwitwararika bakajya babanza kugenzura neza niba

ibikorwa basabwa kwishyura bihari koko.




Twegereye bamwe mubacungamutungo bitabiriye aya mahugurwa bakanaba abanyamuryango b’ikigo ICPAR bagira icyo batubwira kuri raporo y’umugenzuzi mukuru w’imari ya leta ndetse n’ingamba bafashe.

Ndamukunda Eddy Grace ni umwe mubitabiriye amahugurwa y’iminsi 3 yatanzwe na ICPAR, yagarutse kuri raporo y’umugenzuzi w’imari ya leta anagaruka ku ngamba bafashe mu rwego rwo gucunga no gukoresha neza imari ya leta hagamijwe guha umuturage serivisi nziza.

Ati: “Nibyo yatugaragarije ishusho y’ukuntu ingengo y’imari igenda ikoreshwa, atubwira ukuntu amafaranga aba yatanzwe kugira ngo abaturage babone serivise neza, atugaragariza ko hari amafaranga adakoreshwa neza ndetse ko hari ibigo bimwe na bimwe bigenda bigwa mu bihombo, byatweretse ko icyo igihugu gishaka ari uko abaturage batera imbere kandi nkatwe abacungamutungo bateraniye muri

iyi nama turasabwa kwitanga, tugahindura imikorere, tukagira ubushake bwo gukora neza ndetse n’imikoranire y’inzego kugira ngo amafaranga abashe gukoreshwa neza abaturage babone serivise

igihugu gitere imbere.”




Umuyobozi wa ICPAR Amin MIRAMAGO yagarutse kuri raporo y’umugenzi w’imari ya leta, anakomoza ku mpamvu z’aya mahugurwa n’icyitezwe nk’umusaruro nyuma yayo.

“Intego twari twihaye turabona turi kuyigeraho, muri raporo y’umugenzuzi w’imari ya leta, hagiye

hagaragara ko hakirimo intege nkeya ahantu hamwe na hamwe,ni muri urwo rwego buri mwaka dufata umwanya tukaganira kuri ibyo bibazo kugira ngo byibuze nabariya bandi bagifite intege nkeya tube

twabafasha nabo bazamuke, kuko hari ibigo byinshi byagiye biva muri icyo kiciro cyo hasi bikazamuka bigacunga neza umutungo wa leta.”




Aya mahugurwa abaye ku nshuro ya kabiri aho ICPAR ihugura abacungamutungo bakora mu bigo bya leta bitandukanye ikabafasha gukora kinyamwuga ibongerera ubumenyi mu bijyanye n’akazi kabo ka buri munsi. Amahugurwa y’uyu mwaka akaba yaritabiriwe n’abasaga Magana atatu aho basoje biyemeje kugaragaza impinduka nziza.

''TURKEY HAS WON'' SAYS RECEP TAYYIP ERDOGAN.

05:51, 2023-05-29

President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of the AK party has won another five years in power in Turkey's run off election,

The supreme election council by today morning confirmed that the Edogan had  won by 52% of the votes, with his secular rival, Kemal Kilicdaroglu garnering a stunning 48% trial , however he says the election was the most unfair in the history of turkey.




Erdogan who became Turkish prime minister in 2003, has been president since 2014.

In his victory speech to thousands of supporters in Ankara and Istanbul , he said "Turkey has won".




He went ahead to thank the voters that turned out in big numbers to cast their vote, as he said this was a big milestone for Turkey's democracy but also a population's trust in the AK party's ability to stabilize the economy amid the shooting inflation and also handling better the Syrian refugee crisis that is been a rising issue over the years.

Edorgan is now set to lead for other more five years to prove himself as the right choice Turkey made.




ONCE MOST WANTED, FINALLY CAPTURED; Fulgence Kayishema

12:08, 2023-05-25

 Fulgence Kayishema is alleged to have orchestrated the brutal killing of 2,000 women, men and children at a catholic Nyange church in Kivumu, Kibuye prefecture, on 15 April during the 1994 genocide against the Tutsi in the East African nation. The suspect and his colleagues are said to have attempted to burn the church down as a fast way to kill all those that had sought refuge in the church but failed and later would opt for the choice of bulldozing it down




He was indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) in 2001 and had been on the run ever since, using various aliases and disguises, ever since.

The Nyange church attack is remembered as one of the most brutal acts during the 100 days of the Rwandan genocide against the Tutsi.




The Tanzania-based ICTR sentenced more than 60 ringleaders of the genocide, including three over the Notre Dame de la Visitation church massacre including the church's priest, Athanase Seromba, who was sentenced to life in prison in 2008, before the ICTR closed down in 2015, with the remaining cases being taken over by the MICT.

11:34, 2023-05-25

A former ally of president Trump, Ron DeSantis announces his bid for president on twitter amid a glitch session that was hosted by the Twitter boss himself Elon Musk.

What had been as an awaited announcement turned out to be a momentum of his ridicule by his radicle opponents' (Trump) supporters, with some of them going heads on with tweets.




“Ron DeSantis’ botched campaign announcement is another example of why he is just not ready for the job. The stakes are too high, and the fight to save America is too critical to gamble on a first-timer who is clearly not ready for prime time,” said Karoline Leavitt, a spokeswoman for Make America Great Again Inc., Trump’s super PAC.




However the unbothered DeSantis, in his opening address to listeners, painted a dark picture of a country he said is going in the wrong direction under Biden and urged Republicans to get behind him.

“My pledge to you is this: If you nominate me you can set your clock to January 20, 2025, at high noon because on the west side of the US Capitol, I will be taking the oath of office as the 47th president of the United States,” DeSantis said. “No excuses, I will get the job done.”




This sets a fertile play area in the Republican camp as the former president has treated DeSantis, whom he once endorsed for Florida governor, as his top foe for months, assailing him regularly on social media and in interviews. A super PAC aligned with Trump has spent millions attacking DeSantis on national television, setting expectations for a bruising primary between the two former allies.




ANOTHER COMPLAINT TO ICC AGAINST RWANDA ARMY, M23 REBELS IS FILED BY DRC.

12:01, 2023-05-24

With a series of failure to provide circumstantial evidence, the Democratic Republic of the Congo yesterday made another formal referral to the International Criminal Court (ICC) to ensure the court will focus on the alleged systematic pillaging of its natural resources in the country’s east by the Rwanda Defense Force (RDF) and the M23 rebel group.




“The government of the DRC remains deeply concerned about the suffering of the populations in the part of its territory affected by the acts referred to in this case,” the Congolese Justice Ministry claimed in a statement.

The goal of this referral is to investigate and prosecute any person involved in human rights violations between 2022 and 2023, it added.




Kinshasa continues to accuse neighbouring Rwanda of backing the M23, however there is continuing ICC investigation into eastern DRC – since 2004 – and it is unclear if the new referral would shift the court’s focus.

To date, the ICC has convicted three different Congolese militia leaders – one for war crimes and the others for war crimes and crimes against humanity – for their roles in atrocities committed in the eastern DRC.

ICC Prosecutor Karim Khan is expected to visit Kinshasa and Congolese provinces affected by rebel groups from May 28 to May 31, in away to understand the case at hand.

LOONKIITU KILLED.

08:34, 2023-05-22

Conservationists in East Africa are worried with the rate at which lions in the biggest populous Kenya are being killed. This comes after the biggest number of lions killed was registered last Saturday alone.

The Kenya wildlife services confirmed to have lost over ten lions in just the previous week including the oldest of Africa Loonkiitu, who had wondered off to un protected part of the park where he faced the wrath of the livestock keepers according to conservation organization Lion Guardians.




The organization said that the end of a drought is commonly marked by an increase in human-lion conflict, since wild prey becomes harder to hunt and livestock owners are “particularly vigilant” after losing so many animals. Kenya has been experiencing its worst drought in 40 years.

The six lions that died on Saturday had killed 11 goats and one dog, the KWS said in a press release yesterday.

GREECE: FROM MONEY LENDER'S INFLUENCE TO DEMOCRACY.

06:35, 2023-05-22

Greece’s ruling New Democracy party scored a crushing victory in parliamentary elections Sunday but fell short of winning an outright majority in a vote dominated by the cost-of-living crisis, a wiretapping scandal and anger over the country’s deadliest-ever train crash.

With more than 99% of votes counted, ruling center-right party of Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, surpassed all expectations garnering more than 40% of the vote in a result he described as a “political earthquake.”

His main opposition, Alexis Tsipras’s centre-left Syriza party, suffered major losses, coming in second with just over 20% of the vote.




However, Mitsotakis did not win enough votes to secure a single-party government. The vote was held under a new proportional representation system that requires a threshold of around 45%.

Greek President Katerina Sakellaropoulou will now give the top three parties up to three days to form a coalition, though Mitsotakis has already indicated he’s not interested in sharing power.

“Without a doubt, the political earthquake that occurred today calls on us all to speed up the process for a definitive government solution so our country can have an experienced hand at its helm as soon as possible,” Mitsotakis told jubilant New Democracy supporters massed outside party headquarters in Athens.

03:31, 2023-04-26

Umujyi wa Kigali utangaza ko ibyo bilometero 300 by’imihanda y’imigenderano biri rwego rwo koroshya uburyo bwo gutwara abantu n’ibintu.

Aganira n‘itangazamakuru, Meya w’Umujyi wa Kigali, Pudence Rubingisa, yatangaje ko iyo mihanda izaba yuzuye mu gihe cy’imyaka ine iri imbere.

Ni imihanda izubakwa mu bice by’Umujyi wa Kigali biri mu nkengero ahatari hasanzwe imihanda nyamara bigaragara ko hari guturwa cyane ku buryo abaturage batoroherwa no kuhava cyangwa kuhagera.

Ati “Mu nkengero z’Umujyi nka Gikomero, Rutunga, Nduba n’ahandi bakunze guhura n’ikibazo cyo kubona imodoka zitwara abagenzi. Biterwa n’uko akenshi muri ibi bice hatagera imodoka rusange, ni yo mpamvu dufite gahunda yo kuhubaka imihanda y’imigenderano izakurura abashoramari batwara abantu.”

Yakomeje avuga ko iyi mihanda nimara kubakwa, bazavugana na ba rwiyemezamirimo bagashora imari mu gushyiramo imodoka zitwara abagenzi, ngo kandi mu gihe izaba yubakwa, bayitezeho gutanga akazi kuri benshi.

Nubwo imihanda iri kubakwa ngo uburyo bwo gutwara abantu n’ibintu bushoboke mu mujyi wa Kigali, hashize igihe abagenzi binubira ubuke bw’imodoka rusange.

Rubingisa yijeje ko bagiye kuzongera ku buryo ibibazo byo kubura imodoka cyangwa gukererwa kubera ko zabaye nke bihagarara.

03:01, 2023-04-26

Impande zombi zatangaje ko amatariki ambasade zizafungurirwaho azatangazwa nyuma.

Itangazo ry’Ibiro bya Qatar bishinzwe Isakazamakuru Mpuzamahanga ritangaza ko “Imirimo irakomeje hagati y’itsinda rya Qatar n’irya Leta Zunze Ubumwe z’Abarabu kugira ngo hafungurwe za ambasade vuba bishoboka, itariki nyayo izamenyekana ku musozo w’ibikorwa.”
